PETITION.TITLE: Australian Federal Police
PETITION.PARA: The Acting Clerk-Petitions have been lodged for presentation as follows:
Australian Federal Police
To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:
The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia members of the Australian Federal Police shows:

We are greatly concerned at the Government's proposed removal of the Protective Service Component of the Australian Federal Police and the Government's proposed establishment of a Guarding Service using the effected members of the Protective Service Component of the Australian Federal Police.

We are concerned that national security currently being enjoyed by various Federal Government departments, some subject to the Defence Alliance Agreement, are not jeopardised by the disbandonment of the Protective Service Component of the Australian Federal Police by being placed into the hands of a proposed civilian and undisciplined organisation.

We are concerned at the huge expenditure of the taxpayers' money that would be involved by the creation of a new administrative organisation when we currently have satisfactory administration of all Australian Federal Police activities under one management and secondly in considering the taxpayers' money unnecessarily expended in logistical areas, eg the creation of an entirely new nationwide radio network, purchasing of stores, uniforms and ancillary equipment , motor vehicles and suitable premises to house the administrative body of the proposed guarding service and many other items too numerous to mention.

We are concerned that this could be the first step in the complete fragmentation of the Australian Federal Police considering your mandates determination to implement self-government for the Australian Capital Territory and moves afoot to establish an independent Australian Capital Territory law enforcement agency.

We are concerned that the interest of all members of the Protective Service Component of the Australian Federal Police and their families could be jeopardised by such a move and that members may well be discriminated against or disadvantaged as has happened following the amalgamation of the former Commonwealth Police and Australian Capital Territory Police.

We request that to protect the interests of the members of the Protective Service Component as opposed to forming a new guarding service that the Australian Federal Police Act 1979 be amended by the deletion of Sections 6 (d), 7 (2) and 10 from the Act.

We request the retention of a Protective Service Branch of the Australian Federal Police for training members desirous of obtaining a transfer to the General Policing Component of the Australian Federal Police and as an auxillary, trained and disciplined force of men capable of being used to meet emergency situations such as Cyclone Tracy, security for royal visits and visiting VIPs ( CHOGM Conference) and the like and for the 1985 World Athletics Games to be held in the Australian Capital Territory.

We request that a complete review of all functions of the Australian Federal Police be carried out to establish the areas of responsibility of the operational units of the Australian Federal Police and the most effective means of obtaining these objectives.

Your petitioners therefore pray that the Senate stop the proposed formation of a new guarding service, that national security at various Government departments be retained, that the Australian Federal Police Act 1979 be amended by the deletions of Sections 6 (d), 7 (2) and 10, that taxpayers money is not squandered and that a complete review be carried out of all functions of the Australian Federal Police to establish the most effective means of achieving its objectives.

PETITION.TITLE: Sex Discrimination Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens respectfully showeth:
That the Sex Discrimination Bill 1983 contains provisions inconsistent with principles of justice and equality which could be used to:
Undermine civil liberties and religious freedoms;
Entrench abortion funding and render liable to action hospitals, doctors and nurses, who conscientiously refuse to become involved in morally objectionable operations;
Deny to parents their rights to insist that the school 'community' provide an environment condusive to the development, including moral development of their children.

Your petitioners humbly pray that the Senate, in Parliament assembled; should amend the Bill so as to prevent the possibility of its use in the manner stated above and urge, because of the importance to society of all principles involved, that a conscience vote on the Bill be permitted to all Members of Parliament.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Kindergartens and Pre-Schools: Funding
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.
The petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth:

That your petitioners recognise that early childhood education is fundamentally important to the intellectual, emotional, social and physical development of children and that major reductions in kindergarten and preschool funding since 1976 have seriously jeopardised the future of community based early childhood education.
Your petitioners most humbly pray that the Senate in Parliament assembled should:
(i) Legislate to provide triennial Commonwealth funding for community based kindergartens and preschools.
(ii) Ensure that such funding is sufficient to cover:
(a) 100 per cent of the salaries and wages of all approved employed kindergarten and preschool staff and advisors;
(b) long service leave and sick leave payments of such staff and advisors;
(c) extended services which are operated because of the special needs in a particular area;
(d) maintenance and renewal of buildings and equipment;
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Resources and Energy. Has the Minister seen or read the transcript of the Four Corners program on uranium which was televised last weekend? Does he regard it as a fair and objective treatment of this important subject? If not, why not? Does he believe that his own views were adequately and fairly presented? If not, why not ?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —One could give a lengthy answer to the question. I do not intend to give a very lengthy answer to the question, but I will mention two or three things. The main response is that, in my view, it was far from an objective presentation. Reference was made to Oak Ridge in Tennessee. Whilst it is correct that the International Atomic Energy Agency inspectors do not inspect the plant, a fence or a 'black box' I think is the term that some people use, is placed around the plant by the International Atomic Energy Agency which conducts quantum checks on the amount of material moving in or out of the plant. That material must be satisfactorily accounted for. If it cannot be satisfactorily accounted for the matter is reported.

ANSWER.PARA: The Four Corners program omitted about 90 per cent of what I had said. Whilst some editing is always to be expected in these cases, one important statement I made was not telecast. That was that, although it is technically feasible to produce weapons grade plutonium from a power reactor, there is no known instance of that having been done, at least in the non-communist world. It is possible to operate a power reactor in a way which makes it very much easier to produce weapons grade plutonium. The International Atomic Energy Agency safeguards are devised in a way which ensures the prompt discovery of a power reactor being operated in that way.

Essentially the technical background is that the production of weapons grade plutonium requires very quick irradiation of the fuel rod. In most power plants the fuel rods are left in the reactor for a period of approximately 12 months, by which time there is a heavy contamination of non-fissile plutonium isotopes. However, if the rods are very quickly irradiated the plutonium produced is much less contaminated by the non-fissile isotopes. The International Atomic Energy Agency's monitoring procedures of power plants are designed in such a way that the unusual or improper operation of a reactor in that way, that is, by changing fuel rods more frequently than is required for power generation purposes, would be detected before the intensively and short term irradiated rods could be reprocessed into potential explosive material.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask a supplementary question. The Minister has said, and I understand why he said it, that he could have given a very lengthy answer. I wonder whether in the near future he would look at the transcript of the Four Corners program, since it dealt with an important subject, and consider preparing a written statement that could be presented to the Senate for incorporation in Hansard so that the subject matter could be developed further.

—On reflection, the original question asked whether I had read the transcript. The answer is no, I have not. I saw the Four Corners program. I shall certainly consider the suggestion that Senator Sir John Carrick has put forward.

—Is the Leader of the Government in the Senate aware of the urgent need for manufacturing industry in Australia to invest in modern machinery if it is to remain competitive and efficient? In light of the Minister 's call for manufacturing industry to update and modernise, what steps has the Government taken to facilitate the introduction of modern technology in manufacturing industry?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am very surprised that Senator McIntosh should ask that question because it is a matter in respect of which I issued a Press statement only yesterday. I am pleased that Senator McIntosh's mind is thinking along lines similar to my own.

ANSWER.PARA: A number of public comments have been made about the state of machine tools in Australian manufacturing industry, but such comments have not always been accurate. It is fair to say that the manufacturing tool equipment industry in Australia is very much older on the whole than that of many of the countries with which we seek to compete. For a year I have been trying to draw attention to this problem and to the need to upgrade the technological capacity of Australian industry, particularly in the area of processing. When talking about industry generally it is most important that we encourage the incorporation of modern technology into existing industries at the same time as some of us talk about the possibility of creating new industries in this country.

Of course, one of the key areas is the question of computer assisted manufacturing and computer assisted design in Australian industry. As I said earlier, I announced yesterday the establishment of an expert committee to advise on the desirability of a manufacturing advisory service on CAD-CAM flexible manufacturing systems and robotics. I make the point that flexible manufacturing systems and modern technology can help substantially to overcome some of the disabilities which Australian industry has faced in the past because of low volume runs and short production runs in what is a relatively small market. Much lower tooling costs and so on are associated with flexible manufacturing systems. I regard all these initiatives as important if Australian industry is to become more competitive.

The expert committee which has been established will advise on how a manufacturing network of the kind I referred to could be structured in Australia . That committee will be chaired by Mr Kevin Cashman of Sunbeam Corporation Ltd and will have on it various other industrialists and what can best be described in shorthand terms as technologists. I believe that they will be able to produce a sensible and co-ordinated approach to the introduction of technology as appropriate. I use the expression 'as appropriate' because at a time when manufacturers are being bombarded with a variety of new technologies it is very important that they embrace appropriate technologies and not technologies for their own sake. I confidently believe that the work of this committee will help in those tasks. I should also say that my Department is engaged on a joint exercise with the Metal Trades Industry Association of Australia to try to collect accurate and up-to-date statistics on the machine tool population of Australia. Many of the figures cited, to which I referred earlier, in relation to the age of machine tools are now somewhat out of date. With the reports of those two initiatives, together with the report of the Industries Assistance Commission on machine tools and robots, the Government will be in a good position to push ahead with this important aspect of industry modernisation in Australia which I regard as absolutely crucial if manufacturing industry is to embrace the chance which it has now, a chance which I have sometimes described as the last chance.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister for Resources and Energy in his own capacity and as Minister representing the Minister for Trade. Is it true as reported in today's Australian Financial Review that the Minister has asked his Department for information on the trade implications of a ban on the supply of uranium to France while that country continues nuclear tests in the Pacific? Does the Minister agree that Government disruption of otherwise legally binding contracts for the supply of uranium would have an adverse impact , and indeed could have an extremely adverse impact, on Australia's reputation as a reliable supplier of raw materials? Is he, as reported, reconsidering the ban on the supply to France under present conditions which is contained in the Government's draft policy proposals because of those adverse effects on Australian export industries?

—I frequently ask my Department for advice, both factual information and departmental opinions, about a wide variety of matters. There is nothing unusual in that. I will continue to do so. The second part of the question related to the intervention by a government to prevent the delivery of any material for which delivery has been contracted. It certainly could be argued that that would adversely affect the reputation of countries as suppliers of materials. But I might add that it would not be without precedent. The action of the previous Government, for example, in terminating sand mining on Fraser Island had precisely the same consequences.

—Is the Minister representing the Minister for Transport aware of criticisms which have been made by Opposition representatives from Tasmania of the inquiry into the Tasmanian freight equalisation scheme being conducted by the Inter-State Commission, namely, that by the honourable member for Wilmot, who alleges that the Federal Government simply wants to scrap the scheme? Can the Minister provide an assurance of the Government's bona fides on this matter?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Gietzelt Sen The Hon A.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —Tasmanian freight problems have been the subject of debate and concern in this Parliament for as long as I can remember and clearly we cannot expect them to be solved in the first year of the Hawke Labor Government. I am aware of the hypocritical, supercritical and somewhat antagonistic remarks that have been made by Opposition members from Tasmania about the referral of the Tasmanian freight equalisation scheme to the Interstate Commission. It has been suggested that that has been done for some ulterior purpose, whereas the motivation of the Minister for Transport in this matter is to assist Tasmanians.

ANSWER.PARA: Clearly, of course, there is a major problem of transport costs involving Tasmania. Tasmania does have a transport disability in relation to the mainland which we all accept. That is the reason, of course, that we have the Tasmanian freight equalisation scheme. However, the problems that have arisen since the operation of the scheme clearly need to be examined by the Inter-State Commission. The Commission is now headed by the honourable Mr Justice Everett, who of course is a Tasmanian. He would be well aware of what freight problems mean to the citizens of Tasmania. I can give an assurance to Senator Hearn that, having this matter reviewed by the Inter-State Commission, the Government is hopeful that a solution or at least a part solution to the freight problem in that State will be found. We have a situation in which there is overcompensation and under-compensation. There needs to be more equalisation.

Any suggestion by Opposition members of criticism of the Government's intent in this matter will do very little to assist the Government and the citizens of Tasmania. We require the co-operation of all concerned-the business sector and the consumer movement. Any scaremongering or imputing of improper motives to the InterState Commission will do a grave disservice to the citizens of Tasmania. It is about time Opposition members adopted a constructive approach and stopped their destructive criticism.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Minister representing the Minister for Aviation. —I think I indicated in reply to a question late last year that the Government has under consideration some of the suggestions made by Senator Jack Evans about better coastal surveillance, particularly in the areas to which he referred, the north-east and north-west parts of Australia, in respect of matters such as illegal immigrants, drug running and other illegal activities. The Minister for Aviation has this matter under consideration. I assure the honourable senator that the Government will shortly examine how best it can handle difficulties which obviously have been with us for many years. The Minister himself indicated privately to me that he has the matter under active consideration. I shall certainly draw the Minister's attention to the specific matters raised by Senator Jack Evans for perhaps a better update on how far the Minister has progressed in his discussions with Cabinet.

—Does the Minister for Resources and Energy agree that the uranium policy adopted by the Victorian conference of the Australian Labor Party yesterday is, in the words of Mrs Joan Coxsedge, 'the strongest, more coherent anti-uranium policy that has ever been presented to any Labor Party conference'? Does the Minister believe that the policy adopted at the conference in Perth yesterday, which he attended, is in line with or opposed to current Government policy? Is it true that, as reported on the AM program, he is not happy with the decision but that it is not significant?

—I do not know what motions were carried at the Victorian conference. Coincidentally, about 10 seconds before this question was asked of me, I was handed a list of the items that were dealt with at that conference. I make no comment on it because I would necessarily be making a comment without knowledge of the facts. I will comment on the Perth conference. The first question asked by Senator Archer was whether the motions carried at that conference were a repudiation of Government policy. The answer to that question is no, in that the motions which were carried and on which clarification was sought following the taking of the last vote, are virtually identical to the position adopted by the Government. In my opinion, however-this is what prompted my comment to which Senator Archer referred-the package of motions carried in Western Australia contains very similar elements of the inconsistency or, some would argue, even contradictoriness which is present in the present Federal platform of the Labor Party.

—I ask a supplementary question to allow Senator Walsh an opportunity to make this matter clear. The question I asked was whether the Minister believed that the policy adopted at the conference in Perth was in line with Government policy. The Minister said the answer is no. Is that what he meant? Secondly, the Minister said he had not read the Victorian advice. Will he please report to the Senate when he has read it?
—The first part of the question is a supplementary question.

—The answer to the very last question is no. The answer to the earlier part of the question, in order to clear any confusion in the answer which I gave, without getting the positives and negatives confused, is that the essential part of the resolutions carried at the conference in Western Australia yesterday is compatible with the policy adopted by the Caucus and the Government last year. The most important component of it is that it recognises that the development of the Roxby Downs mine will not be inhibited, although there can be no guarantee that the Roxby Downs project will proceed. Commercial decisions are involved. Primarily it is a commercial decision to be taken by the joint venturers on which they are due to report by the end of this year.

—My question is directed to the Attorney-General. I refer him to the calls by the Human Rights Commission, reported at the weekend, for legislation to outlaw the dissemination of race hatred propaganda. I ask: Will the Attorney-General indicate what steps the Government has taken or proposes to take to deal with this growing problem?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am aware of the public statements by the Chairman, Dame Roma Mitchell, and the Deputy Chairman, Peter Bailey, over the weekend. I want to make it clear that I welcome the active role that is being taken by the Commission to publicise important issues in the human rights field and to bring forward constructive suggestions for legislative reform. The views of the Commission have already been forwarded to me and made available generally in the report it made late last year on the problem of race hatred propaganda, which report contained proposals for amendment to the Racial Discrimination Act to cover incitement to race hatred and racial defamation. Those proposals are presently under consideration by the Government, as I have indicated previously in this place, in the context of the review of human rights legislation generally, and the Racial Discrimination Act in particular, presently being conducted by a departmental task force with the benefit of public submissions following advertisements seeking such submissions late last year. I do make the point that recent events, in particular the spate of offensive stickers and pamphlets directed at Asian immigrants, have once again highlighted the propensity of some members of our community to engage in racist behaviour specifically designed to provoke ill will or worse against ethnic minorities.

ANSWER.PARA: I also take this occasion to express my concern at what seems to me to be something of a deterioration in standards so far as less extreme racial slurs are concerned. In that respect I refer particularly to an article in a leading Melbourne paper over the weekend which purported to be an interview with Gary MacDonald, of Norman Gunston fame, describing the way in which he had moved to take the role as Fagan in the Oliver Twist theatre production, the heading for which, as I recall it, was something along the lines of: 'From Little Aussie Bleeder to Crafty Jew'. It seems to me that that kind of stereotyping, which was repeated in the text of the article, but most conspicuously in the headline, is wholly offensive to particular minority groups within our community. Although I certainly would not want to suggest that this is the kind of thing that is in any way appropriate to penal sanctions, it is, I believe, the kind of thing that quite rightly attracts concern by the Commission.

I make the point finally, as I have on previous occasions, that this is not an easy one to resolve because of the fundamental tension here between the principle of free speech and expression on the one hand, and on the other the right of all individuals to live in a harmonious society free of prejudice and persecution. I am not sure how the balance can best be struck; it may be by some extended civil remedy for group defamation, but this is the kind of thing to which the Government is giving close consideration. I hope to be in a position to report on this later in the year.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question, which is also to the Attorney-General, follows the answer he has just given. I express my agreement with him that we should discourage racial hatred and manifestations of it, but I ask him to assure the Senate that in any consideration the Government gives this matter there will be no attempt to reduce the freedom of people such as Professor Blainey to raise what are significant questions of public policy and issues such as our immigration policy, and that very careful attention will be given to the need to ensure freedom of speech on these important matters.

—I am happy to give the honourable senator such an assurance . I remind him that in saying that I am saying no more than I have consistently said in every public contribution I have made to this debate. I am aware of the importance of there being able to be contributions, rational or irrational, to public debate on sensitive topics. One can get only to first base in justifying legislative sanctions of any kind against such expression if they are of a peculiarly extreme kind and constitute something in the nature of incitement. Even then there are legitimate arguments as to how far it is proper for legislation to go. It may well be that it is better to place the emphasis on trying to develop education on these matters in the community and sensitivity to the issues involved by means other than legal ones. But that is a debate we still have to have, and it is not one that I am seeking in any way to pre-empt.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Communications. It concerns the recent ruling of the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal on tobacco advertising. Can the Minister advise why the Tribunal has chosen to give a retrospective ruling on advertisements which have been running for more than a year? Is the Minister aware that, due to these rulings, the credibility of the Tribunal has been harmed somewhat? Has the Minister for Communications discussed with the Tribunal the possible ramifications the rulings present for broadcasting?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —Insofar as Senator Elstob's question asks about retrospectivity in the Broadcasting Tribunal's decision, I would apprehend that it is the Broadcasting Tribunal's function to administer the law and if, as it does do in perusing program content and so on over a period, it finds breaches of the law, it seems to me quite in order for the Tribunal so to declare. The fact that in that sense the ruling has a retrospective application does not seem to me to be in any way objectionable. The law is there and if television licensees do not comply with the law it is the Tribunal's function to point that out and take appropriate action.

ANSWER.PARA: I am also asked whether the credibility of the Tribunal has been damaged by its ruling. In view of the part of the answer I have already given, I would say no. I am further asked by Senator Elstob whether the Minister has discussed with the Tribunal the possible ramifications for broadcasting that the ruling presents. I do not know, but I would assume that the Minister has not discussed the ruling of the Broadcasting Tribunal with that body. The Broadcasting Tribunal is an independent statutory authority and I would not regard it as the business of the Minister for Communications to canvass with it its rulings on matters which are peculiarly within the province of that statutory authority.

Finally, let me say in relation to this whole matter that the Minister for Communications made a statement, which was released on 22 March this year. I have not the details of the statement here, but if Senator Elstob wishes I can obtain a copy of it for him so that he can see in detail the approach adopted by the Minister for Communications.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask a question of the Minister for Resources and Energy. It arises from an article in the Australian today headed: 'ALP senator slams government attitude to uranium'. Does the Minister agree with his Western Australian colleague Senator Coleman who is reported to have said in her submission to the Australian Science and Technology Council inquiry into Australia's role in the nuclear fuel cycle that no confidence can be placed in the promises and commitments of political leaders regarding uranium?
—I have not seen the submission and I would not rely on that newspaper, in particular, to give an adequate account of what was contained in the submission.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: BORROLOOLA: FINANCIAL ASSISTANCE FOLLOWING CYCLONE KATHY

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Prime Minister. Last week in response to my question on assistance available to people at Borroloola following Cyclone Kathy the Minister indicated that a communication had been sent to the Chief Minister of the Northern Territory offering financial assistance. I ask the Minister: Has the Chief Minister responded to the Government's offer? It has been reported to me that several families at Borroloola are suffering because emergency food provisions are not available. Will the Minister investigate these claims and take whatever action is necessary to assist these families?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I recall Senator Robertson's question of last week. In my answer to that question I indicated that the Prime Minister had telexed the Chief Minister of the Northern Territory offering any assistance possible under the Natural Disasters Organisation relief scheme and that the Royal Australian Air Force had contributed a Caribou aircraft which had taken supplies to the area. The Prime Minister's offer to the Northern Territory Chief Minister has received no response at this stage. One does not seek to make any point about that. It may well be that a response requires a careful assessment of the damage done and so on and it may be a week or so before a response is forthcoming. The position is that, as at today, there has been no response from the Northern Territory Government.

ANSWER.PARA: Senator Robertson in his question referred to reports of alleged suffering by several families as a result of a lack of emergency supplies, particularly food. The question of emergency food relief is a matter for the Northern Territory Government. Nonetheless, I do not regard that as a satisfactory answer. Senator Robertson, in a sense, has perceived the issue by asking whether I will make inquiries to see whether that is true and whether the Commonwealth can make any contribution in respect of that problem. I will make those inquiries and will advise Senator Robertson as soon as there is a response from the Northern Territory Government to the Commonwealth offer. I will make inquiries, more particularly, regarding alleged suffering by families and provide him with a response as quickly as possible.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the Attorney-General whether he believes he should add to his answer to my question of last Friday when he said that he had no recollection of having seen a legal opinion which casts doubts on the legality of the Government's categorisation of hospitals under Medicare. I again ask whether before last Friday he saw a view that the categorisation action could not be enforced by law. If not, has he since become aware that the action was illegal? Is it not a fact that the Minister for Health rendered categorisation invalid by failing to comply with the provisions of his own Act?

—I confirm my recollection as stated here last Friday that I have not seen any such opinion. The matter is in the process of being checked. I was advised this morning that I certainly had not seen any paper on this matter. I understand that an opinion was sought and obtained, I think, by the Department of Health from a private legal counsel. That seems to be the matter to which Senator Walters is referring. I have not had any departmental briefing on it. As such I am not in a position to answer Senator Walters further. I have asked that a letter be prepared for my signature advising her of such information as I am in a position to give her. I will send that in due course.

—Has the Minister representing the Minister for Health seen the article in today's Age where the Federal President of the Australian Medical Association, Dr Lindsay Thompson, is quoted as saying that he expected the doctors who went on strike later this week would 'presume every case is an emergency until proven otherwise'? He further admitted that doctors would never mount an effective strike 'if by that you mean one that would close down a public hospital. I guess that is what separates us from the builders labourers'. Does the Minister agree that Dr Thompson's comments indicate a clear lack of commitment to the proposed strike and a cynical use of strike talk to try to intimidate this Government, and that his comments about the Builders Labourers Federation show that he does not understand what constitutes proper industrial action?

—I did briefly note the statement by Dr Thompson this morning, I think in the Age or on the radio. I did not, however, note the detail he mentioned. I suppose it is possible that the doctors' strike could close public hospitals and stop patients getting treated in those hospitals, but I imagine that the vast majority of doctors in this country would in fact not tolerate that situation and that we would not have a strike like that. I dare say there is a fair bit of cynicism in Dr Thompson's approach, because he is clearly trying to emulate the Builders Labourers Federation and other trade unions without their experience or knowledge. However, I did not note the detailed comments about the Builders Labourers Federation. It is my understanding that Dr Blewett met with Dr Thompson and other representatives of the AMA this morning. I hope that out of that there will be some resolution to this dispute. Rather than say anything more and stir the thing up, I will finish there.

What is the current average cost of weekly rental for a non-government flat in Canberra?
—I think that clearly requires an answer from the Minister for Territories and Local Government. I will seek an early response.

—My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Minister for Home Affairs and Environment. I refer the Minister to the distortions of historical fact and current reality contained in the propaganda film The Human Face of Russia, prepared and produced at taxpayers' expense by Film Australia and recently screened by the 10 Network in Melbourne and Sydney. Firstly, is the Minister aware that this Australian production contains monstrous distortions of the true position by confusing Ukrainian and Russian cultures, and indeed cities and places; giving false information about collectivisation and the Moscow-induced famine under which at least seven million Ukrainians died of starvation in the enforcement of collectivisation; and making false allegations about equality of jobs and educational opportunities while ignoring the victimisation of dissidents and religious and minority groups in these areas? Secondly, will the Minister take action to ensure that this propaganda exercise is not distributed abroad to the shame and disgrace of Australian citizens? Will the Minister seek to ensure that Australian human rights groups and Ukrainian national groups have equal opportunity to reply to this pro-Soviet propaganda? Is the Minister aware that the film is an amalgam of several films produced in 1979 which were then attacked on similar grounds?

—I am not aware of the film to which Senator Missen referred, so I cannot comment on the claims he made about distortions in the subject matter presented in it. I think the best thing I can do is refer Senator Missen's question to the Minister for Home Affairs and Environment and ask him to respond directly to Senator Missen's queries about this film.

—I direct my question to the Minister representing the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations. Has the Minister seen reports that certain citizens in Australia are advocating that employers can choose to opt out of the Conciliation and Arbitration Act? Are these the same individuals who sabotaged the central wage fixation system in 1981?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have seen some reports about this matter, but they were not discursive or necessarily well informed. I cannot say whether the people who are now advocating that companies be allowed to opt out of the Conciliation and Arbitration Act are the same people who brought the country almost to its knees with the confusion of their wages policy in 1981. After all, we in the Government accept that governments are largely responsible for administration of systems and particularly for a coherent wages policy being presented to the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission and maintained and enforced by governments. In that context, I cannot label any particular individuals as the question invites me to.

ANSWER.PARA: I suppose the current advocates of the opting out process are to be found in the present Opposition. I believe the principal advocate of that view is the discredited former Treasurer, Mr John Howard. On the other side of the picture the forces are led by the credible former Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations, Mr Ian Macphee. That is a battle which they have to resolve. If one identifies, as Senator Ray does, the forces of darkness and the festival of light in the Liberal Party, there is no doubt, if I were to exert any influence in that matter, on which side I would fall, but that might be the kiss of death for the festival of light. So the same people are involved. All one can record with horror is that because of wage increases in excess of 20 per cent in 1981- 82 the whole system of wage fixation was brought into discredit and, as a result , serious economic consequences followed for this country from which it was still recovering when this Government was elected on 5 March 1983.

TALK.START.PARA: —Does the Minister assisting the Prime Minister on the Status of Women agree with the proposition that the social and economic health of the family, as the basic unit of our society, is essential to the social and economic health of our nation? Does she agree that concern has been expressed throughout the Western world in recent times as to the future of the family by people whose political and social views cover a broad spectrum, from the so- called Moral Majority to feminists such as Germaine Greer and Betty Friedan? Is it a fact that the statistics available on the family in Australia are highly deficient and that this denies to government and interested groups and individuals the information necessary for constructive debate and decisions on matters which affect the family? Does the Minister agree that information sought through the five-yearly census forms compounds this deficiency? For example, where a spouse is temporarily absent from home on census night the family is coded as a one-parent family or, if there are no children, the spouse at home is coded as a person living alone, and so on. In view of the importance of family related information to policies on women, will the Minister undertake to urge the Prime Minister and the Government to make such additions and modifications to the 1986 census as are necessary to get accurate information on the Australian family?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen The Hon S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think it is quite clear, after a year in office, that our Government places a very high priority indeed on supporting the family in all its forms, be it the two-parent family, the single parent family or an extended family, where wage earners are caring for aged relatives. We do not assume that every family has the same composition or the same shape. We certainly regard the family unit as of basic social and economic importance, as Senator Martin suggested in her question. Our Government has undertaken a number of measures, particularly in the area of the responsibility of my colleague Senator Grimes, to assist families to provide the social and economic support necessary for their health. No doubt more measures of this kind will be implemented.
—For the health of what?

—Senator Chaney seems to be in some doubt. I am sure that Senator Grimes can list the various improvements we have made, for example for the children of low income families, in the allowance for low income families and in the dependants allowances under the various social security benefits, all of which were increased because of our recognition of the importance of giving adequate income support assistance to low income families.

ANSWER.PARA: I totally agree with the suggestion in Senator Martin's question that data regarding the economic and other circumstances of families is defective and insufficient. It is true that now we do not have accurate information covering all the aspects that affect a family's wellbeing, and we are certainly determined to improve this situation. One of the very high priorities in the restructured and strengthened Office of the Status of Women is a research program which will explore the kinds of areas which Senator Martin's question covers, as well as many others. For example, the Office of the Status of Women has just prepared a very thorough paper for the benefit of giving advice to the Government on the taxation system and the effect of current taxation measures on women, including those who are responsible for families.

That is just one example of the kind of work that the Office is undertaking. I expect that there will be many other ways in which the research program of the Office will enable the Government to improve its understanding of and policies on the economic and social situation of families. I will certainly give consideration, and ask the Prime Minister to give consideration, to those specific matters raised in Senator Martin's question which relate to the way in which census data on families is collected. If it is possible to improve the accuracy and scope of data obtained from the census by changing the way in which questions are asked, I am sure that the Government will give sympathetic consideration to that suggestion. If the Government is to have policies that are effective in assisting families, whatever their composition, I agree that it needs to have available better data.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question, which is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations, concerns the community employment program. Can the Minister say whether, as in South Australia, other States have a community employment development officer employed by councils of social service specifically to assist community groups with formulating CEP projects and submissions for funding? Does the Government intend to review the CEP guidelines in view of the fact that eligibility provisions have prevented many worthwhile projects sponsored by community groups getting off the ground?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Elstob was kind enough to mention to me a day or two ago that he intended to ask this question. I have obtained an answer to the honourable senator's question from the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations. Community employment program grants have been approved in the following States or Territories for the specific purpose of stimulating and developing CEP proposals in the community. Victoria has two development officers sponsored by the Victorian Council of Social Service. Queensland has two development officers and one administrative assistant jointly sponsored by the Queensland Council of Social Service and Basic Research Action Development. Tasmania has two development officers sponsored by the Tasmanian Council of Social Service. The Northern Territory and the Australian Capital Territory each have one development officer sponsored respectively by the Council of Social Service and by Jobless Action.

ANSWER.PARA: I am advised that my colleague the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations has had consultations with all States and Territories and is undertaking a review of CEP in the light of experience with the program to date. A number of program developments were discussed at the recent conference of labour Ministers. It is intended also that in the next few months further consultations will take place with the States and the Territories and non- government organisations to enable any modification to CEP to be introduced in the next financial year. In relation to the requirement that sponsors contribute 30 per cent of total project costs, the Minister has advised that, in view of widespread concern expressed by local government community groups, he is initiating a separate review of this requirement. That matter will be considered by the Government in the near future. At that stage no doubt I will be able to provide Senator Elstob with a further answer.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question, which is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Defence, concerns the Government's complete and unequivocal commitment to upholding the Treaty on the Non-Proliferation of Nuclear Weapons. Why does the Government want to monitor nuclear weapons development in other countries to ensure our technological lead time to produce nuclear weapons is matched to developments in such countries, when the Government says that it does not ever want to produce nuclear weapons and that it never can because of the nuclear non-proliferation treaty?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The status of the reports in last week's National Times, from which Senator Macklin draws that question, has been amply described in a statement by me in this place last Friday. There is nothing more I can usefully add to it. As to the level of commitment of this Government to the Treaty on the Non-Proliferation of Nuclear Weapons, again I can use very little language today that would be more unequivocal than the language I used on behalf of the Government last Friday. I can supplement it in at least a couple of respects just to get the record even clearer perhaps than it already is.

ANSWER.PARA: On 22 November last year Cabinet made the following decisions on arms control and disarmament which have in fact been announced but which I draw again to the honourable senator's attention. There were eight interrelated decisions. They were:
(i) to promote measures to halt and reverse the nuclear arms race;
(ii) to uphold the international nuclear non-proliferation treaty;
(iii) to promote a comprehensive and verifiable ban on nuclear testing;
(iv) to develop the concept of a nuclear free zone in the South Pacific;
(v) to support the achievement of an agreement to ban chemical weapons;
(vi) to support the process of negotiation and the achievement of balanced and verifiable arms control agreements;
(vii) to take an active role in pursuing arms control and disarmament measures wherever possible;
that includes, of course, the establishment of the Ambassador for Disarmament-
(viii) and to affirm Australia's readiness to join a consensus to hold an international conference on the Indian Ocean zone of peace question.

I also mention for the honourable senator's benefit that the strategic basis document which was considered by Cabinet last year, and I make no comment as to whether Mr Toohey's version of it was in any way accurate, contained the following key sentence on the nuclear question:

Australia's interests continue to be served by the adherence to, and support for wider acceptance of, the treaty on non-proliferation of nuclear weapons and for strengthening nuclear safeguards measures generally.

That fundamentally important sentence does not appear in the purported excerpts from the document published by the National Times last week. Any attempt to draw nourishment from the alleged language of the document in the form in which that language is articulated by the National Times ought to take considerations like that very much into account.

I repeat what I have said before. Australia is a party to the non-proliferation treaty. It regards that as a permanent and binding obligation and it will honour that obligation in every conceivable way open to it.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask that the paper from which the Minister quoted be tabled.
—The Leader of the Opposition has asked that the paper from which the Minister quoted be tabled.
—By all means.

—Can the Minister assisting the Prime Minister on the Status of Women inform the Senate whether employees of the Commonwealth Banking Corporation will be covered by provisions of the Sex Discrimination Act? If so, what steps are being taken to ensure that the great imbalance of the sexes at middle and senior levels of employment at the bank is redressed as soon as possible?

—Yes, I can confirm that employees of the Commonwealth Bank will be covered by the provisions of the Sex Discrimination Act. That will mean that the bank, like any other employer covered by the Act, will have to cease any discriminatory practices in recruitment, promotion, training and so forth. Of course, the second part of Senator Zakharov's question, that of changing the structure with regard to women and men throughout that organisation, will be addressed more substantially after the release and discussion of affirmative action proposals which are now imminent. The Sex Discrimination Act will certainly cover employees of the Commonwealth Bank.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs. I refer to the warning contained in the report of the Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs and Defence entitled 'Threats to Australia's Security':

QUESTION.PARA: The implications of the continuing unsettled security and political situation in West Irian cannot be ignored within the context of examining potential sources of conflict in which Australia might become involved.
I refer also to that part of last week's leaked defence document which stated:

Should a substantial incursion occur, the PNG Defence Force would have a very limited ability to respond. PNG could be expected to request consultation with Australia under the 1977 Joint Statement on Defence matters, leading to requests for military assistance and raising difficult issues for Australia.

Bearing in mind the above, I ask the Minister: What has been Australia's reaction to the alleged incursion of Indonesian military jets into Papua New Guinea air space last week, described by the Papua New Guinea Government as a flagrant violation of its territorial sovereignty and a serious breach of international law? Also, what is the Government doing, if anything, to help defuse the current border tension?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I can confirm reports made to the effect that the Papua New Guinea Government has delivered a protest note to the Indonesian Ambassador in Port Moresby over the intrusion into Papua New Guinea of what that Government believes to be Indonesian military aircraft. I note the Indonesian Embassy comment made public over the weekend that such an incursion was not in fact denied. The protest reflects the Papua New Guinea Government's disappointment over Indonesian handling of recent border developments and indicates the intention to review the position of the Indonesian Defence Attache in Port Moresby. Prime Minister Somare called for the Foreign Ministers of both countries to meet to iron out recent misunderstandings. The Indonesian Foreign Minister, Dr Mochtar, is reported to have welcomed that proposal for a meeting and has indicated that it could take place on his return from his current visit to Moscow.

ANSWER.PARA: The Australian Government's role has essentially been one of a spectator of these events. We are naturally very concerned at events which take place in an area so close to Australia and which do have obvious implications for Australia. However, we have taken the view and continue to take the view that matters pertaining to the Indonesian-Papua New Guinea border are for the Indonesian and Papua New Guinea governments to resolve. We are encouraged, as a result of that approach, by the indications that I have just mentioned which are that the two governments are prepared to resolve their differences through dialogue. Naturally, we hope that that process will carry through to fruition.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question, which I direct to the Minister representing the Minister for Housing and Construction, concerns the latest Indicative Planning Council report on the housing industry. I ask: Does the report confirm earlier indications that the recovery in the housing industry, particularly in my home State, South Australia, is well under way? Does the report acknowledge the role played by the Federal Government's housing policies in this recovery of the housing industry? Will the availability of resources in South Australia in any way prevent a continuation of these boom conditions in the 1984-85 financial year, or will the Minister be closely monitoring the situation to ensure that the recovery continues unabated?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —As Senator Foreman says, the report of the Indicative Planning Council for the Housing Industry confirms earlier indications that the recovery in the housing industry is well under way. The forecast housing commencements in 1983-84 are 30 per cent above the 20-year low that we had last year of 105,000 commencements, that is, there are 135,000 commencements this year. South Australia, as Senator Foreman will be pleased to know, features prominently in this recovery. The 1983-84 forecast of commencements in South Australia is 11, 500 which is, in fact, 40 per cent over 1982-83. This is the highest level of commencements in South Australia since 1976-77. The report attributes this recovery to increased availability and reduced cost of housing finance, consumer confidence in economic recovery and the continued success of the first home ownership scheme.

ANSWER.PARA: Senator Foreman asked me about the availability of resources in South Australia to maintain this recovery. The Council states that in South Australia the labour market is still in an oversupply situation and, in view of the forecast commencements, no major problems can be foreseen for the period under review. Reserve stocks of land have gradually been reduced but are currently considered adequate. However, the Council considers that increased subdivision activity is desirable. It does not consider that there are any constraints on material supplies. However, I can assure honourable senators that the Government is concerned to ensure that recovery is not affected by resource constraints. The Minister for Housing and Construction has informed me that he has instructed his Department to monitor the situation not only in South Australia but also nationally. He has asked the Council to prepare a report on the industry capacity. He has also arranged a meeting in late April with representatives of State and local governments, industry groups, financial institutions, the trade union movement and housing consumers to discuss housing policy issues prior to the Budget and the Premiers Conference. I can assure the chamber that the Government's housing policies for 1984-85 will be developed in close consultation with all relevant groups and all sections of the industry.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: MacGibbon Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Did the Minister representing the Prime Minister see today's article in the news analysis section of the Australian Financial Review on Australian beef sales to Japan, the latest in a long line of reports of losses of overseas market shares for Australian primary products since this Government came to power? I refer to the following paragraph in that article:

QUESTION.PARA: However, the debate in Tokyo last week left no doubt at all that Australia has completely dropped out of the Japan-US political beef slugging match.
Why was the Cabinet decision taken not to fight for Australia's meat exports, or are all our diplomatic energies spent in cosying up to Vietnam?

TALK.START.PARA: —I did not see the report referred to by Senator MacGibbon. There was no Cabinet decision, in Senator MacGibbon's terms, not to pursue beef sales to Japan. No time is being spent by the Cabinet in, as he put it, cosying up to Vietnam. The question is, in a sense, offensively couched in that it is based on inaccuracies in all the matters to which I have referred and on the other matter of continuing declining sales of primary produce overseas since this Government came to power.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —On Friday of last week Senator Rae directed a question to me relating to the topic of clearance of so-called noil silk fabrics in Melbourne by Customs. Senator Rae's question related to delays in clearances by Customs because of the necessity of scientific tests of certain material. I am informed that the answer is as follows: Fabrics containing a predominance of wool and containing more than 10 per cent noil silk attract a duty of 2 per cent. There has been a marked increase in imports of fabric from Italy which has been declared to fall within the definition necessary to achieve a rate of duty of 2 per cent.

ANSWER.PARA: As a result of investigations of a number of importers and of analysis of various samples, a widespread system of misdescription of goods has been uncovered in connection with these fabric imports. Fabric described as containing 60 per cent wool has been found to have a wool content as low as 19 per cent. Instead of containing more than 10 per cent silk, fabric has been found to contain only one per cent of silk. Fabric which does not meet the definition of achieving 2 per cent duty attracts at least 45 per cent duty. A significant quantity of fabric has already been seized and action is being take to seize more. Fabric which is regarded as falling within the risk category has been closely monitored to ensure that the correct duty is collected, and there are large quantities of fabric in this suspect category. Since November 1983, 50 shipments have been sampled in Melbourne and 14 have been found to be incorrectly declared, with large sums of additional duty due; and 16 have been correctly declared and released while results are awaited on several other shipments.

The Melbourne Chamber of Commerce was advised by telex on 22 February that Customs would accept analysis of samples by the Australian Wool Testing Authority. This is in addition to analyses by Australian Government Analytical Laboratories in an effort to facilitate clearance by those importers who correctly declare their goods. The earlier paragraphs are of course self- explanatory in a sense, but the last paragraph refers to the point of Senator Rae's question. There are now two sources of testing and the Melbourne Chamber of Commerce was advised on 26 February of their availability. We hope that it will achieve the result of greater expedition, which was apparent in the concern expressed by Senator Rae.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I thank the Minister very much for the expedition with which he obtained that information for me arising from my speech on the adjournment debate last Friday.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —On Friday Senator Peter Rae asked me a question about pre-Budget quotas. In my answer to him I made the point that they were introduced earlier than usual last year. The decision to impose pre-Budget quotas was taken on 18 May. Shortly after that date I, in my capacity as Minister for Industry and Commerce, advised the Prime Minister, the Treasurer and the Minister for Finance of that decision. Prior to the decision of 18 May officers of the Department of Industry and Commerce had been in consultation with officers of the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet, the Department of Finance and the Treasury. The introduction of pre-Budget quotas, as Senator Rae will appreciate, is rather complex. Immediately following such a decision it is necessary for departmental officers to research previous clearance history, determine the basis for quota allocation, input the information into the computer and subsequently print quota instruments. In all, some 45 officers of my Department were involved in the process.

ANSWER.PARA: In the 24 to 48-hour period prior to the introduction of quotas on 22 June it was necessary to brief State control officers and arrange for 310 quota instruments to be delivered to the respective companies immediately after the announcement. In all over 100 officers of my Department, Australia-wide, were involved in this need-to-know process. When the Department became aware of a possible leak of information regarding quotas, consideration was given to the conduct of an investigation. However, the Department decided that in view of the number of departmental officers involved, together with officers in other departments who were aware of the decision to impose the quotas on 22 June, such an investigation would be unlikely to reveal the source of the leak if in fact there was one. The Department advised me of the normal level of clearances on 20 June or 21 June and that it did not propose to conduct an investigation, for the reasons I have previously outlined. I accepted that advice at the time. I made some slightly unfavourable comment about what had happened in a written note to the Department.

It comes as a surprise to me, and I understand also to senior officers of the Department, that a particular person appears to be suspected of leaking the information. If the honourable senator knows as a 'notorious fact'-as he put it on Friday I think-that there is a person who should be under suspicion, I would be grateful if he would make the information available to me so I can give further consideration to that matter.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Gietzelt Sen The Hon A.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —During Question Time Senator Jack Evans asked me a question about coastal surveillance, particularly in the northern part of Australia. I draw his attention to a statement that was put down in the House of Representatives on Friday last perhaps to amplify the reply I gave to the question raised by him.

ANSWER.PARA: In April last year the Minister for Defence and the Minister for Transport jointly requested the Minister for Aviation and Minister Assisting the Minister for Defence, to carry out a review of how our nation's surveillance needs were met. The Prime Minister indicated at that time that a report of the findings and results of that review would be made available to the Parliament. That is what was presented to the House of Representatives on Friday last. Mr Beazley's review concluded, among other things, by stating:

. . . . in view of the responsibilities of the Australian Federal Police for the enforcement of Commonwealth law the co-ordinated surveillance protection organisation should be based on the Australian Federal Police. Accordingly, the Government has decided that a coastal protection unit will be established within the Australian Federal Police with responsibility for directing and co- ordinating overall coastal surveillance response and enforcement. The unit will operate within the Australian Coastal Surveillance Centre and will be a joint user of that centre with the Department of Transport. The Department of Transport will continue to manage the functions of the centre and will retain responsibility for maritime safety, search and rescue and associated functions.

The new arrangements will mean that the Australian Federal Police will be on hand to apprehend offenders when the crimes are detected. Under the old system, offences could only be detected and then reported. The two firms whose contracts will not be renewed after 30 April are the Northern Territory Aerial Works, in Darwin, and the Queensland company Airesearch Pty Ltd. A Western Australian based group, Skywest Airlines Pty Ltd, will be the single contractor. It already has operations in Queensland following its takeover of H. C. Sleigh Aviation Ltd . It will be extending its Queensland operations and also opening up operations in the Northern Territory. As I understand it, in future the responsibility of the Parliament for these operations will be handled by the Special Minister of State.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: MINISTER FOR TERRITORIES AND LOCAL GOVERNMENT

TALK.START.PARA: —During Question Time Senator Reid asked me a question for which I was not immediately able to provide the answer. I have subsequently been advised that the policy has operated for many years, having been varied from time to time, of providing members of parliament with an entitlement to public housing. Ministers have always been entitled to an allocation, and still are. The policy has been confirmed by successive governments and the present policy is unchanged from that applied by the previous Government. Several Ministers of the past, including members of the Liberal-National Party Government, have taken advantage of the policy and lived in public housing while members of parliament. No housing policy has been changed by the present Minister for Territories and Local Government in such a way as to advantage himself. The flat in question was allocated to the Minister in accordance with the policy when he was a Minister in the previous Government in 1973. He still occupies that residence, in 1984, and at all times the full set rent for the property has been paid.

DEBATE.TITLE: REORGANISED PORTFOLIO RESPONSIBILITIES IN ABORIGINAL AFFAIRS

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the paper.

I do not wish to talk about the particular administrative rearrangements the Government has proposed for Aboriginal affairs. That is a matter for the Government and it is its right to organise affairs as it thinks appropriate. I do not want to let this opportunity pass without drawing attention to a couple of notable matters contained in the announcement. The first is the fact that Mr Charles Perkins has been appointed Secretary to the Department of Aboriginal Affairs. He is the first Aboriginal Australian to reach the top rank of the Commonwealth Public Service. This is a record which only Charles Perkins can hold-it can never be equalled or approached; there can be no other first person to share it with him. It is a notable achievement by Mr Perkins and I put on record my own view that this is something for which he deserves congratulations from within the Parliament.

Over the years I have had a varied relationship with Charlie Perkins, starting off at Sydney University when he went there in the mid-1960s as the first Aboriginal student at that institution to take an undergraduate degree, then watching his career over the years and finally when we worked together when I was Minister for Aboriginal Affairs. I think it is fair to say that we have always had a good relationship, though it was not always a tranquil one. It is also fair to say that as a Minister it was my duty on occasions to disagree forcefully with Charles and for him to disagree with me. We had some quite interesting discussions. It was also my function to protect him during some of the controversies that erupted during that time when he was trying to play the dual role of head of a statutory corporation and Aboriginal politician. He found himself in the very difficult situation of having a foot in two worlds, with responsibilities devolving upon him because of his Aboriginality and other responsibilities devolving upon him because of his role as an officer of the Public Service or as the head of a statutory corporaton.

I would therefore like to say that there now falls upon Charles Perkins a very special challenge and responsibility because as a permanent head he can no longer have the freedom which he did have in the past to comment publicly on matters about which he feels passionately and on which he wishes to have his views known. I wish him well in his new job. I think it will be a new set of constraints as well as a new set of opportunities. While we congratulate him, we will watch his progress with interest.

I also note that Miss Lois O'Donoghue will be taking on some new responsibilities under the re-organisation. This remarkable Australian also deserves the commendation of all Australians and all members of the Parliament.

TALK.START.PARA: —What position does she have?

—She has been the Chairman of Aboriginal Hostels Ltd. She will be taking on a role with the new housing organisation. I first met Lois O' Donoghue when she was acting regional director of the Department of Aboriginal Affairs. I made a trip to Oodnadatta with a Senate committee which included former Senators Keeffe, Bonner and Davidson. It was quite a remarkable trip as we seemed to raise considerable ire in Oodnadatta. We thought we were going to be run out at one stage. At that stage Lois O'Donoughue was doing a very important job with the Department of Aboriginal Affairs. She, too, was straddling two worlds in quite a remarkable way. As I remember, her mother at that stage was living in the town camp outside Oodnadatta. Lois found time to visit her family and to look after the senators as she went through. Since then she has been Chairman of the National Aboriginal Conference, Chairman of Aboriginal Hostels Ltd and has served as a commissioner on the Aboriginal Development Commission. She now takes over this new task which involves the bringing together of several housing responsibilities. Her appointment to this job is one more recognition of the singular contribution which Lois O'Donoghue has made to Australia and to Aboriginal development in particular. The fact that she has been honoured both by way of traditional honours and with the Order of Australia is an example of the kind of recognition that the community would wish to give her. I take this opportunity to put on record my appreciation of what these two people have done and my hope that they will continue to contribute in the same way.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Teague Sen B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I concur fully with what my colleague Senator Peter Baume said in respect of Charles Perkins and Lois O'Donoghue. They are remarkable Australians. Irrespective of controversies which have arisen in the past they have conscientiously followed through their interests in the development of the best interests of Aboriginal communities in Australia. Both sides of this Parliament would accept these new appointments and give their personal congratulations to Charles Perkins and Lois O'Donoghue in their new responsibilities.

SPEECH.PARA: I have had dealings with both persons over many years, first with Charles Perkins when we were undergraduate students, he at the University of Sydney and I at the University of Adelaide. We were involved with the Aboriginal scholarship scheme for university entry. In the last six years that I have been a member of the Senate it has been a pleasure to see the way that they continued to contribute on behalf not only of the Aboriginal communities in every part of Australia, but in conscientiously seeing themselves as a part of Australia as a whole, as Australian citizens. It was a pleasure for my wife and me, only last weekend, to visit briefly the Lois O'Donoghue Hostel in Port Augusta. It is a new, very attractive and efficient hostel for Aboriginal travellers in that important part of my State. It is very appropriately and boldly named the Lois O 'Donoghue Hostel.

Both Charles Perkins and Lois O'Donoghue spent considerable parts of their early lives in South Australia. They knew each other as children and as teenagers in that they suffered the same dubious honour of having been taken away from their families under the old, and gladly superseded, protectionist procedures. Without any ability to disagree, they were taken from their families to homes in Adelaide where they received pastoral care, encouragement and the knowledge and learning which put them in a position to apply themselves on behalf of the Aboriginal communities of Australia today. Whatever the mixed blessings of those difficult years that were in part shared by Charles Perkins and Lois O'Donoghue, they remain two of the most outstanding leaders of the Aboriginal people. Whilst in noting these rearrangements we do not hold back from discussing, arguing about and disagreeing with Government policies that are executed, we do note the high honour accorded to those taking up these new appointments and we genuinely wish them well.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Rae Sen P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I join with my colleagues Senator Baume and Senator Teague in welcoming and congratulating Charlie Perkins and Lois O' Donoghue on their appointments. I first came to know Charlie Perkins at a later stage, in particular when I was shadow Minister for Aboriginal Affairs in the period when we were in opposition in the earlier part of the 1970s. I formed then and continue to hold a very high opinion of both his capacity and the sensitivity with which he has fulfilled the very peculiar role which he has had. As Senator Baume said, his role has been very difficult in that it involved both moving up through, and carrying out an important function in, the Australian Public Service as well as, of necessity, being involved in a degree of Aboriginal politics. That is an area of politics in which radicalism and very strong feelings have been engendered by some of the history and past experiences of the people involved.

SPEECH.PARA: I have found Charles Perkins one of the truly great people in his ability to walk the tightrope of satisfying the demand for action on the part of people who in other countries have become revolutionaries. Along with former Senator Neville Bonner who, I think, is in the precincts of the House today, he has played an extremely important part in the reconciliation of the legitimate demand that Australian Aboriginal people obtain a more equitable place in Australian society and the Australian economy. They have been able to see that happen without the trouble which has been experienced in some other countries and without the degree of extremism which has been experienced in other countries. I believe that we owe a lot to people such as Neville Bonner, Charles Perkins, Lois O'Donoghue and others who have been able at the one time to be outspoken without being revolutionary.
