SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think the Government's rearrangements in relation to the Aboriginal Affairs Department are generally welcomed by all. I would particularly like to congratulate the Government for the moves it has made in making more places available in the Department for Aboriginals, not only at senior level, but also throughout the Department, thus enabling them to have a greater say in what goes on. Charles Perkins is well known throughout the Aboriginal community and Australia. That is not to say-I imagine any senator here who knows that area well would agree-that he is totally accepted by all people within the Aboriginal community or that his views are in accord with those of everybody in the Aboriginal community. I think that it is a welcomed fact among the Aboriginal community in Australia, in terms of the growth of its political awareness, that there are varying shades of opinion and there is much contention on issues. I believe these political movements within the community are to be welcomed. There are varying shades of view and discussions are conducted in a vigorous and often very heated manner. In many ways that is part of the Aboriginal people having moved into the centre area in controlling their own lives and destinies.

SPEECH.PARA: Now the Aborigines have, as the prime departmental adviser to the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs (Mr Holding), a member of their own race. That is an important role but we should always bear in mind that he will tender one view-an important view but nevertheless it is one view-to the Government. The Government will receive a variety of other views, namely through the National Aboriginal Conference, that will often express an alternative position. In the contention of those various positions I believe there will be general advancement. I think that the Government should be congratulated for making a move which has not been made before. That move has been extensive throughout the Department of Aboriginal Affairs. I hope there will be a continuation of that move.

I believe that the Minister could well dissolve his Department of Aboriginal Affairs and turn it into a secretariat for the National Aboriginal Conference. That is probably a move that governments are not likely to take for some time, but hopefully eventually they will. If that did occur our procedures would be very similar to the procedures which currently govern the development of policy in the United States system. In time to come that development of policy will become far less contentious than it is today; many of the issues which are on the political agenda will have disappeared and it will be merely an ongoing proposition with very much less heat than there is today in the policy area of Aboriginal affairs.

I believe it is appropriate that there should be this appointment to the head of a department when the Government has before the Senate and the House of Representatives a very comprehensive motion on the whole issue and indeed has made an announcement that there will be national uniform legislation in this area. I think that when those issues arrive undoubtedly there will be further contention within the wider community as Australians discuss an issue that has been with us for a long period. Hopefully, at that time the Government will be able to rely on the new permanent head for advice which comes not only from his Department but also from the very wide and extensive contacts that the head of the Department has in the Aboriginal community. I believe this is a very useful and good step forward. We wish both Lois O'Donoghue and Charles Perkins well in their new positions. Presumably this will be the last time we will hear about them in this place because, as departmental people, they will be now in a non- contentious area. However, I doubt that very much. Because of the type of people they are I believe they will be mentioned in here from time to time. I think that will be useful.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kilgariff Sen B.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I note the statement made by the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs, Mr Clyde Holding, regarding the considerable changes that have occurred which are designed to put authority and responsibility into Aboriginal hands. I congratulate Charlie Perkins on the fact that he is now the first person of Aboriginal descent to become permanent head of the Department of Aboriginal Affairs. I have known Charlie all his life, and his family in Alice Springs. Over the years Charlie has gone ahead from milestone to milestone to arrive at his present position. I know that in the challenge ahead of him-there will be a considerable challenge-he will be ably assisted by his wife, who will give him tremendous support.

SPEECH.PARA: I speak of challenge. I believe that Charlie Perkins has a very difficult job ahead of him. I hope that now he is the departmental head of the Department of Aboriginal Affairs he will bring about a continuing review of assistance in all matters relating to Aboriginality. The challenge is tremendous. The many Aboriginals who were born in the bush, who live there and who no doubt will die there, are still the have-nots. At times I wonder, when I consider the vast amount of money that is spent on Aboriginal affairs, whether sufficient money reaches the people of the bush. A vast number of organisations have developed within Aboriginality. Many staff are employed within those organisations. Sometimes I feel there are too many chiefs and few Indians. The point I make is that-I say this as a challenge to Charlie Perkins-a continuing review of expenditure in matters relating to Aboriginals is necessary. He may find there are many actions that he can take to ensure that the people whom I have described-those on the bottom rung-will receive more benefit than they receive now, and in some places, whether they be cities or towns, there are the haves and the have-nots. I look to Charlie Perkins to accept that challenge. There is another challenge which I believe he will pick up. I was quite interested in the remarks of the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs when, in the last page of his statement, he said:

This Government stands for reconciliation. The reconciliation will not be achieved until there is a recognition by both Aboriginal and non-Aboriginal of the worth of each other in a multicultural society where each has an important role to play and a contribution to make.

I support the Minister very strongly in those remarks. I commend him for seeing, in the arrangements that he has brought about, that this will happen. I also challenge Charlie Perkins to be the bridge in many instances in the territory and the outback between white and black to bring about better relations. I could go on at length about that, but time is against me.

I wish to speak very briefly about Lois O'Donoghue, who is a most delightful and capable person. In her years of service to Aboriginal Hostels Ltd she made a remarkable effort on behalf of the people who have been housed by that organisation. Honourable senators may remember that last Thursday I spoke on the report that Lois O'Donoghue produced, the 1982-83 report on Aboriginal Hostels Ltd. I know that in the future vast demands will be made on her regarding the creation of the new Aboriginal Housing Authority, which I support. I think that if anyone has the ability to carry out the job, it is Lois O'Donoghue. I congratulate her on the distinction of being the first person, an Aboriginal woman, to be in charge of the new Aboriginal Housing Authority. I know that if anyone can make a success of this new organisation-it has to be success-that person is Lois O'Donoghue.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not wish to extend greatly the debate that has perhaps gone on longer than the Government expected in any event, but there are a couple of things I wish to say in support of what has been said by my Opposition colleagues. Firstly, I refer to the appointment of Mr Charles Perkins. I extend my congratulations to Mr Perkins. I have had a great deal to do with him. He was the Deputy Secretary of the Department of Aboriginal Affairs when I was the Minister. Whilst I was the Minister he was appointed to the Aboriginal Development Commission as its Chairman. The Fraser Government put a great deal of responsibility on to Charles Perkins and gave him the most significant role that I think had ever been given to an Aboriginal person in government. Now that he has been made the Secretary, the head of the Department of Aboriginal Affairs, he has, as Senator Baume put it, achieved something which can never be matched by anybody else. He has been a first in his field and that can never be taken from him.

SPEECH.PARA: In extending my personal good wishes to him, I say that he will have to face two substantial hurdles in carrying out his task. One is a hurdle which is common to anyone working in an Aboriginal organisation, and that is to represent all the interests of Aboriginals. Certainly my own experience has been that in that community, as in any community, there are factions and different interest groups. I believe it will require enormous wisdom on the part of Mr Perkins to represent all the differing Aboriginal interests that he has to represent as Secretary to the Department. I wish him well in that endeavour. I believe it will be an enormous challenge for him, as it would be for anyone else. Also, he will face the very great challenge of representing the public interest in a broader sense. Mr Perkins has always been a radical. He said so himself on the weekend. The new role given to him by the Government will require him to see very clearly the community interests as well as the interests of the Aboriginal people of Australia. I wish him well in facing the very real challenges in both those areas.

So far as Mrs O'Donoghue is concerned, I can only say that I have not met a more delightful person of any race, colour or creed. I believe that she has an enormous reservoir of goodwill among all those who have ever dealt with her. I simply join with other honourable senators in saying that I have great confidence in her. I hope she gets great satisfaction from the significant tasks that the Government has given her to carry out in addition to those that she already holds. Lastly, I acknowledge the work of John Taylor. I do not think that any bureaucrat, be he Aboriginal or non-Aboriginal, regards the appointment as Secretary to the Department of Aboriginal Affairs as an appointment to an easy post. Mr Taylor, who served in that position for some years, is to be thanked for his application to the task and for the fact that he took on that task in what was, I am sure, a sideways move rather than a promotional one. I wish him well in his new job in New York. John Taylor is one of a line of distinguished public servants who have headed the Department. I refer also to Mr Tony Ayers, the present head of the Department of Social Security, and Sir David Hay, now retired. All those people have served the Aboriginal people well in that capacity. On behalf of the Opposition, I thank John Taylor for his work as Secretary to the Department of Aboriginal Affairs.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I commend the two appointments and I wish the appointees well and every success in their journeys. I do that primarily because it was my pleasure to come to know Charles Perkins during the four years that I was privileged to hold the education portfolio in the Federal Parliament. At the time I held that portfolio it included responsibility for education in the Northern Territory. That meant that I was responsible for the education not only of non-Aboriginal Australians in the Northern Territory but also for Aborigines wherever they may have been in the Territory. In carrying out that responsibility I found that there was an immense amount to learn, an immense amount of understanding to be gained. I have said in the Senate previously that at the end of four years I had fewer answers than I had at the start, but certainly I knew more about the questions to be posed and the probing to be done. That is the adventure all education Ministers face. I note that the Government Whip, Senator Robertson, acknowledges that. I think we are bipartisan in our attitudes to this immense problems.

SPEECH.PARA: Charles Perkins, as permanent head of the Department of Aboriginal Affairs-and uniquely so, as Senator Peter Baume and other honourable senators have said- faces problems more complex, diverse and unorthodox than any other permanent head because he must endeavour to interpret to the Government and the people of Australia, in full sympathy and wisdom, the needs and aspirations, the hopes and fears of a people whose cultures, far from being primitive, have been deep, complex, and far different from the structures of cultures in which we have walked. No other permanent head confronts that difficulty. Charles Perkins is, as he describes himself, an Alice Springs boy. He has made a very great journey. PROCTEXT.PARA: Motion (by Senator Macklin) agreed to:

That leave be given to introduce a Bill for an Act to alter the Constitution so as to ensure that the Members of the House of Representatives and of the Parliaments of the States are chosen directly and democratically by the people.
Bill presented by Senator Macklin, and read a first time.
Standing Orders suspended.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.
I seek leave to have my second reading speech incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The speech read as follows-

This is the second time that a Bill with this title has been introduced to this Parliament. The first time was on the 8th November 1973, when the then Prime Minister, Mr Whitlam, introduced a Bill which was substantially the same as the Bill before us today. The introduction of that Bill was the implementation of a promise made by Mr Whitlam on behalf of the Australian Government at the Australian Constitutional Convention held in Sydney in September of that year. The Bill had the aim, as indeed this one does, of writing into the Constitution the principle of substantial equality of electoral divisions for all the Parliaments of Australia, that is, one person, one vote of equal value to every other vote. The then Opposition, under the leadership of Mr Snedden, opposed the Bill, basically, it appears to me, because it felt that the stated principle was not being implemented by Mr Whitlam's Bill. The Opposition argued, quite correctly I believe, that by making electorates equal in the sense that they were to have an equal number of people in them, would not give votes equal value .

The argument advanced by some people, especially city members of the House of Representatives, is that from a work load point of view, these members still have to represent people who are not registered to vote and consequently should be allowed to have them counted in the numbers. From my point of view, this is going about things the wrong way around. Indeed, I believe that we would be far better off encouraging these people to become Australian citizens, if they are not already, and to register to vote.
Constitution Alteration (Democratic Elections) Bill

Given the strong feeling exhibited in 1973 about whether electorates should be divided on the basis of electors or people, I thought it best to wait until the Electoral Legislation Amendment Bill had passed through Parliament before raising the matter again. I had thought that we might well see a debate at that time on whether electorates should continue to be divided along current lines- that is, number of electors-or whether the Government would take up the Whitlam proposal again and attempt to divide electorates along the lines of numbers of people in them. No debate arose, and I take heart from that, that the present Labor Government is quite happy to accept what I take to be the Opposition line, that things remain the way they are. As a result of this I have amended Mr Whitlam's original Bill so that the numbers ascertained in respect of Divisions shall be, as nearly as practicable, the same in respect of the numbers of electors rather than the numbers of people in each electorate. This concept I believe should now have the support of the vast majority of senators and members in this Parliament. Although it is a principle which appears to have the almost complete support of Federal parliamentarians, and indeed the people of Australia , it is a principle which is obviously not supported by all parliamentarians at the State level.

I believe that the time has come for the people of the States to have their say on whether or not their current situations should be allowed to continue. Unfortunately no State Parliament requires a vote of electors in order to change its own Constitution in this regard. Indeed, not even the Federal Constitution requires that change. But I believe it is time that we enshrined the principle in the Federal Constitution so that future governments are not persuaded to change the principle now established for purely political gain.

There are two other changes which have been made to Mr Whitlam's original Bill which I will mention briefly here. The first of these is a purely technical one to rectify an inconsistency in Mr Whitlam's wording of section 5 and section 7 of the Bill. I do not believe that this change will have any effect on the implementation of the Bill if it is adopted. The second change is to allow parliaments to decide to grant the right to vote to people under the age of 18 if they so desire. This change may be more controversial. My reason for incorporating this change is quite simple. Given the difficulties in making amendments to the Constitution, I do not believe that we should enshrine the 18- year-old age limit for voting into the Constitution, as the time may well come- even if it is 20 or 30 years away-or even more, that we may wish to give 17 or even 16 year-olds the vote. This issue was raised in particular relation to 17- year-olds being conscripted to fight in Vietnam even though they did not have the vote. I believe personally that this was going too far. It is one thing to force 6 to 15-year-olds to go to school, whether or not it is one of their own choosing, but it is quite a different matter to ask a 17-year-old to fight in a war which he or she might wish to oppose by voting for a political party which opposed such a war if he or she were entitled to vote. A vote of 17-year-olds might well have made the difference in 1969 as to who governed this country and as to whether or not this country continued to conscript people to go to Vietnam .

When this Bill was last raised in Parliament the question was raised by Senator Little as to whether the Bill would allow proportional representation and whether or not the government of the day supported that proposal. Unfortunately the Government did not, as it still does not; but the Bill does allow for that type of system to exist, as it already does in Tasmania. As I said in my second reading speech on the Commonwealth Electoral Legislation Amendment Bill, I believe that the fact that proportional representation for the House of Representatives was missing from that Bill, effectively means that the Bill did not really grapple with the last major task of reform in the electoral process. I believe that is a bitter disappointment to many people in the community who feel that that is a necessary move that we must take. I hope that in the future it will be seen to be a necessary reform and that eventually it will be taken. The acceptance of this Bill will certainly do nothing to hinder that development .

As my colleague, Senator Jack Evans, said in his second reading speech on the aforementioned Bill, the omission of proportional representation means that Australia continues with the very lopsided, winner takes all system of having governments elected. 'Winner takes all' follows automatically from a system under which there is a single candidate elected for an electorate and a candidate has to attract only 50 per cent of the vote plus one to win. There is no justice and no fairness in that kind of system. I think most people in Australia are now aware that the newer countries which have been formed since this country was federated and since we have had the single member electorate imposed on us from the turn of the century, have opted for proportional representation. Honourable senators may wish to look back over this part of Senator Evans' speech which can be found on pages 3058 and 3059 of the Hansard for 30 November 1983.

Before concluding I draw honourable Senators' attention to two other provisions in the Bill. Section 25 of the Constitution provides that if by the law of any State persons of any race are disqualified from voting at elections for the more numerous House of the State, then in reckoning the number of people of the State or of the Commonwealth, persons of that race resident in that State shall not be counted. This is an archaic and objectionable provision. It is not within the spirit of the wishes of any political party in this place, and the Bill provides for the repeal of that section. By these measures I believe we will add much to the durability of our parliamentary systems, and remove injustices which have lived too long. I also draw the Senate's attention to a further provision in the Bill. It is designed to ensure that cases can be brought before the High Court in relation to matters arising in the electoral provisions of State or Australian law. The way in which this is done is to include a new section of the Constitution that will permit an elector of the Commonwealth to bring a relevant matter before the High Court, and an elector in a State to raise a matter relating to that State. I commend the Bill to the Senate.
Debate (on motion by Senator Robertson) ajourned.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Health Insurance Amendment Bill 1984 (No. 2) represents a further stage in the current dispute between the Government and members of the medical profession in Australia. The Bill is belated and partial recognition by the Government that one section of the Government's arrangements, namely, section 17 of the Health Insurance Act, is not fair and in its current form is unacceptable. In addition, it contains provisions which can give approval to existing contracts even where doctors do not wish to sign new contracts under Medicare. This may be a manoeuvre designed to bring some doctors into the scheme irrespective of whether or not they want it or whether or not they know it.

SPEECH.PARA: As it currently stands, the now notorious section 17 gives to the Federal Minister for Health (Dr Blewett) the unfettered power to determine the acceptability of contracts between doctors and hospitals without any provision for oversight, arbitration or appeal by those who are affected by the contracts. It is this provision which has resulted in quite unprecedented industrial action and the threat of industrial action by doctors. Never before in the history of the medical profession in Australia has such a step been taken. Equally, never before in Australia has there been such an intrusion into the professional and personal operation of the practice of medicine.

The situation that now exists is at least partly due to the Government's refusal last September to accept what it now offers by way of compromise. I remind the Senate that last September the Opposition in this place put forward an amendment to the enabling legislation which would have allowed for parliamentary scrutiny of any guidelines gazetted by the Minister. When that was being debated in the Senate, what did Senator Grimes have to say? On that occasion Senator Grimes described my amendment-it was my amendment-as 'an unnecessary impediment'. The Government did not support the amendment. The amendment now comes to the Senate under the auspices of that same Government. But it is no longer an 'unnecessary impediment'; it is now presented to us as a constructive proposal. I can only assume that the Government finds that it is wiser now than it was last September. This is a demonstration of political expediency but it comes at a time when circumstances have changed markedly from those that applied last year.

The Bill before us was debated in the other place on Thursday night of last week, 29 March. Anyone who wishes to can read that debate and see the contributions by the Government members. They will see that, with the exception of the speech of the honourable member for Eden-Monaro, Mr Snow, contributions by other Government members represent an all-out attack on doctors and the medical profession by those who spoke in the debate on behalf of the Government. As I have said, I exclude one member. The debate last Thursday went far beyond the provisions of the Bill. It misrepresented the issues. It misrepresented the effect on the operation of Medicare of opposition from the doctors. The misrepresentation that went on was not only in the House of Representatives. I remind honourable senators of what is contained in the Senate Hansard of last Wednesday when Senator Sibraa asked a question. I refer honourable senators to that question on page 785. It was a question that misrepresented circumstances in Canberra. Senator Sibraa's question was:

My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Minister for Health. Is the Minister aware-I am sure he is after Senator Button's statement-that Senator Georges, after falling in the parliamentary building and apparently breaking some of his ribs, was refused X-ray treatment at the Royal Canberra Hospital last night because of industrial action being taken by radiologists? . . .

The fact is that Senator Georges was not refused X-ray treatment. The situation is that the circumstances applying in the Royal Canberra Hospital last week were exactly those that always apply. They were not the result of any industrial action. I phoned the superintendent of the hospital to check the facts and received his personal assurance that there was no industrial action. What we have here is just part of a pattern which is misrepresenting the position of doctors, misrepresenting the circumstances in the community and misrepresenting the effects which the current dispute has on Medicare.

Why has the Government picked on doctors? It is a fact that most doctors oppose Australian Labor Party policy. Most doctors are individual entrepreneurs in a society where that is apparently unfashionable with this Government. Most doctors oppose the nationalisation by this Government of health insurance. Most doctors are determined to fight for decent contract conditions for themselves under Medicare if they are to operate in the hospitals. They are regarded by some of the speakers last week as tall poppies. Any reading of the speeches that were made in the other place will reveal outright class hatred and hatred of doctors as a class of people.

One might ask why Government members have pushed this argument so hard and why they are trying to force doctors to accept the contracts offered to them. The reason is that the Australian Constitution contains words designed to prevent the direct nationalisation of medical practice. If this is prevented directly by the Constitution, what is being sought by our political opponents are ways of doing it indirectly. The Constitution says that there shall be no civil conscription of doctors. Of course, since Commonwealth law overrides State law, it is likely that there can be no civil conscription of doctors at State level either. But Medicare has caused a confrontation and has provided a convenient basis for the socialist Left to attack the profession, to attack the doctors and to attack the way they operate and what they stand for.

The centre of the argument from the Government has been that the doctors' intransigence or opposition will affect Medicare and its cost. Let us put that furphy to rest. Medicare benefits are fixed. Medicare benefits are 85 per cent of the schedule fee. It would not matter if I charged a patient a million dollars for some procedure. The fact is that a doctor can draw as a Medicare benefit only 85 per cent of the schedule fee. While ever those fees are contained in the schedule, the amount which goes out under Medicare is fixed. Whether the doctors charge the schedule fee, below the schedule fee or above the schedule fee, the Medicare benefit is fixed at 85 per cent of the schedule fee. In that case, how is it that the payout of benefits can rise? How can it rise, even if the fee rises? Of course, most doctors charge the schedule fee.

I was indebted to my colleague the honourable member for Mackellar, Mr Carlton, in the other place last week when he drew attention to Press statements by the Minister for Health in South Australia, Dr Cornwall, who said that he had looked at diagnostic specialists in that State, that they were all already charging the schedule fee or less and that he was perfectly happy with the contracts that they had signed. Those doctors and the doctors in Victoria and New South Wales are in fact complying as a matter of good practice with the kinds of conditions which are being sought by this Government. However, I come back to the fact that details in those contracts will not affect the payments, the outgoings, under Medicare. The only conceivable way that the costs under Medicare could go up, if the doctor were charging a bit more, is if the little extra increments for each service for any patient added up in the end to something more than $150 in one year. Only in that circumstance would the Government have to pick up the whole schedule fee as its benefits.

Of course, other ways in which payments could vary under Medicare include if the Government had a hidden agenda; if the Government intended to vary the schedule fees down and then required doctors under the terms of contract to lower what they claim; if the Government intended in some way through a hidden agenda to make bulk billing compulsory at a later date and then required doctors , as a basis of participation, to become bulk billing practitioners; or if at a later date moves were made by this Government to limit the delivery of services. Unless those things happen, and the Government has given no indication that they will, there can be no significant effect at all upon Medicare costs while this argument rages. It is absolute nonsense for the Government to argue that it must win this battle to control the cost of Medicare in the interests of the Australian people. It is simply not correct to put this argument because the benefits to be paid out are equal to 85 per cent of the schedule fee in any circumstance and that will continue whether or not the doctors are charging one fee or another fee.

One of the tragedies of this whole debate is the fact that the Government seems to have lost sight of the fact that society, the community, needs doctors. Of course, Medicare needs the doctors. Medicare cannot operate without them. No Minister for Health in Australia can ever deliver the services to people under Medicare. No bureaucrat can deliver the health services. No State Minister or State official can deliver the services. No hospital bureaucrat or administrator can deliver the health services. The only people who can deliver them are health personnel who relate to individual patients. They are the people who will deliver under Medicare the individual services which really, in the end, are what the Government is out to see delivered. Among those health personnel, of course, are doctors. In fact, they provide most of the essential services which Medicare will cover. The system will not operate unless the doctors agree to be part of it. The system cannot operate unless the doctors can be part of Medicare and can feel that they are being treated honourably and honestly in going into the arrangement.

We have an extraordinary situation in that the Australian Labor Party failed to deal and come to any agreement with the doctors, with those whom it expects to provide the services, before it introduced its scheme. This, of course, is an example of stunning incompetence by the Australian Labor Party and the Minister. It shows an arrogant disregard for the putting into place of proper arrangements in relation to this scheme. If Medicare is to be delivered by the medical profession, the Government should have sat down and worked out some adequate arrangements before it put the legislative framework into place. That it did not do so makes the current conflict its own fault.

Of course, the Government has now come back through the Press and through its Ministers to try to force a profession to accept what is unacceptable, to sign contracts which are unacceptable and to do things which that profession will not do. I might say that I have noticed today that as a result of discussions which have taken place, the Australian Medical Association and the Minister for Health hope that the Penington Inquiry into Rights of Private Practice in Public Hospitals might come up with some satisfactory compromise arrangement. We would be delighted if that could be the outcome. We would be delighted if arrangements could be made which would meet the essential needs of the medical profession to be treated decently in this matter.

The Government does not want to forget that hospital practice is only one option. There are many other options open to doctors who are anxious to serve the public. Never forget that doctors such as radiologists and pathologists would be much better off financially if they left the hospitals and went into private practice. Some of my colleagues, and I am a doctor, who decided to go into hospital radiology practice did so in the full knowledge that they would be earning much less money, that they would be trading off certain professional satisfaction which hospital service would give them against the income they could earn if they went into private practice using their skills. The Government needs these specialists to make its scheme work. The Government needs radiologists in its hospitals working under Medicare. It needs pathologists in its hospitals working under Medicare. It will ignore that fact at its peril. Unless it can find a way for them to be able to sign contracts which they feel are acceptable they will withdraw and go to private practice. They will say to the Government: 'Run your own hospital system as you can'. They will still give service to the public without civil conscription and without bowing to the demands of any particular government.

What about the doctors who were attacked so much last week in the House of Representatives? The medical profession is still a profession which on survey is held in the highest regard by the Australian public. It is still the first career choice of the very best intellectual talent from our schools. But it is a profession in which people do not begin to earn any money at all until they are in their mid-20s. It is a profession in which most members extend their study life-long. They continue to study each week and throughout their lives to keep themselves up with current information. They undertake extensive continuing education, sometimes intensive, to acquire extra diplomas and degrees in certain specialty areas. It just so happens that last Saturday, just two days ago, I attended a course conducted by the post-graduate committees of medicine of the University of Sydney and the University of New South Wales at which some highly technical information on the subject of immunology was given to bring doctors up to date. Although this was the first fine Saturday in Sydney for weeks and weeks more than 100 doctors paid for the privilege of attending. They gave up their entire day to advance their own knowledge because that is the professionally responsible way to behave.

The doctors who came under attack work for extraordinarily long hours. It is a matter of statistical fact that doctors suffer some of the worst rates for early death, illness, suicide, psychiatric breakdown, drug abuse and marital breakdown . These are some of the penalties they pay.

TALK.START.PARA: —They get better with more money, do they, Senator?

—I am interested to hear Senator Crowley's response. I would not mind coming into my home the kind of income coming into hers. While I live on a senator's salary, her household receives that salary plus a professorial salary. So the honourable senator should not pretend to be a representative of the workers. She will ride, no doubt, to the barricades in her Volvo or whatever .

SPEECH.PARA: I would also like to say that the gross fees which doctors receive, and I am talking about procedural doctors such as radiologists, do not represent their income. It is all very well for politicians, anxious to make a point, to talk about the gross amount of money that may have been taken out in one doctor's name or one other doctor's name. There are two answers to that. First of all, that is the gross money from which equipment has to be purchased and staff have to be paid; it does not represent the income. Secondly, in hospitals it is not infrequent for all the bills to be sent out in one name on behalf of a number of doctors. Unless one is certain that the bills going out relate to a doctor's services, one can in fact mislead people either intentionally or unintentionally by using one doctor's name and one amount and assuming it is income that person has received.

We are very concerned when Dr Blewett says that his Government has made every effort to be reasonable. How reasonable was it when the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke ), that champion of consensus and reconciliation, likened the medical profession to the Builders Labourers Federation? How reasonable are the references to doctors as greedy and elitist when those claims are made by Government members and are there in Hansard for all to see? How reasonable is it when we examine concessions claimed by the Government, only to find that they are not concessions at all? The Opposition welcomes the establishment of the Penington committee to inquire into the areas of dispute, but, in the meantime, Dr Blewett insists that doctors should sign the contracts. The Bill has brought in amendments which, to my mind, will deem them to have signed the contract, even if they were previous contracts. Quite rightly, the doctors are not prepared to lock themselves into a situation which could be rendered unnecessary depending on the kind of report which Professor Penington brings down and subsequent consideration of that report by the Government.

Dr Blewett has since retreated a little and so he should. He says he is perfectly happy to defer the guidelines pending the report by the Penington inquiry but only if the Australian Medical Association promises in advance to accept the recommendations of that inquiry. How can it give that kind of commitment before it knows what the findings will be? If today's news reports indicate that there is some movement towards a compromise we shall be pleased, but until we know the details we have no reason to trust that we are on the right track or to be confident. We think that if the Government were genuine in its desire to be reasonable, it would hold the entire matter of guidelines in abeyance until the Penington report is to hand and until the Government has had a chance to consider that report and make its views known.

The Opposition is concerned because doctors at present will not sign the contracts which have been offered to them. If the State governments say that doctors cannot continue to serve the people without signing those contracts, it will be up to the States to lock doctors out of the hospitals in which they offer services. Tempers at present are high and while the present Bill seeks to give to Parliament a power which we thought it should have from the beginning, and while we will support that part of it-after all, it is our amendment-we believe that the Bill is not sufficient. For that reason the Opposition has gone further and we have a private members Bill which seeks to remove the provisions that have caused all the confrontation. It is confrontation about matters which are not essential to Medicare's operation and which do not relate essentially to the costs of Medicare. The provisions are nothing to do with the Government's desire to have a nationalised health insurance system. They do have to do with the Government's desire to control the medical profession and to bring it to heel. For these reasons the Opposition believes that the Government amendments do not go far enough. Therefore I now move an amendment to the second reading motion. It states:

Leave out all words after 'That', insert 'the Senate is of the opinion that the Government should take immediate steps to resolve the dispute between the Minister for Health and the doctors by accepting the Health Legislation Amendment Bill 1984 introduced into the Senate by Senator Baume on 28 March 1984 '.
The Opposition will also move some amendments in the Committee stage which may have the result of putting into effect some of the provisions of the private member's Bill to which I referred.

In summary, although section 17 is not essential to Medicare's operation, its continuance in its present form represents a quite unacceptable intrusion into the arrangements in Australia between private doctors and the hospitals within which they work. The Government portrays the Opposition as having an ideological bias against Medicare. We certainly oppose Medicare but it is now the law of the land. We think it could be more properly stated that the Government has an ideological objection against private medical practice in Australia and its present insistence is making that more apparent each day. We want the Government to demonstrate without any further equivocation its commitment to the principle of private medical practice; its recognition of the traditional doctor-patient relationship; its recognition of the fact that most doctors in Australia have operated in ways with which it would agree; and that most hospital contracts have provided for fees to be at or below the scheduled fee. Most hospital contracts have provided already for service charges; most already provide that the income doctors receive is much less than the fee charged.

We want the Government in the interest of the Australian people to withdraw the unnecessary and offensive provisions of section 17 at least while the matter is taken further by the Penington inquiry. We believe that it is only the people of Australia who can lose in the present confrontation. We do not believe that the Government has any mandate to move to bring the medical profession either into compulsory bulk billing or into compulsory adherence to certain fees. The medical profession is there to provide services to the people in a variety of ways. Until the Government can find its way clear to deal honourably and fairly with those it expects to deliver its Medicare scheme, so long will this confrontation continue and so long will the responsibility for that confrontation rest with the Government.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Haines Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Until Senator Peter Baume rose to speak, I was under the distinct impression that the dispute that has been making headlines for the last month or more was about a matter of considerable principle, for which I had great sympathy, and not about money. Senator Baume spent a large amount of the time devoted to his remarks in discussing the reverse point of view-in other words, that this matter was more about money than principle. The newspaper reports of the concerns expressed by the Australian Medical Association over the Medicare legislation as it exists up to today is centred on the fact that the dispute related to a matter of principle under which no other group in the community was being asked to operate. The AMA in all the reports I have seen indicated that the dispute was not about whether private specialists or medical specialists with private patients in public hospitals should charge the schedule fee. Most, I have been assured, do so. Indeed, one specialist in the Australian Capital Territory informed me that the majority of his colleagues charge less than the schedule fee.

SPEECH.PARA: I was informed that the dispute was not about whether these specialists should pay a facilities fee since most diagnostic specialists are already paying such fees, some of them quite high fees. I understood from newspaper reports that it was not a matter of whether doctors should or should not enter into contracts with the public hospitals in which they work, because most already have some sort of contract. I was assured time and again that the dispute related to the fact that under the present system it was possible for the terms and conditions of these medical specialists with private patients in public hospitals to have their contracts unilaterally determined and/or changed by the Minister for Health at any time he or a subsequent Minister saw fit; that there was no right of appeal for all or any of the medical practitioners affected; that there was no parliamentary scrutiny with no requirement for consultation between the Minister and doctors concerned and that these matters added to their concerns.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Haines is quite right.

—I thank Senator Baume for that comment. I was under the impression that the concerns were likely to be assuaged if the legislation was amended so that the Minister did not have these unfettered powers-in other words , so that there was some scrutiny and so that the medical profession or this section of the medical profession was not placed in a position under which no other section of the community would like itself placed under. At the moment we do not have a situation where any unionist, teacher, journalist or business executive is placed in a position where the contract that he begins to work under can be altered by the whim or the decision of any person. It does not exist for anybody else. The AMA seems to make it clear that it simply wants to be treated with the same sort of courtesy.

SPEECH.PARA: This amending Bill brought forward by the Government will therefore ensure that any guideline or guidelines gazetted by the Minister under section 17 of the Health Insurance Act will be regarded as a regulation or regulations. The guideline or guidelines will therefore be subject to disallowance by either House of Parliament within 15 sitting days. I accept the fact that the AMA is concerned that at some time in the future this chamber, as the other, may be in the hands of a political party for which it has no sympathy and which has no sympathy for the medical profession. But that is a long way in the future. I suggest we could get ourselves into a tremendous dither if we sit around worrying about that, no matter what piece of legislation comes before us.

This amendment provides the only meaningful form of appeal possible in a piece of legislation which involves both State and Federal governments, private and salaried medical practitioners, public hospitals and private patients. It has been suggested by some that a review by the Administrative Appeals Tribunal would be a suitable means by which groups of doctors or individual doctors could attain some sort of appeal and change to their condition-

TALK.START.PARA: —I have expert advice that that is not possible.

—I have had the same expert advice, Senator Baume, and I am therefore pleased to say that the statement I made last year, when rejecting your amendment to the original Bill-to refer it, I think, to the AAT-namely, that there were constitutional problems, at that time had some merit.
—You accepted his amendment.
—Indeed we did not.
—Order! These private conversations are interesting but could you direct your remarks through the Chair?

—Certainly, Mr Acting Deputy President. Senator Teague's comment was in fact not accurate. There was a whole assortment of amendments last year but the two we are concerned with related, firstly, to regulatory powers and, secondly, to a right of appeal. The comments I made about doubtful constitutionality, which I used as justification for not supporting Senator Baume's amendment, related to the right of appeal amendment. We too, like Senator Baume, have had advice that an appeal to the AAT is not going to be possible since the Administrative Appeals Tribunal can determine only whether the guidelines laid down have in fact been adhered to. It is not in any position to determine whether the guidelines are nice or nasty; it can determine simply whether the decision of the Minister of Health, taken under the guidelines, is applicable and fair. Of course there are ample precedents for treating as regulations other determinations or guidelines made by a Minister. A number of Acts which have come before this place recently and in the past have made sure that determinations, guidelines, plans of action, programs of action and so on that are in pieces of legislation are given parliamentary scrutiny. Section 58C of the Defence Act 1903, for example, refers to determinations made by a Minister with relation to remuneration, payment of allowances, other pecuniary benefits, long service leave and so on. Those are subject to parliamentary scrutiny and hence to appeal through that mechanism. There are others. Section 10 (2) and (3) of the Environment Protection (Nuclear Codes) Act 1978, section 426 (1) of the Navigation Act 1912 and section 17 (3) of the Broadcasting and Television Act 1942 all provide this form of parliamentary appeal and scrutiny. At no stage in any of the Acts I have just mentioned is reference made to any consultative requirement of the Minister. But I suggest that the comment made by the Minister in his second reading speech is appropriate at this stage. He said:

SPEECH.PARA: I believe that that AMA and other medical groups should accept this Bill as substantially achieving their aims in relation to appeal rights under section 17 . It is obvious that any Federal government would find it impossible to introduce unreasonable quidelines under section 17 because it would require the consent of both Houses of Federal Parliament, and also the agreement of State parliaments to any complementary legislation or regulations made by State governments.

That fits in with a comment I made last week in a matter of public importance relating to this matter; that in fact it would be foolhardy for any Minister to contemplate bringing forward orders, determinations, directions, plans of management, guidelines or whatever without undertaking some form of consultation with the groups concerned. To do so, as the Minister has indicated in his second reading speech, would invite not only controversy but also the almost certain disallowance by one House of Parliament not in the control of the Government.

So in essence the purpose of this Bill is very similar to what I aim to do in the private members Bill which I introduced last week; that is, to ensure that specialists with private patients in a public hospital are not placed in a position which no other group in the community would tolerate. They will no longer be expected to face the prospect of having draconian terms and conditions forced on them or of having their terms and conditions of employment altered by ministerial decree alone at any time in the future.

In addition to removing the present unfettered powers of the Minister-I must say here that the term 'unfettered powers' was used, as I understand it, first by the AMA, and is the problem around which the dispute substantially hinges-the amendment provides for parliamentary scrutiny and debate and would ensure that the Minister undertakes prior consultation with the profession. That this is in fact the primary concern of the medical profession is indicated in a recent letter to all major newspapers which I referred to again last week but which I think bears looking at again, in which the Chairman of the Victorian State Committee of the Australian Association of Surgeons had this to say:
The Basic Problems with Section 17 are:

1. The Federal Minister for Health may, by writing to a doctor, add to or delete from a previous or future agreement between the doctor and his Public Hospital, and thus destroy the contract. No negotiation is entailed.
2. The Minister is not supervised by the Parliament in acting as in 1.
He went on to say:

No self-respecting individual or community group can accept such blatant discrimination against their right to understand and negotiate their conditions of work, and in this we feel we are fighting for all ACTU members, other unions and non unionists, as well as ourselves.
All other issues are peripheral to this perceived threat to the whole medical profession, and indeed the whole community, if the principle of the present legislation is accepted.

Once such loss of the right to participate in determining one's work conditions happens to one group in a community democracy itself is under threat. Even nationalisation of an industry should not destroy such a right.

As I indicated at the beginning of my comments, this expression of opinion by the Chairman of the Victorian State Committee of the Australian Association of Surgeons is one with which I have considerable sympathy. Clearly the amendment to section 17 of the Health Insurance Act, which is before us today, will satisfy both the basic problems that the good doctor mentioned in that letter. It also satisfies the concern expressed with regard to the right of an individual or groups to negotiate their conditions of work. Senator Baume said this is not sufficient. He said it was sufficient last year. Mr Carlton said that if it had been in place last year none of this wrangle would have happened. It is simply not possible to have it both ways.

TALK.START.PARA: —I did not ever say it was sufficient, not last year or any time. I put up extra amendments for you last year. You know that; you just referred to them.

—Indeed, and we supported most of them. The only one we did not as a group support was that concerning the Administrative Appeals Tribunal, and Senator Baume himself has admitted that was constitutionally suspect. Therefore, one would expect that the passage of this amending Bill today will go a long way towards solving the dispute that exists between the AMA and the present Government. I am not quite sure why it will not go the whole way, except that the profession is still clearly concerned about the vexed question of the need for a regular formalised review of the schedule fee. Certainly that is a problem , as Senator Baume indicates.
—Yes.

—However, the brief conversations I have had with members of the profession on this matter indicate that they themselves are unable to agree on what the criteria for the basis of a regular formalised review of the schedule fee should be. At one stage it was suggested to me that even attaching it to the consumer price index might be appropriate. Somebody else suggested that a specific percentage ought to be considered but at the moment the profession is not united on what it sees as the basis for this review. However, that all of us would regard it as a fairly urgent matter for the Government to look into is not in dispute. The Penington inquiry now has responsibility for considering and making recommendations on other areas of concern that have been expressed by the AMA and the Government. Comments in recent days indicate that the report of that committee might solve this whole unfortunate affair. Until the report comes down , however, the passage of this amending Bill seems a reasonable and effective interim measure.

SPEECH.PARA: In closing, I raise the question of the constitutionality of the whole section 17 which has been brought into contention. The only way that can be solved is if section 17 actually remains in the Act and is challenged at High Court level. I point out that, notwithstanding any amendments that are or are not made to the Judiciary Act, constitutional challenges provide for about the only remaining right of appeal to the High Court. So if the AMA believes, as what was then known as the British Medical Association believed in 1949, that it has a just case to challenge section 17 on the grounds that it is civil conscription-I imagine, from the 2:3 majority decision in that case, that it would have good grounds for believing that it could successfully challenge this section-that is the path it should take. In the meantime, passage of this legislation will overcome the problems that the AMA has indicated for some time that it has with the whole Medicare legislation. It will provide parliamenary scrutiny, it will take away the unfettered powers of the Minister for Health and it will encourage consultation between the Minister and the doctors concerned or raise the real risk of disallowance of a regulation far more draconian or even slightly more draconian than the existing situation; that is a situation which most doctors aver occurs one in which most charge the schedule fee or less, most diagnostic specialists pay facilities fees and most of them enter into some form of contract with the hospitals.

As far as Senator Baume's attachment to the second reading motion is concerned- I became aware of it only when he mentioned it during his speech-I suggest that the time and the place for this House to vote for or against a private member's Bill is when such a Bill rises to or is brought to the top of the Notice Paper on its own account. I will not be recommending to my colleagues that we support this attachment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate is debating an amendment to section 17 of the Health Insurance Act which relates to the treatment of private patients by visiting medical officers in public hospitals. Section 17 provides that, unless the visiting medical officer agrees to sign a contract dictated by the Commonwealth Government, the patient shall not be eligible for medical benefits under Medicare. That is the crux of the matter.

SPEECH.PARA: Of course, the problem is unique. Nowhere else can one find these kinds of sanctions. This is the second sanction put on the patient under Medicare. The patient is being used to blackmail the medical profession.

The biggest sanction-one that is intolerable and a complete denial of human rights-is that nobody in Australia under Medicare will have the right to take out private insurance against extra costs. There is absolutely no justification, in human rights terms, for that. It is a provision to bring duress on the medical profession to charge the basic fee and to bulk bill. That is undeniable and Senator Crowley has not denied that at all. Absolutely restricting human rights in order to force a socialist act is ugly and no member of the Hawke Government, least of all the Attorney-General (Senator Gareth Evans) and any others who purport to be defenders of human rights, could come in here and support this action. It is a sanction against the patient.

Now there is a second sanction that if the patient elects to go to a visiting medical officer in a public hospital as a private patient and does not inquire or know that the doctor has not signed the contract forced upon him that patient will not get medical benefits. That is a deliberate attempt to use a sanction against a patient to blackmail a doctor into performing under duress what the Government wants to be performed. So duress is used and, in fact, the patient is the target. Somehow or other this issue is being represented before the public as some kind of disorderly dog fight between the medical profession and the Government, as though the patient is not a part of it and as though the Government is looking to the interests of the patient.

At the outset of any debate on this matter I want to make it perfectly clear that by those two sanctions and this duress, Medicare has very seriously damaged the interests of the patient. This legislation denies the patient the right to privately insure, but it goes further and says to the patient: 'If you are silly enough to elect to go as a private patient to a visiting medical officer in a public hospital and that visiting medical officer has not signed the contract, we will not give you any medical benefits.' What is the morality of this in the name of conscience? The Government is forcing everybody in the community to pay a one per cent tax levy and therefore, by any morality at all, a person ought to get the same benefit from that levy no matter what he elects to do. What right has the Government to exact a tribute from all people and then to say: 'If you do not choose a particular doctor we will punish you'? Is that the kind of socialism we are proud of? Are these the kinds of human rights about which we are proud?

I want to look at the principles involved because very great principles are involved. I reject any idea that this is a kindly government benefiting the patient against a rapacious medical profession. Let us look at section 17. Nowhere in the whole arbitral system in Australia can we find a provision like this. Nowhere is there a provision that enforces a set of conditions upon a person or a group of people without their right, first of all, to prior discussion in the formulation of those provisions and, secondly, to appeal. The Australian Labor Party is strong on talking about arbitral provisions. It is a strong supporter of the arbitration system which is a system based on prior discussion, consensus and the right of appeal. But tragically, in this matter, uniquely the only profession, the only group of people which will be denied this , is the medical profession.

But we can go a step further than that. Whenever, in a dialogue between an interest group and the government, some issue arises and the issue is put to examination by a committee, by appeal or by arbitration, there is an outstanding overriding principle, and that is that the status quo will remain until after that inquiry has been made, that there will be no alteration or enforcement until then and that, the inquiry having concluded, there is still a right of people to argue and debate. Uniquely in this case, the medical profession is being pressed and uniquely the duress of patient inconvenience is being used to squeeze that profession.

There have been some violent expressions of melodramatic language used against the medical profession by the Labor Party and vituperation by Ministers of the Hawke Government. Why? They have said that the medical profession is like the builders labourers. I am something of a student of the Labor Party's platform and policies. I believe that the Labor Party has argued ardently over the years about the right of individuals and individual unions to withhold their services if they believe that they have a genuine dispute. Why then has the Government picked on this group? Certainly, doctors have tremendous responsibilities. But why this group? Let me hear the Government inveighing against the workers on Capital Hill who, for the last month or two, have been denying their services to the people of Australia-

TALK.START.PARA: —To the taxpayers.

—Yes, to the taxpayers of Australia in the building of the new Parliament House. There has been an awesome silence from the Labor Party about that matter. Where then is the intervention by the Labor Party to overcome that dispute? Where then is this consensus? Where then is there any vituperation against those people who are withholding their services?

SPEECH.PARA: It cannot be that in this argument of withholding services the Government is saying: 'We must intervene with the medical profession because so much of the public money goes into medical expenses and into the payment of medical practitioners'. Other professions are even more heavily involved; for example, the legal profession. Has anyone done any investigation into what an average family pays each year on third party and comprehensive insurance and what is paid by way of workers compensation, accident insurance, household insurance and so on-money that is really the backbone of the fees of the legal profession? Tens of millions of dollars a year-perhaps now hundreds of millions in legal aid through the Commonwealth Government-is spent on maintaining the legal profession . Does anyone say that we should regulate the legal profession? Does anyone say that no one lawyer, no matter how skilled he is compared with another, will get any more than the next lawyer? Does anyone say that they are getting much more money than they should? After all, so many of them are getting more than $61,000 that has been referred to by the Government in respect of visiting medical practitioners. So what is this all about?

TALK.START.PARA: —And which profession services the great bulk of the public?

—Yes. I will press on further and mention accountants because the volume of work that accountants do largely arises from Acts of State and Federal governments that impose basic costs and charges. Should we regulate them? One could come to only one conclusion about this. When one sees that a government has set out to do something that is unique and something that offends all the principles that it has ever set, one can only say that it is being done to nationalise the profession. This is being done to nationalise medicine. For what other reason is it being done? For what other reason would the Government deny the basic human rights of ordinary Australians to self insure?
—We did it only to get you excited.

—The honourable senator can be assured that the only persons who will get excited about this will be members of the Labor Party when the enormity of what they are doing is realised. These points are unarguable. Nowhere in the democratic world that I know of has any non-socialist country willingly said to a human being: 'I won't let you take a step to be voluntarily provident'. I ask honourable senators to tell me about any country which has done that and supported the principle behind it. It is an outrage to freedom. It has been done for a very simple reason. It has been done to force bulk billing and, therefore, to force a major change in the whole of the relationship between the community and the medical profession. Instead of the relationship being one of doctor and patient, one in which the patient by contracting with the doctor, achieves a service, one in which the patient, can select a doctor with special qualities and special charges, what is being done is to say that the relationship will be between government and doctors and it will be on the basis of a doctor bulk billing. The computer will decide the answers to this situation . The patient will not be a significant part of it. Otherwise, why do it? Why threaten the patient? Section 17 does threaten the patient as the denial of gap insurance threatens the patient. It is nonsense to say that the patient is not involved in this dispute. Of course the patient is involved. In any democracy a patient who pays for health insurance should have the absolute right to choose the specialist of his or her choice and get the benefit what that service provides. To say: 'We will tax you but certain of you, if you behave in a particular way, will not get the benefit' is a rejection of human rights. Let that be perfectly clear.

SPEECH.PARA: So the matter narrows down to what we are looking at with this problem. Clearly the States have indicated-certainly Mr Roper in Victoria and Dr Cornwall in South Australia have indicated-that there is not a problem as they see it. The States clearly have responsibility for hospitals. The States have the responsibility not only for the cost of the internal management of hospitals but also for the relationship between the doctor and the patient. The States and not the Commonwealth are to decide what shall be that relationship, who shall be the specialists, what shall be the diagnostic aids and the procedures available. There is now an intrusion, using section 51 of the Constitution, a section dubious in its application to this legislation, which has the Commonwealth moving in and pushing the States aside, saying that it will lay down the terms. But of course the question of how the hospital is run with its interns, its residents, its registrars and its visiting specialists must be in the final analysis a matter for the States.

Senator Haines said that she was surprised to hear the intrusion of the argument about costs. I put it to the Senate that it was not Senator Baume who intruded that argument. If one runs through the debates in the other place and the statements of the Hawke Government one sees that the intrusion is an argument about greedy practitioners who want to overcharge. Let us refute that straight away. Let us refute it by pointing to the fact that we know from Mr Roper and Dr Cornwall that in their States they would have found it unnecessary to bring in price control arrangements to enforce the basic fee. In fact, they have both come out and said that in their States all doctors charge either the prescribed fee or less. That has been the case under ordinary contracts that have been operating over the years. In New South Wales it appears that that is also so.

Equally, the question of how much a visiting medical officer shall repay to the hospital by way of facility fees has been traditionally over the years a matter between the hospital administration and the visiting medical officer. No one has ardently suggested that there has been an abuse of this practice. If there has been any abuse, it is entirely a matter for the State governments to rectify.

The Minister, in his second reading speech, copiously quoted from the report of the Jamison Commission of Inquiry into the Efficiency and Administration of Hospitals in support of his arguments for Federal intervention. But the very matters that he quoted are those that relate entirely to State responsibilities and the question of hospitals putting their houses in order, if indeed that is necessary. The Jamison report suggested that the overuse of diagnostic facilities in hospitals might be inquired into. If there is, in fact, this overuse, not only VMOs, but also interns, registrars and all the procedures of the hospitals should be looked into at a State level. If one looks at Dr Blewett 's speech step by step, one sees that he is arguing on totally false grounds.

Equally, I am quite sure that whatever a High Court may decide in the future, there was never any intention in the mind of the public when it passed the amendment to the Constitution some decades ago that it would bring about a condition such as has been brought about today. The amendment to section 51 of the Constitution provides:
The provision of . . . medical and dental services (but not so as to authorise any form of civil conscription) . . .

It seems that at the very least there is a strong case to argue that what the Government is doing is an abuse of the intention of that provision. I make that quite clear because quite often what the public decides in a referendum that words mean and what a High Court decides they mean can be quite different. I have no doubt in the world that this is so, because I was active at the time the amendment was made. I remember very well the then Leader of the Opposition, Mr Menzies, interpolating those words 'but not so as to authorise any form of civil conscription'. I remember very clearly that there was no intention in the Parliament's mind or in the mind of the public outside to do what has been done today.

The Government has set up the Penington Committee of Inquiry into Rights of Private Practice in Public Hospitals. That inquiry is proceeding. The only logical thing to do would be to stand at ease, to preserve the status quo, until the inquiry is over. When the inquiry report comes in it should be a matter for public debate. It would be good if the report were one that could provide consensus and solve the problem. If not, let us have the debate, let us get to the core of it. I repeat: I know of no other instance, when an inquiry has been set up, of the status quo being altered pending that inquiry and the discussion following the report of the inquiry. I know of no other instance in which the Prime Minister or anyone else has said to any other profession: 'Yes, we will lift the present requirements for signing a contract now if you will agree to the Penington report, whatever it may be'. A game of blindman's buff? Where indeed is the morality of that? We are dealing with a series of events which challenge the test of public morality.

Let us look at them. In the first place there is the denial of the right of the individual to take voluntary steps to insure privately against extra costs. What justification can there be for that denial? There is the denial of the right of a private patient to get medical benefits, the patient having paid a tax levy, if that patient chooses to go to a specialist as a private patient in a public hospital, that specialist not having signed a contract. Both those instances are , of course, blackmail of the doctors. Let us go further in the test of public morality. Where has it ever been said that there will be an enforcement of a unilateral contract in which the people who are forced to sign it have had no part in the discussions and have no right of appeal? The contract having been signed, it can be changed unilaterally at any time. Where is the morality of this situation?

On top of this has come the Government's smokescreen. The Government is trying to hide the fact that it is seeking to bring in nationalised medicine. It wants to take this dialogue away from the interests of the patient to an alleged greedy self-interest of the medical profession. It wants to pretend to the public that the Government is interested in the patient and that the doctor is not. That is demonstrably nonsense. It is an outrage. In point of fact, the Government has denied the patient's basic fundamental rights. It has been clearly demonstrated that it is not a question of the doctors saying: 'We want more money; we want to charge more than the basis of charging'.

TALK.START.PARA: —They don't do it.

—Because, in fact, they do not do it. In fact, the State Ministers have said that there is no necessity for this price control. In fact, most doctors do not charge more; many of them charge less. That is the kind of morality we are getting into. The Government pretends about goals and hides others. Let us not forget the important statement made by the present Minister for Health, Dr Blewett, in Adelaide in 1982. He said that the Labor Party:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . has put aside any primary emphasis on salaried or capitation systems in pragmatic recognition of the prevailing culture and attitudes in this society and in its effort to secure widespread community support for its program.
Remember those words 'in its effort to secure widespread community support for its program'. He continued:
Private fee-for-service medicine is deeply entrenched in Australian society, strongly defended by the medical profession, and favourably evaluated by the population at large.
The next sentence is crucial. It states:
That is a fact of life and whatever changes we desire in that system will have to take place gradually and incrementally.

The present Minister said that the public does not want the abolition of their freedom under the doctor-patient fee-for-service situation. He said that if we want to change that we have to do it gradually and incrementally. Here we have the whole plan of gradualism, which says to people: 'Look, do not accept a private fee-for-service situation with your local doctor. Get your doctor to bulk bill'.

TALK.START.PARA: —Fabius Maximus.

—Yes, the honourable senator is quite right-do things gradually and you will get there. The aim is to gradually destroy the doctor- patient fee-for-service relationship-the right of the client to choose and to choose what to pay. Where in any other profession is the client denied the right to choose to pay a particular fee? Where for example, among lawyers is one denied the right to pay a higher fee if the lawer is regarded as being more skilled? Why should not a medical practitioner who has demonstrably much greater skills than another medical practitioner have the right to charge a higher fee if he or she believes it is appropriate? No other profession has this sanction imposed upon it, including the professions which place heavy burdens upon the public purse. What is happening here, as is the case with education, is that there is a levelling down, a move towards mediocrity, that is, that all shall go at the speed of the slowest. We will make everybody charge the same.Whether doctors have higher or lower skills does not matter. Let us all level things out and have equality of outcome. That is the phrase of the Minister for Education and Youth Affairs, Senator Ryan, and her colleagues. At the very heart of this situation lies the fact that, unlike any other association or union, the medical profession will not be allowed to arbitrate in the ordinary way. It will have a unilateral decision forced upon it. That is an outrage. I remind the Senate that the Government, day after day, defends the right of all others-as I recall-to withhold their services if they believe they have a genuine agreement. It attacks the medical profession with vitriol for doing so. In my view, the medical profession is a highly responsible body, most of whose members are highly dedicated and perform a very fine service for the community. Of course the medical profession should continue that service because it is a life sustaining service. It has a moral duty to do that. Any denials of service should occur only when arbitration has failed and in extremes. I have always doubted the validity of the principle of the right to withhold services. I believe that is a principle which needs to be looked at very carefully.

SPEECH.PARA: I rose because I did not want this subject to be viewed as being some kind of a dog fight, as I have said, between doctors who want a lot more money and the Government which wants to protect the patient. It is clearly a fight in which the patients' interests are being sabotaged by this Government. The very principles of the right of private arrangement between doctor and patient are being sabotaged. What the doctors are saying is unarguably right and the public deserves to understand it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crowley Sen R.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am rendered almost speechless by that monument to debating by Senator Sir John Carrick. I will come back to that later . Fortunately, I am not quite speechless. I can say that he and Senator Baume opposite have entertained the public of Australia, or the few members who have been listening, to a remarkable set of independent pieces of information which is wrong in the sense that it is selective so that one comes out with the wrong impression. The first error I wish to correct was made by Senator Baume. He claimed that this is the first time ever that the medical profession has been driven to take this sort of industrial action.
