Perhaps the honourable senator does not know, but for the record I wish to say that this is certainly not the first time that the medical profession has been driven to industrial action. I think we need to be quite clear about that. From 1896 to 1900, four years, there was a strike by hospital-
—18 when?

—I invite Senator Walters to read the Hansard. From 1896 to 1900 , for four years, there was a strike in South Australia by hospital specialists which closed down the medical school. That would seem to me a fair example of the medical profession's industrial action. Senator Walters asked about dates. Perhaps she should refer herself to the Hobart Hospital when in 1917 a professional action was taken by the medical profession in that State. That dispute lasted for 13 years. It was nothing if not persistent. As a consequence of the arrangements that the Tasmanian doctors came to in Tasmania at that stage , because of the Hobart and Launceston hospital arrangements, the provisions for private practice in public hospitals in Tasmania are much less of a dispute at the moment, precisely because of the settlement that was reached after that piece of industrial action. Thirdly, in 1938 the specialists at the Brisbane and South Coast hospitals threatened to go on strike, but were persuaded to become part time and paid specialists-that situation very much exists at the moment- which is why Queensland's voice in this whole debate is very different. For the record, there has been industrial action by Senator Baume's and my profession in times past. This is not the first time. Those people who are rushing around saying 'Isn't it dreadful? Look what we have been driven to' need to know that they have been driven there a couple of times before.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Baume claimed that this case has been one of misrepresentation. I agree with him. I thank him and Senator Sir John Carrick for their contribution to misrepresentation and hope that I will not fall to that kind of line also. Certainly the doctors have been up to some misrepresentation. I hasten to say that I am referring to those doctors who have been spokespersons-so many women are involved-for the Australian Medical Association. They are not really representative of the broad medical profession. I think we should make it quite clear that this sport of doctor bashing is invidious and should be laid aside. We are debating, negotiating and discussing the matter with the spokesmen for the AMA. They are not even representative of all the members in that organisation. They are certainly not representative of all the doctors in the profession.

I refer the Senate to an article which appeared in the Melbourne Age on 2 April . The article elaborates very clearly what has happened in this whole dispute. Again, as another piece of misrepresentation, it would seem-if one listens to Senator Baume-as if the Government has taken on the profession. As Senator Haines pointed out, it was the medical profession, the AMA, in its advertisement in the Age of 14 March headed 'Why the Doctors Are So Angry', which first used the words 'unfettered power without right of appeal to insert any restrictive clauses he chooses'-that is, the Minister for Health (Dr Blewett)-'into long- standing agreements'. It was the AMA which hotted up and hyped up the debate and the argument. The advertisement also referred to 'a power assumed by government which could be used to destroy the rights of citizens to make private arrangements with their private doctors to treat them in hospital'. Similarly, a letter published on 3 February from Dr Sutherland and 44 other doctors stated:
Doctors who treat private patients in public hospitals are being asked to sign contracts which ultimately will erode their professional independence and limit their incomes.

As Geoffrey Barker in the 'State of the Nation' article commented, it was a frank admission that the first concerns of the doctors were status and money. I think it is very important that we examine closely how this debate has become hyped up. Medicare was very successfully introduced on 1 February. Some short while after the opposition from the medical profession emerged which focused around clause 17 of the legislation. The opposition of the doctors focused around the fear they have that the Minister-any Minister; presumably not just the current Labor Minister-will be able to use 'unfettered powers' to alter the way in which doctors practise medicine in this country. That is quite an extraordinary piece of overstatement on the part of the spokesmen for the AMA. Further to that, Minister Blewett, in discussions with the AMA, has been at pains to be reasonable and to recognise the need for continuing discussions on and thought about this matter. I shall come back to that matter later.

The claim made by the doctors and Senator Sir John Carrick, that a patient will lose his or her civil rights to choose a doctor and to have the treatment that he or she wants, is one of the furphies that the Liberal Opposition maintains. In fact, most sick people-people are often sick and often frightened when they seek the help of a doctor-have no real or effective rights to make a private choice. The essential choice they make is to go to a general practitioner. If they learn to trust and appreciate that general practitioner they will accept a referral by that general practitioner; they do not choose their own specialist. I allow the exception that in the case of obstetrics care women sometimes will choose their own specialist. Apart from that, those who make their own private choice are those who have doctor contacts or doctor colleagues or are high status people in our community. The majority of Australians rely for referral upon their general practitioner. In him or her they trust; they do not themselves choose a private specialist. In particular they do not do so when they do not know what is wrong with them and have to seek further diagnosis and specialist treatment. It is a nonsense to say that patients have the right to make a choice; they do not. Most people, if they examine this matter reasonably, will appreciate that they do not. They depend on being referred by their medical doctor. In fact, it is the doctors who exercise the right of choice on behalf of the patient, not the patient himself or herself. The argument advanced by Senator Sir John Carrick is very misleading.

Another point that interests me in this whole argument is the principal objection of the AMA to the Minister requiring that medical practitioners charge the schedule fee. This seems to be some kind of wicked restriction or limitation on the medical profession. I shall tell the Senate how the schedule fee is arrived at. In fact, an inquiry into this matter has just been completed. It was carried out between January 1984 and March 1984. The inquiry was presided over by the Deputy President of the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission, Mr Justice McKenzie. Submissions were invited from interested parties. Public hearings were held, and the parties could give verbal information or provide written submissions. After hearing all the evidence, the Deputy President of the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission handed down his judgment. In fact, submissions to this recent inquiry, which was held between January and March 1984, came from the Federal Government, the AMA, the New South Wales Department of Health, and the Australian Association of Surgeons. Lesser submissions were received from the Macquarie Pathology Service and the Department of Community Medicine in Sydney. Thirty-five minor submissions were received. I suppose they were lesser submissions in the sense that they were presented but the authors did not appear before the inquiry to give verbal evidence.

The decision was based on the evidence and submissions received from the two largest groups, the AMA and the Federal Government. The umpire in this case was the Deputy President of the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission. He handed down his decision, but then the AMA said: 'The umpire having made his decision, we do not want to play ball. We object to how the schedule fees are set. We object to the score you have given us'. It says that despite the fact that it made a submission to that inquiry into the schedule fee. In fact, the AMA would have been one of the largest organisations appearing before the inquiry. It was argued this afternoon that there is a problem about how the schedule fee is set because the spokespeople for the AMA cannot agree on the terms of such an inquiry. I do not really see that the Federal Government should be held responsible for the limitations and liabilities of the AMA. It is not a very good argument at all. Having agreed to what a schedule fee is, by making a submission to the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission, the AMA then says: ' It is not fair; we do not agree with the decision'. It by and large set its own schedule fee a little higher-in fact, quite a big little bit higher; in some cases well over 10 per cent higher-than the schedule fee agreed to. Even then it is unhappy.

I have heard it said today also that the AMA is unhappy about being restricted to receiving 85 per cent of the schedule fee. How was this 85 per cent figure arrived at? In the years before the last election-that is, 1981 and 1982-the then shadow spokesman on health matters, Neal Blewett, discussed all of these issues at great length all over the country with various groups with an interest in health matters, and in particular with the AMA. It is not as though all of these matters have been sprung upon the AMA. It was party to all of these discussions and it agreed to the 85 per cent figure. It did so for a number of reasons. The AMA agreed that 15 per cent was a fair estimate of what it cost to run a practice, to chase up bad debts, to write off money forgone, to administer a practice and so on. Further, the AMA argued that the gap between the schedule fee and the insurance rebate was necessary. It supported the concept that there be no insurance to cover the gap. That is what the AMA thought before 1982.

I wish that Senator Sir John Carrick had stayed in the chamber to hear me make these remarks because he was at pains to point out that people are about to lose their civil rights because they cannot take out gap insurance. History is a curious thing. Perhaps it selectively dulled Senator Sir John Carrick's memory. Prior to 1972 the Liberal Government and the AMA did not want gap insurance to be made available. In fact, up to the introduction of Medicare, the AMA did not want gap insurance to be made available. It does not want it for reasons very different from those of the Government. The AMA does not want gap insurance because its non-availability allows it to perpetuate the argument it often puts forward about the patient being able to contribute to the patient-doctor relationship. The AMA feels that if gap insurance is not available it will restrain the patients from overusing the system. It will also enable the AMA to continue to advance the argument that the contract between the patient and the doctor is substantiated by the payment of money. The AMA has often argued that it does not want the introduction of gap insurance.

The Government is unashamed of the reasons it advanced for setting the figure of 85 per cent. A reasonable agreement was reached with the AMA. The 85 per cent figure provides the Government with a means of constraining the cost of health care in the community. There certainly is an inducement to bulk billing. Both of those objectives form part of the Government's policy: It wishes to constrain the cost of health services in the community Australia-wide. It wishes to encourage bulk billing: Firstly, because it is simpler and fairer to all people concerned; secondly, because it helps to contain costs; thirdly, because it results in money being received on a more regular basis; and, fourthly, as I have often heard argued by doctors, bulk billing frees them from worrying about whether a patient can pay and lets them get on with the business of practising good medicine. Many reasons can be advanced as to why bulk billing is a good thing. Those arguments come from both sides of the debate; that is, from the Federal Government and from the AMA. I find it curious that honourable senators opposite have suddenly changed their tack and advance reasons for not having bulk billing. Perhaps those honourable senators were not party to the debate that took place prior to the introduction of Medicare.

Once Medicare was in place, the provisions contained in section 17 became the focus of the profession. The Minister is a reasonable man. If he has a fault at all it is perhaps that he presumed reasonableness on the part of the others. Most doctors quite likely are reasonable people. Many of the members of the AMA to whom I have spoken have been distressed about how the debate has been progressing and about the fact that the stage has been reached where the doctors are about to take some considerable industrial action. That is distressing to most of those doctors. I think most of them are reasonable, but the spokesmen for the AMA certainly do not appear to be reasonable, judging from the way in which they are shaping their argument. Despite Minister Blewett's recognition of the difficulties and his willingness to address the problem, despite the fact that he has accepted in principle the amendment proposed originally by the Australian Democrats and subsequently legislated for in this place, and despite the fact that he has established an inquiry presided over by Dr Penington to address these matters and other matters, the AMA continues to sulk. If it is an industrial organisation, it does not know how to behave as an industrial organisation. It has much to learn.

The debate has been quite extraordinary. I read in the Bulletin of 3 April 1984 the following quotation from Dr Peter Duffy who is a radiologist. He is a Sydney ultrasound practitioner and Secretary of the Royal Australasian College of Radiologists. He said:

If the Minister has the power to say you've got to work 80 hours a week or 91 1 /2 hours and clean toilets on Saturday night at one minute past nine; if he were to do such ridiculous things, you would have to jump or leave. It's better to sort this out in the beginning.

When I see a doctor who is in fact the Secretary of the Royal Australasian College of Radiologists actually going into print with utter rubbish of that sort, suggesting that the Minister should take note of that kind of argument, I think it is very sad. That man is quite ridiculous.

TALK.START.PARA: —He is illustrating the principle.

—If he is illustrating a principle, Senator Teague, I wish he would illustrate it with sense and not with farcical illustrations of doctors perhaps cleaning toilets, although it may not be a bad thing if they did. But to assume that Minister Blewett is about to set regulations of that sort is not illustrative of anything except that the doctor is probably going soft.

SPEECH.PARA: The next article that quite staggers me is an editorial in the News in South Australia of 29 March 1984, a paper that is not renowned for its radical approach to things. The editorial reads:
This newspaper has no hesitation in condemning in the strongest terms the irresponsible mooring gangs dispute which tied up South Australian shipping.
That same kind of language is warranted for the doctors and their threat to a national strike from Monday week.
Perhaps the Federal Government was crass in aspects of Medicare's introduction.
But, on any reasonable assessment of the dispute, it is obvious that the Federal Government has bent over backwards to accommodate the doctors.
For doctors then to take to the streets of Adelaide and other cities and to threaten a national strike is irresponsible and wrong.
The well-paid doctors should immediately do what they will have to do eventually anyway, sit down, stop making threats and start talking commonsense.

It is a matter of great shame that the doctors have actually found themselves driven to heights of rhetoric well beyond their own requirements or wishes in this matter. They have got themselves cornered. They have upped their ante and are now in a very difficult, if not foolish, position.

TALK.START.PARA: —Painting themselves into a corner.

—That is a very good way of putting it. I simply mention those two quotations because they are illustrative of the level of debate. I commend the News on its editorial. It states very succinctly what should be stated at this stage of the argument. One of the elements that has been overlooked in the whole debate is the consequence of why anybody should interfere and why the Federal Minister should interfere-if that is the right word; I would have thought 'take a long hard look' would be better words-in the arrangements between doctors and hospitals and contracts between them. Senator Sir John Carrick seems to suggest that the debate should be happening in the States. But whose dollars are spent in the State hospitals? They are of course Federal dollars. It would be quite irresponsible-I think wantonly irresponsible-for a Federal Minister not to have considerable regard to how Federal dollars are spent in State institutions.

SPEECH.PARA: One of the reasons there are more problems at this time than before is that under the previous Government hospital agreements between the Federal and State governments were considerably changed. After the five-year agreements ran out, two States, Tasmania and South Australia, had 10-year agreements and could have proceeded, and in fact did but in slightly varied terms. But as a consequence of that change in arrangements between the Federal and State governments, the States had to find much more of the money themselves. They found there was no reason, and certainly no incentive, for them to continue to provide estimates of costs in the hospitals or the other data that had been required under the previous State-Federal Hospital agreement, so they ceased to do it. Now we have a Federal Government trying to make sensible planning provisions in terms of expenditure in the health area but it does not have the basic data to go on. It needs to collect that basic data. It now requires it from the States which are essentially very pleased to co-operate because good data allows both the Federal and State governments to do better and good planning.

Another important piece of data that the Government did not have was any real estimate of how much private work was being done in public institutions. We have had all sorts of Opposition claims that people will not be able to get a bed in a public hospital because the queues will be very long, there will be a huge waiting list and so on. One of the things that happened under the previous Government's arrangements was that public hospital beds were occupied by people having private hospitalisation and private medical treatment. It is important to have some hard data in this area so as to be able to say to people that once we get the private work out of public facilities we will be able to make much better use of them for public patients under the Medicare arrangements. There will be no need to wait so long or to be afraid in anticipation of those changes . But the Government did not have the data. It has tried to acquire some of it.

In fact in South Australia, the aforementioned State-I am proud of South Australia for a number of reasons, not the least of which is that its doctors are fairly reasonable people-well over 60 per cent of doctors have already signed contracts. They are currently practising under the sorts of contracts that Minister Blewett was proposing. Why should people object to what they have already agreed to? Senator Sir John Carrick argued that kind of line in another question. I agree with him if his argument refers to doctors who suddenly disagree with terms and conditions to which they have already agreed. Doctors in South Australia were charging the schedule fee in large part for their pathology services so the agreement is very comfortable in South Australia and upsets nobody very much.

One of the problems was that in other States there was no understanding, at least not to the same extent there was in South Australia, of how much money was recouped through private work in public hospitals. There was no reliable data on how much was paid back to the funds, usually established by the hospitals to recoup a percentage of that private money to offset the costs of equipment, staff, administrative services, billing and so on.

The other question is what happened to the money that was left over. In some hospitals a great amount of it went into research. Considerable grants, staffing arrangements and research were financed with the private money recouped by private practitioners in public facilities. This is a bit of a problem because most of that research was not subject to review or analysis by the National Health and Medical Research Council. In fact, it was a problem that the AMA admits, at least in private, as being a considerable difficulty for it. The AMA admits that that research was being done without the NHMRC or any other body in Australia's evaluating it, judging it to be worth while or even admitting that it was duplicating some other piece of research. This is a spin-off problem from the consequences of private practice unfettered, uncontrolled and unmeasured.

There are a number of reasons why the Government most responsibly wanted to understand what was happening with private practice in public institutions. It was not only a matter of cost constraint, it was also a matter of data collection and a more reasonable and responsible allocation of government funds. To suggest, as Senator Sir John Carrick did, that these are State matters and no business of the Federal Government is very misleading. The Federal Government has a proper responsibility to understand what is happening to Federal dollars, even when they are being spent by the States.

This whole debate in fact is remarkable in terms of the heat that was engendered when the Federal Government responsibly decided to set clear guidelines. In fact section 17 is no more than clear guidelines. However, I think it is well appreciated that those people to whom the guidelines apply ought to have some ability to take part in the deliberations about the guidelines before they are accepted. The right of appeal or parliamentary scrutiny of those guidelines or regulations I agree and the Government agrees is very reasonable. But to suggest that it is irresponsible of the Federal Government to establish clear guidelines so that people can know where they stand and how they have to adjust according to those guidelines is quite stupid. It is responsible government.

I suppose it comes as a terrible shock to people at the moment because we have had seven years of government that seemed more at pains to undo Federal guidelines, to disregard them and let people go willy-nilly. This Government is unashamed about being responsible for how it spends the Federal dollar. It is unashamed about that responsibility for people in the health area in particular. That is the nature of this debate.

The other important thing that has been overlooked too-in this debate anyhow-is how much of the taxpayer's dollar which the Federal Government wishes to account for and to be able to account for goes to educating the doctors. How much goes to paying for them all through their university training? How much goes to paying for them as they work in public hospitals? How much goes to assisting their post-graduate training and, in the case of the situation under debate, to providing facilities? The very expensive technological equipment used for radiology and biochemistry and in all areas of pathology services and research are provided by the taxpayer. The doctor has the use of those facilities. He has the use of taxpayer funded staff, et cetera. Some part-the percentage varies from hospital to hospital or State to State-of his or her private earnings over and above the amount that he or she by agreement may keep goes to defray those costs. But the essential and large part of the cost is borne by the public dollar. I think it would be irresponsible of government not to try to account for where those dollars come from in the beginning and how they are allocated both during the provision of services and, in particular, after the provision of services. To establish guidelines to require some clear yardsticks by which we can measure whether or not what we prefer to be happening is happening seems to me to be the outline and the definition of responsible government.

I have heard people refer in this debate to the constitutional rights of doctors not to have to suffer civil conscription. I find that proposition very interesting. I have read some part of the judgment handed down in the very interesting case that concerns this matter. This judgment was certainly not unanimous. In fact, two of the judges argued very coherently that civil conscription was to be understood in the way in which most of us would understand that term. It had nothing to do, they argued, with requiring or not requiring that certain fees be set. A very interesting and tortured series of arguments was advanced to suggest that requiring a doctor to set a certain fee would be part of civil conscription. The arguments largely centered around interfering with the doctor's right to contract with a patient. But the patient- doctor relationship in terms of a doctor's ablity to practice his medicine as he will is not interfered with whether he charges $100 or $10. The practice of medicine is quite separate from how it is paid for. Those members of the medical profession who are still objecting are finding it quite difficult to make that distinction. Certainly, two of the judges felt that way in the decision handed down in the civil conscription of doctors case.

At the next election a referendum will be put to allow the High Court to give opinions or advice to government. Assuming that that question is agreed to, I think it would be very interesting to see the outcome if such a case as this once again went before the High Court. It may be in fact no more than a matter of how the Bench is weighted at the time. I have trouble appreciating that the law is open to objective assessment and is not coloured by the nature of the people on the Bench. However, I would allow that that is the case and that as much as possible the judges, in weighing up the evidence before them, will make their decision accordingly. If the case were presented to the High Court again the outcome might be different. A different discussion would certainly ensue about the definition of 'civil conscription'. As I said, the judgment might not necessarily be the one that was reached previously.

To summarise, I commend the Government for introducing the amendment to section 17 of the health legislation. I appreciate the Government's view that the argument that has proceeded apace to this stage has brought no credit, no satisfaction and no relief of concern for most patients who are hoping that they can see their doctors and receive their medicine and services as ever. The Government recognises that this is one way in which that debate and argument may be laid to rest. Hopefully, the passage of this amendment will achieve that.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walters Sen M.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are debating today the Health Insurance Amendment Bill 1984 (No. 2) which seeks to amend section 17 of the Health Insurance Act. Section 17 was originally amended by the Government to allow for ministerial direction in regard to doctors' contracts. Whether honourable senators opposite like it or not, it is a fact that the Minister for Health (Dr Blewett) has complete jurisdiction over the contracts of doctors working in public hospitals. It was because the doctors objected to this that they have taken the action they have taken. Indeed, as Senator Sir John Carrick has indicated, it was not a penalty against the doctors but against the patients. Patients were to be denied any medical benefit if they were treated by a doctor who had not signed a contract. The Government has now backed down over this issue. It has belatedly brought forward an amendment to allow parliamentary scrutiny of the right of the Minister to alter doctors' contracts without negotiation with doctors.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Haines says that she does not understand why this legislation does not overcome all the problems in the dispute. If she does not understand it, I cannot imagine why she has been even talking to the Australian Medical Association. Senator Haines does understand that the composition of this place fluctuates. She does understand that the numbers in this Senate alter considerably through the will of the people. She has said that she is aware of that, but that is unlikely. Indeed, she has said for some considerable time that the Government would not have the numbers in this place and, therefore, she did not see any point in worrying about that. I think the doctors do see some point in worrying about a situation in which the Parliament as a whole would have the right, without negotiation with them, to say what sort of contract should be signed by them in State public hospitals. It is absolutely ridiculous that the Parliament should have any say in such a matter. The Parliament does not have any say in regard to the contracts of lawyers, engineers or anyone else. It does not have any say about exactly what they should get or the agreements under which they should work. It is really quite ridiculous to think that doctors would agree to this sort of thing.
As has been indicated already, Senator Peter Baume brought forward a similar measure last September when the problem first arose.

TALK.START.PARA: —Pronounce it right, Senator.

—I notice that Senator Baume is irritated when Senator Crowley does not get it right. However, Senator Grimes had quite a lot to say at that time. He said: 'Well, we would have some interesting situations in hospitals if the guidelines were approved by State Ministers and the Federal Minister and someone for some reason or other moved for the disallowance in this place and then 15 sitting days later after the contracts had been drawn up the guidelines were disapproved'. Evidently he now does not mind that interesting situation developing because he is putting to us now that we allow that interesting situation to develop. He went on to say, as Senator Baume has indicated, that he thought that the whole thing was an unnecessary impediment. He now does not mind the unnecessary impediment or the interesting situation developing. We find that Senator Grimes is rather fluid, too, in the things he agrees with. One moment an assets test is proposed on pensions and the next moment we find that that is all a great mistake. Mr Hawke told Senator Grimes to back off and he did so. So Senator Grimes is used to this sort of thing.

SPEECH.PARA: If such a proposal had been put forward in 1978 Senator Cavanagh, who was then a member of this place, would never have allowed Caucus to come to such a decision. I remind honourable senators opposite that in 1978 when bad drafts- manship at that time led the Minister in our Government to make certain directions-those directions were to be laid on the table, but there was no room for a disallowance-Senator Cavanagh said:
The thing of which I complain-
he had earlier complained bitterly about draftsmanship-

is contained in section 4 of the Act, which says that a Minister may make a declaration under section 4B, which has certain objects as set out in the legislation. The Act then sets out the procedure for presentation to the Parliament, and that is the end of it; there is no need for the Parliament to discuss it.
He went on to say how terribly undemocratic that sort of thing was. Senator Cavanagh retired from this place some time ago and the Government is the worse for it.

The Minister for Health said in the other place that doctors were concerned that the schedule might be frozen. He gave a personal guarantee that that would not be done. One has only to look at the history of promises made by the Minister for Health and other Ministers to see what becomes of government promises. There is no guarantee that the present Government will do a thing it says it will do.

TALK.START.PARA: —It was your Government that froze the fees.

—I shall come to that matter shortly. Let us look at the Government's record on doctor bashing. Senator Crowley, Senator Grimes, Senator Tate, Dr Blewett and Mr Hawke have all had a wonderful time doctor bashing. Let us examine what Senator Grimes said in November last year:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . they will make a lot of noise but they will interrupt that noise occasionally by putting their snouts in the trough of public funding.

What a statement to come from a Minister of the Crown. What an appalling example of the sort of Minister of the Crown put up by the present Government. What appalling words. Senator Tate said that the doctors in Hobart were ripping off the system. There are so many descriptions of what members in the other place and the Government think about doctors that I shall not take up further time quoting them.

Perhaps I should cite the latest public opinion poll published by the Bulletin of the professions considered to be tops in ethics. Senator Baume referred to this. The top mark went to the doctors, with a figure of 64 per cent public approval. Over the years in which many Labor members, and Senator Grimes in particular, have been doctor bashing, the public's approval of doctors rose from 62 per cent to 63 per cent and it is now 64 per cent. What is the position of politicians in that poll? I am ashamed to say that as we politicians have among our ranks people such as Senator Grimes, Dr Blewett and Senator Tate, the public 's opinion of politicians is way down the list. It does not seem to matter how much political doctor bashing goes on, the public opinion of doctors continues to rise. Ours, I am ashamed to say, is down to 19 per cent. That is an absolute disgrace. However, it does not matter what Senator Grimes does, public opinion of doctors continues to rise. Senator Crowley has just left the profession of which the public had a decent opinion and has now entered a profession whose standing with the public is, I am afraid, very low.

Let us examine the sorts of doctors the Government is bashing. Last Thursday or Friday night, in Hobart, 150 doctors attended a meeting-not bad for Hobart-and several motions were passed. One motion read:
That this meeting rejects the power given to the Minister by Section 17; advises doctors not to sign contracts-

That is a reference to the contracts put forward by the Government. The motion concluded by stating that the meeting also supported the national stand by the AMA. This was not an AMA meeting. They were 150 doctors from all around Hobart.

TALK.START.PARA: —Oh!
—Senator Grimes, who is now laughing, must admit that a gathering of 150 doctors in Hobart is not a bad number. The meeting noted:

SPEECH.PARA: That no intermediate patient has ever been charged in excess of the schedule fee and that this has been written into the intermediate patients agreement since its inception in 1976.
The meeting noted that the schedule fee for intermediate patients had never been exceeded.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is part of their contract.
—It is not part of their contract.
—It is a contract with the Government.

—It is not, and if Senator Grimes does not understand that he should not be the spokesman on health in this place. It is not in their contract at all. It is a voluntary agreement that they have decided on themselves.
—That they have signed.

—They have not signed it at all. If you do not understand that, I am most surprised. However, the doctors are completely behind the national move and have given it their full support. The doctors in Hobart do not need to take any particular stand on this nor do the doctors in Queensland. Tasmania and Queensland are the only two States which do not have Labor Governments and where Dr Blewett has not agreed with the State governments to inflict these contracts on doctors.

SPEECH.PARA: Let us examine why the Government is taking such a stand against the doctors. All speakers on this side of the chamber have queried the reason. It can be for no other reason than nationalisation.

TALK.START.PARA: —Huh!

—Senator Grimes in his inimitable way says: 'Huh, nationalisation!' There is no doubt that the Government is seeking nationalisation through the back door. Why the back door? Because constitutionally it cannot do so otherwise. Let us look at a number of quotations that will make clear the Government's reasons for taking such a course. On 26 February 1984, when the dispute had only just begun and both sides were just having a few terse words, with the AMA asking Dr Blewett to review the matter, the Minister for Health said that he could not understand the surgeons. He said:

SPEECH.PARA: Our proposals only affect the specialists of radiology, pathology, nuclear medicine and radiotherapy.
Therefore, he does not understand the surgeons at all. He continued:
There are no proposals at all relating to the surgeons, who are a separate area of medical specialty.

That is what he said in February in a news release. But what did he say to the Doctors Reform Society in August last year? He certainly did not say what he said in February. He said to the Doctors Reform Society:
One area of particular concern to the Government in the public hospital sphere is the right to private practice of sessional medical staff, particularly in the diagnostic service area . . .

It was agreed at the July Health Ministers Conference that attention to these problems should be initially directed to the area of diagnostic services, with the intention to move more broadly in due course.

In February he said he did not understand the surgeons becoming concerned because there were no proposals relating to them as they were in a separate area of medical specialty. At the Doctors Reform Society meeting he had said that he had the intention to move more broadly in due course. He wonders why the doctors do not trust him. There is no way anyone would trust him when he makes those sorts of comments. So at the moment we have proof that he does intend to move more broadly and not just against the diagnosticians. We also know that Mr Hawke and Dr Blewett have both said that bulk billing is the answer. They have indeed, in their advertising, stressed to the patients: 'Go and seek out a doctor who bulk bills'. What happens when a doctor bulk bills? That means the whole of his income is paid to him by the Government. To me, and I am sure to anyone else, that means that the doctor is a public servant and, because he is paid entirely by the Government, he is nationalised. Then we have the hospitals. Of course we have no suggestion at all that should anything happen private hospitals will be nationalised in any way. Senator Grimes would be laughing at the thought of that . Again Dr Blewett in his speech to the Doctors Reform Society said:
The Commonwealth is proceeding to collate information provided by the States as a basis to determine the future direction of activities to regulate rights of private practice.
In the private hospital sector the Government is moving to give greater control over subsidies to State Governments. This should also allow a greater degree of integration of hospital services.
Dr Deeble goes into it a little more clearly-I am quoting from the Sun-Herald newspaper of 29 January this year-when he says:
Putting private hospitals into three classes is a very first step towards putting private hospitals into the public system. This is a very big step, but it is a long-term aim.

I have dealt with the doctors and the hospitals. Let us have a look at the private funds, because they have indeed become a State monopoly as regards doctors' fees. Nowhere at all are patients permitted to insure themselves for their doctors' fees. They have got to be paid by the Government. The private funds have lost all right to insure for doctors' fees. So the medical fees section of the private funds have indeed become a State monopoly. They have been nationalised in the area of doctors' fees. We have only hospitals left. According to Dr Blewett and Dr Deeble putting private hospitals into three classes is the very first step towards putting private hospitals into the public system; this is a very big step, but it is a long term aim. So do not tell me that the aim of this Government is not to nationalise the whole health area. Indeed, it is well on the way. But why else would the doctors not trust Dr Blewett? Let me just give a few examples of things that he said in his second reading speech on the Health Legislation Amendment Bill on 6 September last year . He said:
Australian residents will be covered automatically and the 1 per cent payment will be made along with, but separately identified from, the tax instalments in the weekly or fortnightly pay packet.

Mr Acting Deputy President, can you tell me whether your pay packet has your one per cent separately identified from your other tax instalments? No one throughout the whole of Australia to whom I have spoken can. That quotation was from the second reading speech of Dr Blewett. This Government promised that the one per cent would be identified separately in the tax instalments of people's pay packets. That has not occurred. I wonder why it has not occurred. I wonder whether it is because Mr Hawke said that nine out of 10 people would be better off under this system. The Government does not really want to label for the people every week that they are paying more and that every time they go to the doctor and pay the extra 15 per cent of the doctor's fee they are paying more and more.

At the moment we have the Penington Committee of Inquiry into Rights of Private Practice in Public Hospitals being conducted. We are being told that at the end of that the Government will agree to whatever the recommendations are and that the doctors should do likewise, but that in the meantime they should abide by anything Dr Blewett cares to put forward, indeed that we should make sure that the doctors sign the contracts before that inquiry makes its recommendations. If only the Government would treat the rest of its industrial relations in the same way we would see what the public of Australia thinks about its methods, but it does not. It has two systems, one for the unions and one for the doctors. The one for the unions does not even suggest-indeed at the National Economic Summit Conference it was not even considered because it was thought to be not negotiatable and the doctors were told so-that they should abide by the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission's decision. We were told that the unions would not even consider abiding by the Arbitration Commission's decision when it comes down with wage rates. The unions say that they are not negotiable and they will not consider them. This Government says the doctors should abide by its inquiry. Indeed the doctors are not having a bar of it.

Mr Acting Deputy President, you would have heard, and so would the rest of Australia, all the accusations regarding fraud and over-servicing. This has been going on for some time. The professor of Statistics at the School of Economic and Financial Studies at Macquarie University, North Ryde, New South Wales, thinks the whole thing has been a cook-up in the Department of Health. For those officers who are now laughing beside the Minister, I will read what he said. The article is called 'Medifraud', and states:
. . . Dr Neal Blewett, the Federal Minister of Health, states-
That is in the Medical Journal of Australia--

. . . January 21 . . . that the estimates of $100 million for the magnitude of medical fraud and overservicing for 1980-81 and $120 million for 1981-82 are based on rigorous methods which are outlined in his department's submission to the Parliamentary Joint Committee of Public Accounts.

As a statistician with an interest in medical statistics, I have examined this submission . . . I have also studied a statistical review by E. S. Knight of the Commonwealth Department of Health's fraud and overservicing detection system, . . . and a further statement by Dr Blewett on medical fraud and overservicing made in Parliament on November 15, 1983.
In these reports, it is claimed that the amount of excess doctors' fees in 1982 was of the order of $100 million, broken down into one-third legitimate, one- third fraud and one-third overservicing.

I can say with conviction that there is no statistical or logical basis either for the amount quoted or for the breakdown into categories. The only basis for these figures is the 'expert opinion' of members of the Department of Health, ' supported' by a statistical calculation that is irrelevant and misleading. I have no disagreement with the E. S. Knight report which, if anything, adds weight to this conclusion.
As a scientist-
he is not a medical doctor, but a scientist-

I object most strongly to public policies being formulated on the basis of improper studies. There are sound procedures, well known to biostatisticians and epidemiologists, for estimating the extent and nature of fraud and overservicing in the medical profession. The procedures involve intelligent . . . study design , unbiased statistical sampling from the study population, and careful data management, data analysis and reporting, guided of course by expert opinion. There is no evidence that these procedures have been carried out.

That is signed by Don McNeil, PhD, Professor of Statistics at the School of Economic and Financial Studies, Macquarie University. As I have said, the doctor bashing by the Department of Health and the Government has surpassed anything we have previously seen in this country. I believe that that action by people who have cooked the figures is completely irresponsible and they have a lot to answer for. I sincerely hope that the Government gives up this doctor bashing and sees the wisdom of abiding by the private member's Bill put by Senator Baume and accepts Senator Baume's amendment to the motion that the Bill be now read a second time, as follows:

Leave out all words after 'That', insert 'the Senate is of the opinion that the Government should take immediate steps to resolve the dispute between the Minister for Health and the doctors by accepting the Health Legislation Amendment Bill 1984 introduced into the Senate by Senator Baume on 28 March 1984 .

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Teague Sen B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —Throughout the whole afternoon Opposition senators have been seeking to find a remedy to the offence in Australia's Medicare legislation whereby the Government has the unilateral power to determine contracts for doctors serviced in public hospitals. We are not debating Medicare itself. That matter was determined last year in the acrimonious debates about so many matters of principle that were involved in the socialising of health care in Australia. The declared positions of the Labor Government and of the Opposition, which takes a liberal approach to this matter, are very clear and more and more the public is becoming aware of the enormously contrasting approaches that Labor and the Opposition take to the organisation of health care in Australia. No, that is not what the current debate is about. Rather, it is about one aspect of the health insurance legislation that has come to be in focus in every newspaper over all of the weeks that the debate has ensued and which is currently of such great concern to the Australian public because of the impending lockout of doctors by the Government through unilaterally declaring contracts which are unacceptable to the medical profession. We hear day by day of a new turn in the discussions that stop and start between the Minister for Health (Dr Blewett) and the Australian Medical Association, and I am sure that the Opposition and the public hope that there will be a turn in that discussion that will stop this impending dislocation of health services in Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: The remedy to the problem is in the legislation before us. We are considering section 17 of the Health Insurance Act. The Opposition's case is that this whole section is deficient because it allows the contract of service for doctors in public hospitals to be determined solely by the government of the day, by the Minister for Health. That needs to be amended so that, as with every other contract of employment, every other contract for service provided by a profession, there is give and take, mutual discussion, consultation, negotiation and, if there is disagreement in that process, arbitration so that the contract is not thrust by one party on to the other but is something which is reasonably and sensibly derived so that it can be accepted by both parties to the contract. Because the contract is unilaterally declarable by the Minister for Health, it is offensive to the entire medical profession.

Can the Senate and the public be sympathetic to that profession? If the doctors go ahead and sign the contracts handed to them, they are agreeing to the basis on which that contract is offered; that is, they have no right in principle to disagree with the contract. It is determined by the Minister for Health in Canberra, in a centralist, autocratic way. Are they, by signing that contract, to accept that process? No, they are not. The Opposition agrees that this legislation needs much more drastic amendment than is contemplated by the Government. The hold on the medical profession is all the more invidious because the patients, the consuming public of Australia, are being held in this stranglehold that the Government is wanting to place on the medical profession. The Government is saying: 'Patients will not be able to gain any Medicare benefit, any subsidy on the cost of the medical process, if you doctors do not sign your contracts. If you do not sign the contracts that we are unilaterally putting before you you will be denying your patients any of the Medicare benefits that, in the past, accrued through health insurance schemes in all the ways that health costs were dealt with'. So the doctor is caught in that stranglehold, that dilemma. Will he deny the patient the Medicare benefit by conceding to this unilaterally determined contract of which he has not had any part or will he protest by saying the principle of the contract's formulation is wrong and therefore he cannot sign the contract? That is what section 17 is about.

In effect, the Government has found in the past several weeks that the public and the medical profession have such legitimacy and public suasion in their claim that it must give way a bit in the legislation. The Government is therefore putting up a squib of a small amendment that goes some distance towards what the medical profession and the Opposition are seeking. It now says: 'Although we, as the Government of Australia, will agree that these contracts being put before all medical practitioners are being unilaterally determined by us, it is all right because we will have this amendment to the legislation which will allow the Parliament to disapprove them if they are odious'. The Australian Democrats put up this proposal a few weeks ago as if it was a brand new initiative, a startling breakthrough that would save the nation from all of the calamities that the Government was leading the medical profession into. But it is not an initiative of the Democrats; it started with the Liberal-National Party Opposition when, in the main debate on Medicare last September, we put forward such a disallowance procedure for incorporation into the Health Insurance Act.

TALK.START.PARA: —Now you say it is a squib.

—We describe it as a squib now because, although it is right and should be supported, we need to go much further and allow the medical profession to be directly involved in the discussions and negotiations on the contracts in the first place. Is it sufficient for the Government and the Democrats now to say: 'Although it is a unilateral contract you have the remedy of Parliament disallowing it? Is that an answer to any area of employment in Australia where a party is locked out from taking any part in negotiating the contract? This contract has been determined by one party.

SPEECH.PARA: We appeal to honourable senators here today and to the public by asking: Is there any area of employment in Australia in which a party to a contract of employment has determined that only one side can conclude the contract? Would only one party determine the definition of the property at issue, the price and arrangements for the purchase of a house? There are two parties to any contract and both parties need to agree to its terms. Similarly, in any contract of employment there is an employer and an employee. The contract of their relationship should be determined by both parties.

The issue which is currently being taken up by the medical profession and which is fully supported by the Opposition is that that principle is not being recognised by the Government nor by the Democrats in this legislation. So, we rightly call this late Government amendment to legislation, which it introduced only a few months ago, a squib because it has the ability only to provide for parliamentary disallowance. It does not take account of the principle that the medical profession should be directly involved in the determinations of its contracts.

This Bill fails to take away the unilateral coercion which is directly allowed by the legislation even in this squib-like amended way. The Government's defence is: 'We are reasonable. We will not hurt the medical profession. Moreover, there are certain reasons for restraint. After all, the State governments have an interest in this matter. They would not want the Federal Government to be unreasonable'. The Government has also put up the case that if the medical practitioners were so offended by the unilaterally determined contracts they would go off and practice surgery and other procedures in private hospitals. That would denude the public hospitals of all their services and the Government would not have the ability to bring in doctors from overseas. The Government is putting forward lame excuses and the feint that it is reasonable after all. It says: 'We are unilaterally determining the contracts but surely you can trust us . We are the elected Government. The people trust us. The people even think that our Prime Minister is doing a reasonably good job; they give him a high public polling rate'. In legislation before the Parliament we should not be put off by reassurances about the present situation; we should look hard and coldly at the powers that are directly conferred by the legislation. That power gives a Federal Minister for Health unilateral coercion in determining all the contracts in public hospitals for medical practitioners.

What is the history of the negotiations that have led to the present impasse between the Federal Government and the medical profession? What has made medical practitioners leave their hospitals, surgeries and private rooms to march in the streets and even talk about industrial action that would deny their services in situations other than emergencies? After the Medicare legislation became law in the last quarter of last year an initial draft was put forward by the Minister for Health of the guidelines for the determination of the contracts. Those guidelines were discussed by the Minister and representatives of the Australian Medical Association. Offence was taken to the prescriptions in that first draft. A second draft of guidelines was put forward which, nevertheless, determined ceilings for the amounts that both salaried doctors in public hospitals and private visiting practitioners might earn.

I must say as a Liberal senator that, on the face of it, I do not see any offence in there being such guidelines or contracts. I do not see any offence in the arena of possibilities that have been widely discussed in public. Certainly they were available to us. There was no secret about the various proposed guidelines along the way. The public is concerned that there be cost limitations in any public scheme and the public and the Parliament are concerned that there be such guidelines and contracts. What is missing in all of this is that, in the first and second drafts, there was no ability for the medical profession to play an equal part in the determination of those contracts. They were not seriously regarded by the Minister. In this way there was offence to every established practice of determining contracts for providing services in Australia. In no other area of employment and in no other profession has there been such unilateral coercion.

On 11 January a third step was taken in addition to the second draft. The Minister said: 'The AMA and I cannot agree. Although I have the power to coerce you there will be trouble probably if I try to do that'. So on 11 January the Minister said: 'We will set up an independent inquiry into all these matters. It will be headed by Professor Penington, the dean of the medicine faculty at the University of Melbourne'. That was fine. In the meantime with whatever wisdom the Penington Inquiry into Rights of Private Practice in Public Hospitals may bring down in the months ahead this legislation is still offensive, even with the squib of an amendment which the Government is putting forward to provide for parliamentary disallowance.

As this third step in the negotiations proceeded into January, the medical profession became more alarmed and started to distrust the Federal Minister and the Federal Government. Doctors were also reminded that the Federal Minister, Dr Blewett, had, in earlier statements, said that he was a fabian in his revolutionary approaches to reorganising the medical profession. There was such public support for a fee for service medical system in Australia that he, a Labor Minister, the Labor Government and the Labor movement generally felt they should not take on too quickly the abolition of the fee for service approach and a private medical system in Australia but move slowly and gradually towards the complete socialisation of the medical profession in Australia.

Thus in January the medical profession's trust in the Federal Minister and the Federal Government had evaporated and it saw substance in those fears about the real intentions, the hidden agenda and the goals of this Government. It does not want to see the deterioration of medical services in Australia that inevitably would follow a wholesale socialisation of health arrangements. Therefore, the profession said that it would dig its heels in on this matter and that it would not be tempted just by a squib that would allow parliamentary disallowance. It said that like every other profession in Australia it wanted to be involved in the determining of that contract that is to bind its members' term of service in public hospitals. In that principle I support the medical profession.

I appeal to Ministers on the other side of the chamber not to put up in debate the argument that the guidelines are reasonable after all, and that such guidelines and contracts only allow public accountability, reasonableness and fairness, because I would agree with all that. All I am saying is that this principle has still escaped the Government and the Australian Democrats in this debate: It is a matter of there not being unilateral coercion of the medical profession by unilaterally determined contracts. What reasons have been put forward by the Labor Government for its unilateral determination of contracts? First, it has said that it will spend $2,000 billion in reimbursing the costs of medical and hospital treatments and that because it is providing the money it knows all about it and can unilaterally determine the best way to spend it and to ensure that it does not go beyond a reasonable ceiling. As Senator Peter Baume has already pointed out, there is not an open-ended ceiling on any cost to any one medical practitioner for any one item of health procedure. There is a schedule fee with regard to every item. Medicare arrangements allow only 85 per cent of that schedule fee to be paid in respect of any item, so there is not an open-ended ceiling.

A second reason given by the Government was that an expert inquiry that looked into the efficiency and administration of hospitals directly recommended that it do this. That is the gloss the Government puts on the Jamison Commission of Inquiry into the Efficiency and Administration of Hospitals which the former Liberal Government instituted, and rightly so. We welcome the generality of the conclusions of the Jamison Inquiry. But it is not the case that Jamison recommended exactly what the Government is doing. In the second reading speech last Friday, recommendations 109, 111, 112 and 113 of that Inquiry's report were quoted. These four recommendations all bear upon this matter, but not one of them or any other finding of the Jamison Inquiry recommended the abolition of private practice in public hospitals. On page 952 of Hansard, the Minister is reported as saying:
This is why it is nonsense for the AMA and the Opposition to object to the Commonwealth Government having a say in the conditions under which doctors are employed in public hospitals.
As I have already made clear, this Government has no intention of abolishing rights of private practice arrangements in public hospitals, despite the recommendation of the Jamison inquiry.
The Minister is implying that Jamison recommended the abolition of private practice. That is not what the Jamison Inquiry found. There is no talk of abolition at all, but rather--

TALK.START.PARA: —Read recommendation 111.
—I will read it. It reads:

SPEECH.PARA: Steps be taken to phase out over a period of years the right of private practice for full time salaried specialists.

TALK.START.PARA: —What is wrong with that? We are not even doing that.

—But the predominance of medical practitioners treating private patients in public hospitals are visiting private medical practitioners. The gloss is made in the same way Senator Grimes has made it just now in the interjection, that this whole matter is about salaried doctors already on the public payroll in the public hospitals. But it is not; it is only partly about them. Even the first and second drafts of the guidelines say reasonably that the private patients of full time salaried officers should allow payments not exceeding 25 per cent in excess of the already determined salary of those public employees. That may be reasonable. I am not arguing about the particularity of it, but I am arguing with the Government that twists into the words of the so- called expert inquiry, the Jamison Inquiry, conclusions which are not there. I see this and I could instance it in other ways. The expert inquiry certainly recommended that there be discussion towards such guidelines and contracts. It did not recommend abolition and it did not recommend unilateral coercion by a government without the medical profession being involved in the determination of these contracts.

SPEECH.PARA: A third reason that the Government put forward is that the AMA has been unreasonable. The Government says: 'We have tried over all these months to discuss this matter with the AMA but we have unilaterally to coerce the AMA now because it is unreasonable'. What a limp set of examples are put forward in the Minister's speech. The one matter to which the AMA has been resolutely opposed is its total exclusion from the process of determining the contracts. The more it understood that that principle was totally transgressed by current legislation, the more it dug in its heels. But on all the details, the Association was entirely co-operative and allowed discussion. It heard the first draft and moved to the second draft. It agreed to participate in the Penington Inquiry. Even today, the AMA is in consultations to try to find an answer to this impasse. The one principle in this debate which is constantly a matter of difficulty is that the Federal Government will not allow a departure from the unilateral coercion that it has arrogantly put upon itself to determine these contracts. In this matter I, as a Liberal senator, and the Opposition concur with the medical profession as we would with any other profession involved in the determining of the contracts for employment or for services.

Other reasons the Government gives for this unilateral determination of contracts muddy the arguments and blur the distinctions by bringing in particularities about money and by implying some kind of greedy, money grubbing medical profession which plays to the basest jealousy instincts in any people, not only Australians. I detest such appeals, such blurrings, and believe that it is not in any way constructive for the Government to put such arguments forward. The Government is blackmailing the medical profession by this stranglehold of saying: 'Your patients will be denied Medicare payments if you do not sign these contracts'. I believe the public should be entirely sympathetic to the doctors for not signing these contracts because the signing of them would mean accepting that a Federal Minister remote in Canberra could arrogantly and unilaterally coerce doctors to accept contracts without their having any say in the terms of those contracts. Whilst we look to the positive and constructive outcomes of the Penington Inquiry, the chance is before us now by supporting the Opposition amendment to win that matter of principle here and now in the Senate.
Sitting suspended from 6.30 to 8 p.m.

TALK.START.PARA: —For most of the afternoon the Senate has tried to press upon the Government that the present dispute with the medical profession which it has brought upon itself has a remedy, and that remedy is to allow the medical profession to be involved in the process of determining the contracts that will guide its service to the public in public hospitals. In the determination of the contracts we need to go much further than the squib of the amendment that the Government has before the Senate which would allow only parliamentary scrutiny of those contracts. The Government must go further and allow a genuine departure from its arrogance to provide unilateral coercion of contracts upon the medical profession.

SPEECH.PARA: The public of Australia is directly concerned today, as it was yesterday and throughout the last few weeks, about the possibility of the dislocation of health services in the country. The surest remedy of that possibility is to go much further than this small amendment to section 17 of the Health Insurance Act and genuinely to allow the medical profession of Australia to play its full part , along with the Federal Government, the State governments and public hospitals as institutions, in the determination of those contracts. Let us not hear in the Senate distractions and statements that the public can trust the Government to be fair or reasonable. We are not assured by such appeals in the present circumstance. What we want is to see that in section 17 of the Health Insurance Act there is a direct ability for the medical profession, the Australian Medical Association, like every other employee or person who provides a service in the country, to take its full part properly in the determination of the contracts under which it is to work in public hospitals.

If the Government takes the position that has been put forward by Senator Baume and all the rest of us from the Opposition who have spoken today, we will go much further than this small squib to a genuine amendment of section 17 which will allow this impasse with the medical profession which the Government has brought upon itself to be resolved so that the public will not suffer the consequences of any lockout as a result of these unilaterally declared contracts by the Government. I conclude by urging Senator Grimes and other Ministers of this Government to give proper ear to the medical profession of Australia.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —One may be surprised to realise that what we are debating in the Senate-as Senator Teague says, we debated it for hours this afternoon-is a Bill called the Health Insurance Amendment Bill 1984 (No. 2). The debate has ranged far and wide, as do all health debates in this place. I have some knowledge of them because I believe I have taken part in every debate in this chamber on a health Bill or a health insurance Bill since 1974. Everyone in this chamber seems to be an expert on health. Certainly everyone is an expert on health insurance. Every time we have a Bill to amend the health insurance or health legislation in this country, no matter how small the amendment is, we have a full debate on health insurance and health care delivery generally. That debate always brings forward the same phrases and rhetoric from members of the Opposition. I listed just a few of them this afternoon. We were told that the Bill represents the nationalisation, either directly or indirectly, of the health industry in this country. Senator Walters called it back door nationalisation.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Teague talked about socialising the medical profession. If it were just a case of socialising the profession I would not mind too much, but he talked about coercion and all those terrible things that are happening to the medical profession in this country. Senator Baume even talked about elements of the debate. He was the first speaker after the second reading speech, which was a very mild speech. He talked about the class hatred that honourable senators on this side of the chamber have for the medical profession. He even described the Minister for Health, Dr Blewett, as being a member of the socialist Left. I can tell honourable senators that that is news not only to Dr Blewett but also to the socialist Left. We heard about a hidden agenda which would somehow, by this back door method, nationalise the health industry in this country. We heard stories of how the Government was, by this legislation, making bulk billing compulsory and so on. I have been listening to that stuff for years. We have all been listening to that stuff for years. I wish people would find some new words to use to describe what is going on.

Senator Baume started off by saying that the amendment in this legislation, which I will actually come to in a minute, was an example of political expediency by the Government. He said that it was not the Government's amendment or Senator Haines's amendment; it was his amendment; it was the amendment that he moved when this legislation was before the chamber, I think, last December.

TALK.START.PARA: —September.

—Perhaps it was September. He said that in the different circumstances which face us and the health consumers in this country the Government would have been guilty of a terrible crime of political expediency in accepting Senator Haines's suggestion which he claimed for his own. Before I deal with that point I indicate that if we want an example of political expediency in the health debates which have taken place in this Parliament, let us look back to 1975 when Senator Baume, who was usually the lead speaker on the other side, opposed vigorously the imposition of a levy to fund health insurance in this country. Sir John Kerr used that legislation as a reason for a double dissolution. When the legislation came back two months later the Parliament passed a Bill to put down a levy to pay for health insurance in this country. If honourable senators want to look at political expediency, I invite them to look at that. To top that off, Senator Baume spent a quarter of an hour saying that it was not Senator Haines's amendment or the Government's amendment; it was his amendment; he moved it, as Senator Teague told me, last September.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Teague said that the Government was moving a damp squib of an amendment . He said that the Opposition and the medical profession oppose it; it is an awful amendment. To give one further example of the sort of nonsense that goes on in this place, Senator Walters, that great defender of the medical profession in general-I am usually a defender of the medical profession-but the medical profession of Tasmania in particular, said it was outrageous that the Government should want to ask doctors who have intermediate patients, as she described them , in hospital to charge the schedule fee. She said that was an outrageous proposition. When I said to her that such a situation already exists in Tasmania she said that I was wrong and that I did not know about this.

I have before me an agreement between the Board of Management of the Royal Hobart Hospital, in legal terms otherwise known as the Board, and the medical practitioner whose name is in the schedule, the medical practitioner who works at the Royal Hobart Hospital, known in this agreement as the doctor. Clause 7 of the document says:
The Board will:

(a) in the name of the Doctor charge the intermediate patients of the Doctors fees for medical, pathological, radiological and other diagnostic services performed by him/her according to the specified fee as prescribed from time to time in Schedule 1 of the Health Insurance Act 1973 . . .

The doctors signed that document to ensure that the fee charged was the schedule fee. The document was signed on 7 October 1983, just a few months ago. Senator Walters said that the doctors did not sign any such document. It is a voluntary agreement. The document was signed by four members of the medical profession elected by the medical profession to sign it. The doctors who agree with it and those who work in the Royal Hobart Hospital and every other public hospital in Tasmania are listed on the back of the schedule, although I point out that I do not have a copy of it here deliberately. The doctors in Tasmania signed the document, thereby agreeing that only the schedule fee would be charged by them. We are told that it was signed by those four doctors on their behalf and on behalf of every doctor in the State.

We are told that members on this side of the Parliament indulge in doctor bashing, that we are terrible people, that we do not like the medical profession , that we are not representative of the medical profession, and that the medical profession does not like us. I make one point in that regard: Since I have been a member of this Parliament-I think I have it right because I thought about it while having my evening meal-11 medical practitioners have been members of this Parliament. There is Dr Jenkins, the Speaker of the House of Representatives, Dr Charlesworth who is currently the honourable member for Perth, Dr Everingham, the honourable member for Capricornia, Dr Klugman, the honourable member for Prospect, Senator Crowley-I notice that she was called Senator Growley by Senator Walters- and me. In recent years other medical practitioners who have been members of this Parliament have been Dr Cass, the honourable member for Maribyrnong in Victoria, and Dr Gunn, the honourable member for Kingston in South Australia. That makes a total of eight medical practitioners.

There have been three other doctors in the Parliament. Senator Baume has been a member of Parliament for as long as I have. All honourable members will remember Senator Sheil. He was here for a few years too. He was the shortest serving Cabinet Minister in this country. Dr Richardson was a member of the other place. He lasted only a couple of years. He then left the Liberal Party and joined the Workers Party or the Progress Party. Eight doctors have come from this side. With the exception of Senator Baume, not many of those from the other side were in the parliament for very long. We on this side of the Parliament are not doctor bashers. Anyone who has the cheek to criticise any aspect of the medical profession in this place is accused by Senator Walters, Senator Sir John Carrick and God knows who else aroung the place of being doctor bashers. What we want is a fair system of health insurance in this country. What we want eventually is a fair system of the delivery of health services in this country.

All afternoon a great deal of nonsense has been spoken in the debate. I suppose as the Minister replying to the debate I should mention some of the matters that have been raised, even though they have little relevance to the Bill before the House-a Bill that I point out to honourable senators seeks to make only a few amendments. Firstly, it seeks to amend section 17 by inserting a new sub-section for the purpose of enabling the Minister, if he is satisfied that the laws of a State or Territory, or agreements or arrangements entered into under such laws, are such as will regulate the rendering of a prescribed professional service in a manner consistent with the guidelines, to sign an instrument exempting a medical practitioner from the requirement to enter into an agreement of the kind referred to. In other words, doctors in those States or Territories do not have to sign anything. They have to come to an agreement with the State Government or the Territory Government. That is what the amendment is about. It was on that point that Senator Teague demonstrated his profound ignorance. The Federal Minister is not a party to such contract. He determines the conditions under which Medicare benefits are paid and he comes to an agreement with the States-it is not a two-party agreement-about what shall be in those contracts. He lays down a set of guidelines, and no one in this country would think that those guidelines were unreasonable.

The second amendment seeks to insert new sub-sections (5), (6), (7) and (8) at the end of section 17. These provisions will enable the guidelines that have been made by the Minister under section 17 and any guidelines that the Minister makes in the future to be disallowed by the Parliament in the same way as a statutory rule may be disallowed. It was in this regard that Senator Walters got herself into diabolical trouble. Senator Walters says it is a cheek to require the doctors to have their regulations or guidelines scrutinised by this Parliament because the people of this country might actually change the complexion of the Parliament. It is her view that the doctors should not be dictated to by the elected representatives of the people of this country, that the doctors are above that. She then said-I urge people to read in Hansard what she said-that when Senator Cavanagh was a member of this Parliament he did not allow that sort of attitude to prevail because Senator Cavanagh used to insist that the Parliament express its views on regulations that Ministers laid down. I urge people to read in Hansard the speech of Senator Walters and to note her logic and the circular argument that she advanced this afternoon. It was extraordinary. She told us what a great fellow Jimmy Cavanagh was. We all agree that he was.
