She told us that he used to insist that Ministers did not have the right to lay down regulations or guidelines without Parliament having an opportunity to express its view.

The proposed amendments provide-pro tem perhaps, depending on the Penington report-for the Parliament, and the Senate in particular, to have those powers. Senator Walters got lost somewhere in her argument. She then said that doctors are really frightened that this Parliament or the Labor Government will suddenly want to freeze the schedule fee. The Government has given a public guarantee to the medical profession that it will review the schedule fee on a regular basis. The only government to freeze the schedule fee was the former Liberal-National Party Government which, as a part of its national policy, froze the schedule fee without negotiation with the medical profession-the Australian Medical Association, the Doctors Reform Society, the General Practitioners Society, the Society of Surgeons or any one of the multiplicity of medical groups in this country. Senator Teague and his colleagues have the cheek to say that this Government does not know anything about industrial relations and that it intends to do something unilaterally, when the only example of unilateral behaviour in recent times was provided by the former Liberal-National Party Government.

The proposed amendments ensure that there will be parliamentary scrutiny of the guidelines brought forward by the Minister. They ensure in fact that in cases where there is a satisfactory agreement with the States the doctors will not have to put their shaking hands to these terrible documents. Senator Baume did not think much of this proposal at all. He pointed out that only doctors can deliver the services that they deliver. I thought that was a fairly obvious statement to make. He said that the system will not operate without them. He said that if the Government did not agree with the system that the doctors wanted they would withdraw their services and this country would not have a health scheme. I would have thought that was the sort of threat that Senator Baume would not like to hear made by the trade unions in this country.

I am reminded of an occasion in this place in 1974. In 1974 Senator Peter Baume got up in this place and said that the doctors in this country would co-operate with anyone except the Australian Labor Party. He got a very good run. He got a run in the Doctors Reform Society journal and all over the country by saying that medical practitioners would co-operate with anyone but the Australian Labor Party. But he is wrong. The medical practitioners in this country, particularly the general practitioners, and more particularly general practitioners working in some rural areas and in disadvantaged areas of this country, will co-operate with the Australian Labor Party because they know what a universal health insurance system gives to their patients; it is the guarantee that they can have access to a health service. What it gives to the doctors is the guarantee that they can deliver those health services without being worried about whether the patient can afford to pay to see a doctor.

Senator Baume talked about the costs to the taxpayer and how limiting doctors to the schedule fee in hospital services would not affect the total cost of health care to the taxpayer because the rebate is limited to the schedule fee. Of course, I have no argument with him about that. But what this Government has to be concerned about and what every government should be concerned about in this country is not only the cost to the taxpayer, which of course is important, but the cost to individual patients and the cost to people who have to go to those hospitals.

If we allow even a few private medical practitioners in public hospitals to use facilities provided by taxpayers' money-as I have said on other occasions, using skills that they acquired at the expense of the taxpayers-and to charge people beyond that fee, the burden falls on those individual patients, and no government should allow that. Any government, be it conservative, Labor or whatever, which provides the amount of money which this Government does to public hospitals in this country under Australia's health scheme without, as I think Mr Justice Kirby said, some strings attached and some accountability, is acting irresponsibly.

That leads me to Senator Haines, who quickly pointed out that although Senator Baume initially started to talk about principles, what in fact he talked about was money. That is what it is about and that is what it has been about all the time. Throughout this long dispute between this Government and some members of the medical profession in this country, we have heard about the lack of appeal not against the contracts but against the broad guidelines under which the State governments can, if they like, provide contracts or regulations. This legislation provides that appeal. The Penington Committee of Inquiry into the Rights of Private Practice in Public Hospitals has as part of its terms of reference to look at the forms of appeal. The Government has said that it will assist the medical profession in providing to the Penington inquiry evidence about how an appeal should be set up. The Government has said that when the Penington inquiry brings down its findings it will accept them. But the Australian Medical Association has accepted none of those things except that it will gratefully accept the Government's assistance in putting its case to the Penington inquiry.

We have had changes to the terms of reference of the Penington inquiry since it was first announced on 24 January this year. On 9 February the terms of reference of that inquiry were widened. Eventually on 16 February the AMA agreed to take part in that inquiry. That is the only concession it has made. On 2 March the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) and Dr Blewett talked to members of the medical profession and agreed that there would be no change to the guidelines until after the Penington inquiry. They agreed to accept the decisions of the Penington inquiry but it was because of the hopeless situation which was arising , because of the situation in which the AMA could not bring some of its so- called troops into order-although I believe senior officers of the AMA wanted to accept it-that we accepted Senator Haines's proposal that any guidelines brought in by the Minister should be subject to the scrutiny of this Parliament. We even got rid of the section which expressed the need for doctors to sign, in those States where the regulations provided for it, that they would charge no more than the schedule fee.

We have the quite ludicrous situation in which most practitioners who are concerned with this legislation do not charge any more than the schedule fee anyway; in some States they have in fact signed contracts, as I have demonstrated in relation to Tasmania, that they will not charge any more than the schedule fee. In Queensland they would love to have the right to charge the schedule fee and love to have the right of private practice that medical practitioners in other States have. All we are doing in this legislation is making some concessions to members of the medical profession so that they will stop this nonsense about going on strike and will do what they are trained to do and what they really want to do; that is, to go into public hospitals and treat patients in the way in which they are supposed to treat them.

TALK.START.PARA: —They want a say.

—They have a say. They have endless access to the Minister for Health. They have access to their State Ministers. They have access to the boards of the hospitals in which they work. What more do they want? Yet we had this extraordinary series of speeches tonight and this afternoon about this legislation.

SPEECH.PARA: I must make passing reference to the speech by Senator Sir John Carrick because I know everyone would be disappointed if I did not. Senator Sir John Carrick does not appear very often in health debates in this place. He used to in the old days and it was nice to hear him again. He gave a mixture of what might be called the free market theory of medicine and the theology of States' rights. He said that the best way to deliver medical services in this country was through the free market. I do not know how many times I have said it in this place but I will bore everyone again by pointing out that one cannot have a free market if either the purchaser or the seller does not have some idea, in fact a full idea, of what the market situation is. In the majority of cases the patient does not have a clue. First of all, in most cases patients cannot make a choice of whether to make the purchase or not; they are sick. The second point is that they do not know enough about the services because they do not have the skills or the knowledge. Governments throughout the world have had to interfere in the so-called free market of health services.

Then Sir John Carrick, for heavens sake, told us we should not interfere in this area because it is a traditional area of States' rights; that States look after State hospitals and the specialists in those hospitals. But the States get the money from the Federal Government in these circumstances. The Federal Government in general reimburses the States for the services provided to those patients. We have the extraordinary situation of Senator Sir John Carrick saying that the only duty of the Federal Government is to pour a big bucket of money down that funnel and not care about what happens at the other end of it. Some of the States would certainly like this situation to apply.

All the Federal Government is saying is that we want some say in the guidelines of how those doctors work. We do not really differ very much from the recommendations of the Jamison Commission of Inquiry into the Efficiency and Administration of Hospitals. The Jamison inquiry was established by the previous Government. Senator Teague was very keen to quote the report of the Jamison inquiry.

TALK.START.PARA: —But you do differ.
—I do not differ. The Jamison inquiry made several recommendations. As Senator Teague did a bit of selective quoting, we ought to look at the recommendations. Re- commendation 109 reads:

SPEECH.PARA: There be an urgent review by each of the employment authorities of rights to private practice in hospitals with a view to limiting its scope, consistent with the underlying intent of the contract between an individual patient and doctor.
Recommendation 111 states:
Steps be taken to phase out over a period of years the right of private practice for full time salaried specialists.
Recommendation 112 states:
Action be taken to improve the awareness of all medical practitioners of the medical value and cost of tests, not only for pathology but for all diagnostic services.
Recommendation 113 states:
Guidelines be issued by health authorities on the utilisation of radiology, pathology and pharmacy services.

These are strong recommendations, as Dr Blewett said, from what was generally accepted as being a pretty conservative report. All that Dr Blewett and this Government are asking is that we have a series of guidelines which firstly limit the amount of money in some cases which people can take out of hospitals from their privileged position of using public hospitals for private purposes and, secondly-and I repeat this, as I have repeated it over and over again in this place-that in using publicly funded facilities, machinery, buildings and staff which are funded by the taxpayer, they charge the schedule fee which, as Senator Crowley pointed out this afternoon, is a negotiated fee determined by a judge, representatives of the medical profession, consumers and anyone else who wants to put his case. How much more reasonable can one be? I am sorry to disappoint Senator Teague but we are being reasonable and we have been reasonable. The Adelaide News, that radical socialist newspaper which, apart from its right wing tendencies, at one stage had Mr Jim Killen and me both dead in the Royal Adelaide Hospital, pointed out that the doctors were being unreasonable, that the Government had made all the concessions and that if the doctors did not go along with the Government Hippocrates would turn in his grave. I suppose that is not a bad way of putting it even if it involves a bit of hyperbole. Politicians have been known to be guilty of that too.

This is a reasonable bit of legislation. Senator Baume thought it was reasonable when he introduced his amendment some months ago. When Senator Haines said: 'Look, this situation is getting impossible; why don't you accept this bit of legislation' we said 'Yes, we will accept it; we have gone a long way but we will accept it because we cannot let the patients suffer'. When we do all that Senator Teague comes in and says: 'The original idea of Senator Baume is a damp squib'. One cannot win in this game. But I believe that in the end the patients must win, the Government must win, the consumers in this country must win and those unreasonable members of my profession must lose. Once they become reasonable, get down to negotiate and put their cases to the Penington Committee of Inquiry into the Rights of Private Practice in Public Hospitals-if they accept the findings of that inquiry, that is all the better-we will have a sensible resolution of this situation. This small bit of legislation, which has caused such a fuss in this place this afternoon in fact is a small step along the track to that resolution. I do not accept Senator Baume's amendment, first of all because I do not agree with it and, secondly, because I think it is a bit of an effrontery for someone to come into this place and say: 'Don't accept the Government's legislation; accept my private member's Bill next week'. So we oppose the amendment and urge the Senate to accept the legislation.
Question put:
That the words proposed to be left out (Senator Peter Baume's amendment) be left out.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the negative.

SPEECH.PARA: Original question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.

PROCTEXT.PARA: The Bill.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition has a couple of amendments it wishes to move in Committee. It seemed unnecessary to proceed otherwise than to take the Bill as a whole. I begin by asking the Minister for Social Security (Senator Grimes) for advice. Clause 2 says that the Act shall come into operation on the day on which it receives royal assent. In the event that royal assent is not received for, say, another 12 or 13 sitting days and the time for possible disallowance of the guidelines which have already appeared has passed, will the Parliament lose the opportunity to disallow the guidelines which have already been brought in?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think I gather the gist of the question. The Bill provides:

SPEECH.PARA: The requirement to lay the guidelines before each House of the Parliament shall be taken to be complied with if the guidelines are so laid within 15 sitting days of that House after the date of commencement of the Act.
I do not understand Senator Baume's problem. The commencement of the Act is after the day of royal assent.

TALK.START.PARA: —Does the Government intend to lay before each House of Parliament the guidelines which have already been introduced?
—Yes.
—So that it will be possible for the Parliament to consider the guidelines which have already come forward, but which are yet to be laid before the Parliament.
—Yes.

—May I ask further whether clause 3, as proposed, will have the effect of, as it were, deeming most doctors in certain States to have complied with the conditions laid down by the Minister even though they do not sign contracts? If the conflict in the medical profession is about the signing of contracts, will this provide a mechanism for avoiding the matter reaching the crunch point, as it were?

—Yes, my understanding is that that is so. One of the purposes of the legislation is to allow the Minister to do that in those States where regulations under which people are employed will cover the situation that we want to see covered. Therefore, they will not have to sign those pieces of paper.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Minister for those explanations. The amendments we wish to move have a different purpose. We believe that while the Penington Committee of Inquiry into the Rights of Private Practice in Public Hospitals is on, we should seek to remove paragraph (1) (aa) from section 17 and also sub-sections (2), (3) and (4). Those are the provisions about which most of the argument has taken place. The Senate was kind enough to allow me to make a second reading speech last week when I discussed this matter more fully. I shall not take up the Committee's time now. Therefore, I seek leave to move amendments (1) and (2) together since they both give effect to what is being proposed in the Bill. I think it would be helpful if the Committee could dispose of them together.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (1) Page 1, clause 2, lines 9 and 10, leave out all words after 'shall', insert 'be deemed to have come into operation on 1 February 1984'.
(2) Pages 2 and 3, clause 3, leave out the clause, insert the following clauses :
Medical benefit not payable in respect of certain medical expenses
'3. Section 17 of the Principal Act is amended-
(a) by omitting paragraph (1) (aa); and
(b) by omitting sub-sections (2), (3) and (4).
Heads of Agreement
'4. Schedule 2 to the Principal Act is amended by omitting clause 6.'.

These amendments give effect to the major part of the private member's Bill about which I spoke in the Senate last week. The amendments would remove those parts of section 17 for the present time. This would mean that those provisions would not be in the Act while the Penington inquiry was considering the matter. I commend the amendments to the Committee.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government opposes the amendments. In fact, the amendments more or less oppose the purpose of the legislation. The Government has given guarantees to the profession in some of these respects. We do not believe that the amendments are a reasonable way to proceed. The Government believes that this legislation is as far as we can go pending the report of the Penington inquiry.

SPEECH.PARA: Question put:
That the amendments (Senator Peter Baume's) be agreed to.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the negative.

TALK.START.PARA: —Now that the Committee has decided not to accept the amendments moved by the Opposition I would like to make it clear that the Opposition will be supporting the Bill because the provisions which are in it are, as we have said throughout, an advance on what was there. The amendment we moved last year is one which we support. We said it was not sufficient but it was an improvement. It seems to me that the most interesting part of this Bill, however, is not the provision for disallowance, which I say we are supporting, but the other provision which gives the Government a capacity now to avoid the confrontation with the medical profession simply by not requiring contracts to be signed. If that is the case it may be that the Government, if it makes the appropriate declaration in most of the States, may avoid the need for signing contracts, and this may avoid an imminent lock-out. As for the Territories, I understand that these new provisions will make it unnecessary for contracts to be signed in the Australian Capital Territory. I think this change in circumstance is something we would draw to the attention of medical practitioners. The Opposition will now certainly support the provisions for disallowance in the Bill.

—I thank the Committee. I thank Senator Baume for supporting the legislation at this stage. What the Government has been about all along is ensuring that the doctors charge no more than the schedule fee for the services provided in the manners in which they have been described in this legislation. As Senator Baume has implied, in those States and Territories where regulations or other legislation provide that that be done there is no need for people to sign contracts. I think it is extraordinary that we have gone through the trauma we have between the medical profession and the Government or anyone else over people being unwilling to sign contracts which in some cases are even more generous than the conditions they work under at the moment. I thank the Opposition for its co-operation at this stage.

—Mr Chairman, apparently earlier this evening in the second reading debate Senator Baume accused me of indulging in doctor bashing. I think the reason he did that was a question I asked last week about treatment Senator Georges had received after an unfortunate accident last week. I asked Senator Grimes whether it was true that Senator Georges could not get X-rayed at the Canberra hospital because of industrial action. I was wrong and Senator Grimes told me at the time that Senator Georges could not get his X- rays read. I was given the facts by people I trusted. I asked the question and received an answer and a correction. I really do not see what is wrong with that , especially as Senator Baume on 5 March made a speech about my colleague Senator Richardson in which he stated as fact things that he knew were not true. I asked a question and I was corrected by Senator Grimes. I hardly think that would qualify in the circumstances as doctor bashing.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Sibraa, I accepted that really as a personal explanation. It is barely relevant to the clauses of the Bill. In the circumstances I accepted it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: Page 2, after clause 3, insert the following new clause:
'3A. After section 35 of the Principal Act the following section is inserted in Division 1 of Part V:

Criteria for granting special leave to appeal ''35A. In considering whether to grant an application for special leave to appeal to the High Court under this Act or under any other Act, the High Court may have regard to any matters that it considers relevant but shall have regard to- (a) whether the proceedings in which the judgment to which the application relates was pronounced involve a question of law- (i) that is of public importance, whether because of its general application or otherwise; or

(ii) in respect of which a decision of the High Court, as the final appellate court, is required to resolve differences of opinion between different courts, or within the one court, as to the state of the law; and

Page 4, clause 6, proposed sub-section 55 (ii), line 15, after 'commencement of ' insert 'section 6 of'.

The second of the two is a purely technical amendment. It is to clause 6 of the Bill. Instead of referring simply to 'commencement of' the legislation, it refers to 'commencement of section 6 of' the legislation. I cannot imagine that that would cause any difficulty.

The more substantial amendment is one that has been the subject of a great deal of discussion between the parties and certainly as between the parties, the Government and the Law Council of Australia. While not exactly reflecting a consensus of views it does, I think, represent an agreed basic position, although some would wish to go further. What this amendment does is introduce a new section 35A into the Judiciary Amendment Act which articulates criteria for granting special leave to appeal. The language of the amendment is, I believe, self-explanatory. This amendment essentially articulates the two basic objectives, as it were, which I think we would all agree about, of special leave legislation; the two basic criteria which ought to determine whether the High Court of Australia accepts a case-namely, whether the matter of law in issue is one of public and general importance, and secondly, whatever may be the case as to the question of law, whether the whole circumstances of the particular case are such as to raise questions about the administration of justice either in this case or generally.

The basic arguments for rejecting other more precise and automatic criteria were spelt out at length by me in my second reading reply in this place last week. Similarly the reasons for opting for indicative criteria of this kind were also spelt out. I do not believe the amendment needs any further explanation from me so far as honourable senators are concerned. Should there be any further questions or discussion I will, of course, be happy to contribute further to the debate. I commend this amendment to the Committee.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition is not opposed to this amendment, although it does not think it is of much significance one way or the other. The High Court of Australia has evolved criteria on which it will grant special leave to appeal and I do not think that spelling out some of these criteria in the legislation will make one iota of difference to the way in which the High Court will continue to exercise its powers in that regard. Of more important consideration is how the High Court will exercise this now sole ground on which appeals to it can be brought. At present the High Court deals with these applications in Canberra, generally with a Bench of three judges. Many people are concerned that very rarely are reasons given and people get pretty short shrift when they appear before the High Court to seek special leave. Perhaps that is more justified in circumstances where there is an appeal as of right in a large number of cases.

SPEECH.PARA: As I have said, a number of concerns have been expressed. One is that the High Court deals with applications for special leave only in Canberra so that applicants or their counsel have to make the journey here. Certainly most come from Sydney or Melbourne but that is an expense in itself. Certainly for those litigants or counsel coming from, say, Perth, it is of great expense indeed. Then, if they are successful, they have to make another journey to Canberra for the actual hearing of the appeal. I know that in some cases the High Court will treat the applications for special leave as the hearing but no doubt there will be fewer cases in the future, as a proportion of the whole, when that facility will be provided. There is a very real concern about that aspect of the matter and I wonder whether the Attorney-General (Senator Gareth Evans) can give us some indication of what is proposed to be done about that.

Of importance to those in distant places like Perth, Hobart, Adelaide or even Brisbane is that the High Court now visits those places once a year but some concern has been expressed to me that if the High Court is to exercise jurisdiction only in cases of special leave, particularly if it has to sit outside Canberra more often to hear those applications, it might be more reluctant to sit regularly in those cities as it has done since it moved to Canberra. I would like an indication of the Government's view in relation to those two points I have raised.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I acknowledge the concerns expressed by Senator Durack, as indeed I did in my second reading reply . I can summarise my response to them as follows: So far as the expense which is undoubtedly involved in travelling, particularly twice, to Canberra for applications for special leave and then the subsequent appeal is concerned, as I indicated it is the case that the High Court has now agreed in principle, and the Government has agreed in principle, to have regular High Court sittings in both Sydney and Melbourne. It is just a question of working out the final administrative nuts and bolts but I hope it will be the case that in all but the most exceptional circumstances in future the applications for special leave coming from those two cities are heard in those cities rather than necessitating a separate journey. As to the more far-flung States, so far as I am concerned it is certainly not the case from anything I have heard that there will be any lessening of the number of visits paid by the High Court to those States and I cannot imagine where that particular suggestion may have emanated from. I do acknowledge that those visits are relatively few and far between and not such as to accommodate all those likely to be wanting to make special leave applications and it is in that context that I have said, and will say again, that we are exploring the application of modern technology, in particular video conference technology, as an alternative to incurring the very substantial costs involved in having counsel fly half way round the country for what might be a very short hearing. Certainly it is my desire in every conceivable way possible to reduce or remove the additional expense involved for litigants in adopting this change.

SPEECH.PARA: A further thing I can say about this, as again I said in my second reading reply, is that we will monitor closely the operation of this new provision and stand ready to review it in the event that any significant shortcomings are revealed. I imagine it would not be appropriate for any such review to take place in a period less than about two years in order to enable a proper trial to take place with appropriate statistics and so on being gathered in the interim, but in the event that any obvious shortcomings are revealed before that time I undertake to the Committee that we will act promptly to remedy them.

As to short shrift being given to applications for special leave, two points can be made: Firstly, it is certainly my desire that applicants be given reasons , so far as that is possible, by the Court for its decisions. I have engaged in discussions with the Court about how that might best be done, albeit outside the framework of legislative regulation. Secondly, and more particularly, I refer to the reason why a number of cases which perhaps ought to be taken by the High Court are not being taken at the moment. The reason why a significant number of disgruntled potential litigants is at the margin is simply that so much of the High Court's docket each term is taken up with appeals as of right.

The position taken by the Government, and I spelt out the statistical foundation for this position when I spoke last time, is that at the moment far too many cases which do not raise questions of law, of general public importance , or which do not involve questions of the administration of justice or an apparent miscarriage of justice in the circumstances of the particular case are occupying the time and attention of the High Court. As I said last time, those appeals as of right presently occupy something of the order of 40 or 50 per cent or in some years even 60 per cent of the total number of appeals being dealt with by the Court. It is the view of close observers of the Court that probably only a quarter of those appeals going up as of right at the moment involve points which would be considered by the Court, or by anyone else for that matter , to justify special leave being granted. If we whittled back in that way to the really serious and important cases the number presently going up and occupying the Court's time, there would obviously be that much more time available on the Court's docket each term to hear cases coming through the special leave application mechanism.

I am certainly confident that meritorious cases, those demanding attention at the level of the highest court in the land, will be heard and determined by the Court on a greater scale than has been the case. Again that is something about which it is difficult to make confident assertions at this stage. Maybe it is something about which we need the further test of experience. I simply repeat that we are willing to expose this legislation to the test of experience and review it very carefully after the operation of a couple of years of that experience. I hope that honourable senators will appreciate the reasons that the Government, in consultation with the Court and following extensive discussions with all the relevant professional interests, has taken the position it has on this. It seemed to us that there simply were not any justifiable grounds for any one or other of the automatic appeal criteria that have been advanced. We needed to opt for a discretionary approach to this matter. The guidance that has been given by this new clause which I moved, even if not representing any particular change to the law-I agree with what Senator Durack said in that respect-at least will represent significant additional guidance to the Court in the exercise of its discretion, and that can be no bad thing.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not wish to raise again the matters that I raised at the second reading stage and to which the Attorney-General ( Senator Gareth Evans) responded. I wish to raise just a perhaps minor thing. Why do we still retain the term 'special leave'? I understand that leave is granted by lower courts and special leave is granted by the High Court of Australia, but the High Court can grant leave only once. Why do we continue to call it special leave? Why cannot we just call it leave?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is a good question from Senator Harradine and not one to which we have addressed any attention. Being an essentially conservative administration, we have decided to simply follow tradition in this respect. As it has been called 'special leave' since the High Court of Australia was formed in 1903, we did not want to generate any undue sense of uncertainty or disarray in the establishments around this nation that we were confronting in any head-on way the traditions of the Court. Perhaps this is a matter that we will summon up courage to address when we move into a more radical mode later in our administration. I will test the reaction of the High Court to Senator Harradine's suggestion. We are all in favour of simplification and the shortening and streamlining of language. Redundant terminology is involved here. I appreciate the point he has raised. We will have a look at it.

Advance Australia Logo Protection Bill
Advance Australia Logo Protection Bill
Advance Australia Logo Protection Bill

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Rae Sen P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: — The Advance Australia Logo Protection Bill which we will debate briefly, as I understand it, proposes to regulate the use of the Advance Australia logo. The ultimate aim of the Advance Australia campaign is to stimulate demand for Australia goods and services and to stimulate a recognition, both in Australia and elsewhere, of the quality of Australian goods, of the desirability of the acquisition of Australian manufactured goods and of the development of some national pride in that which this country can produce. The campaign was started in about 1978 under a former colleague, the former Senator Sir Robert Cotton, who had been Minister for Industry and Commerce. It has developed from there to the stage where, today, the Advance Australia logo is widely used. Looking at the achievements of that campaign, one recognises that a large number of the ambitions of the former coalition Government in stimulating interest and pride in Australian workmanship , capacity and products have been achieved.

SPEECH.PARA: There was a demand for the products and a need to protect the logo from misuse on products which may not have been of the necessary quality and may not even have been manufactured in Australia. Steps have been taken to do two things which were announced in the latter part of the year before last under the former Minister for Industry and Commerce in the coalition Government; namely, to make the Advance Australia campaign self-supporting and to remove it from being a cost to revenue, a cost to the taxpayer. It reached the stage, after the expenditure of some $5.14m of taxpayers' funds to 30 June 1983, where it was possible to license the use of the logo, to charge fees for the licences and for the whole of the campaign to become self-supporting. In other words, it is one of the success stories of a government sponsored development of national pride and of a user pays principle being applied where public funds have been used to get the thing going and, having got going, it has become self-supporting.

The provisions of this legislation which the Opposition supports are: To regulate the use of the Advance Australia logo in order to prevent undermining the objectives of the Advance Australia campaign; to grant monopoly use of the logo for copyright purposes to the Advance Australia company; to enable legal action to be taken for infringement of copyright; to provide safeguard provisions to protect the Commonwealth's interest and investment in the campaign ; to provide for the copyright to revert to the Commonwealth when the company winds up; and for it to be enforced for the usual period of 16 years from 31 October 1983. That situation will become a reality with the passage of this Bill .

The Bill provides for two sorts of licences. The first is a non-exclusive licence to use the logo where 0.1 per cent of the budgeted turnover for a specific product is charged as a fee for the licence. The use of the logo in the non-exclusive category can be used on packaging, business cards, letterheads and like goods. An exclusive licence can also be used where the logo is a predominant feature of a product. The cost of the royalty is the standard industry royalty payable on brand names. I understand that some 700 non- exclusive licences and some 40 exclusive licences have been granted at this stage. The criterion for gaining a non-exclusive licence is that the product must contain 75 per cent of Australian content. In the case of exclusive licences, very properly, there is a requirement that there must be 100 per cent local content. Again, it is quite clear that the whole objective of the campaign started by the former coalition Government and carried on by the present Government is to ensure the continuing development of this logo. With events such as we saw last year in the win of Australia II in the America's Cup and a number of other very successful events held in Australia or won by Australians there is an increasing awareness in the logo.

I go back to the battle waged by Sir John Gorton as Prime Minister to develop a modern awareness, a national pride in Australia. The development of the Australian Film and Television School and a variety of other things lifted Australia and took us through the period of the 1970s in the creation of what I believe was a feeling of identity through to the Advance Australia logo campaign , which started in 1975 and which is continuing successfully. I warmly applaud the present Government's continuation of the program. The Opposition could comment on particular aspects of this matter but I think that I have said sufficient other than in relation to one thing, that is small or new businesses. Small businesses and new businesses may like to incorporate the logo. I believe it would be desirable if some consideration were given as soon as possible to providing terms for perhaps a starting fee which did not impose too much of an imposition on the firm or small business which was just commencing. The starting fee could then develop to the full phased fee when the business was fully under way. I suggest that as a way of encouraging the development of business and the use of the logo in Australia.

As I said, there are some 700 non-exclusive and some 40 exclusive licences. As I understand it, the latter are negotiated on a normal royalty basis which may enable the company to assist small business and developing business in the way in which I have suggested. With that suggestion, I simply indicate that the Opposition warmly supports the introduction of this legislation by the new Government, which is, as I have mentioned, a continuation of a program developed by the former Government. I am sure there is complete bipartisan support for it from all sections of this chamber and all the people in the community. I find it very hard to imagine that people would suggest that this is other than a good thing. Let us get on with it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: — In this debate on the Advance Australia Logo Protection Bill I raise a matter relating to the logo itself. The logo is a representation of the Australian flag with a darkened triangle pointing upwards. To the extent that it is representative of Australia, it does a little bit better than, for example, the Australian bicentennial road development program's logo in which it is very difficult to detect or discern the shape of the State from which I come, Tasmania. I take the opportunity of raising this matter before the Senate which, in fact, is the States House. I take this opportunity while we are speaking about logos and representations of Australia to point out that tourist cards which are published in the city of Canberra have on the back a depiction of the Australian mainland and a message urging the recipient to show the card to a friend with the object of promoting tourism in Australia. These cards have a map of Australia with the significant omission of Tasmania.

SPEECH.PARA: I take the opportunity that the second reading debate affords in that it deals with logos and representations of Australia to remind the Senate and the public of the importance of ensuring that Tasmania is not left off the map as it was in Queensland during the Commonwealth Games. That is the sole reason for my standing up in this place.

TALK.START.PARA: —By whom is the card to which you referred published and which is circulating in Canberra?

—According to the information provided to me the tourist postcard is produced by Colortech Productions of Canberra. That information was supplied to me and perhaps to other senators by a civil engineer in New South Wales who presumably has the interests of the State of Tasmania at heart. Again, I apologise for delaying the Senate, but I believe that it is important not only for the Government but also for the people who are attempting to advance Australia, whether through tourism or industry in the private sector, to be aware of the feelings of the people in my State about being left off the map.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Government in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —As previous speakers have pointed out, the Advance Australia Logo Protection Bill 1984 deals with the so-called Advance Australia logo which Senator Harradine described with such graphic care in the course of his speech. All I can say to Senator Harradine about the Advance Australia logo is that Tasmania's star is there in the Advance Australia logo although, as he pointed out, Tasmania might have been omitted from some other logos and promotional campaigns. I see that as a source of great regret because I regard Tasmania as a jewel in the potential crown in the Commonwealth tourist industry. It would be a great mistake by Colortech of Canberra to go on ignoring that fact if it is publishing tourist postcards.

SPEECH.PARA: I thank honourable senators for their general support of the Advance Australia Logo Protection Bill. Indeed Senator Rae displayed a warmth which is often absent in this chamber in his support of the legislation. I appreciate that. The Bill seeks to regulate the use of the logo as the unlicensed use of it threatens to undermine the viability of the Advance Australia campaign and of course the financial viability of the Advance Australia company. Plenty of colourful examples have been given of imports into Australia from various countries which have the Advance Australia logo affixed by the manufacturing work force in other places before they arrive here. This was a source of great concern to the company and, of course, I think to most Australians.

I make the point that the Advance Australia company is a non-profit, self- funding public interest company which, as Senator Rae pointed out, was established in 1981. Revenue raised by the company is used to promote the campaign which is aimed at stimulating the demand for Australian goods or Australian made goods. I think that is a very important exercise. It is for that reason that this Government has continued to support the Advance Australia company and has brought in this legislation at its request to protect the logo. It is for similar reasons that the Government has resumed funding of the Industrial Design Council of Australia, for example. Unless we take much greater care and be a little more painstaking about questions of product design and quality in this country and unless those questions are substantially addressed in the way they have not been in the past, there can be no long term resurgence of the Australian manufacturing industry.

This legislation is required because in the heady and desirable enthusiasm of Sir John Gorton's days, to which Senator Rae referred, and when this company was first established, the logo design was not registered prior to its industrial use. This legislation is designed to ensure that the campaign is not discredited by use of a logo on imported goods, as I pointed out a minute or two ago. It is to protect the interests of Australian firms which, in good faith, supported the campaign through franchise arrangements. The Bill will establish the company as owner of the copyright and design of the logo and provide for laws relating to ownership of personal property to apply for the design of the logo. Advance Australia and franchisees will be able to seek compensation in the courts for damages if there is any infringement of their rights.

Senator Rae, in the course of his speech, made a suggestion that perhaps the company could consider that the starting fee, as I think he called it, paid by a franchisee for the use of the logo might be adjusted to accommodate the interests of small and new businesses. I might say with respect that that is a very worthwhile suggestion and one which I will pass on to the chairman of the company as coming from Senator Rae in the course of this discussion in the Senate.

Finally, I make the point which I really touched on a minute ago, that it will be the company's responsibility to seek protection through the courts as an independent entity without the need for Commonwealth involvement in any litigation which takes place. But there are safeguard provisions in the Bill to protect the Commonwealth's interests. For example, if the company should be wound up the ownership of the logo would revert to the Commonwealth. If there were any unidentified or indeed unlikely circumstances where the Minister took the view that it was no longer in the public interest for the company to own the logo, it would similarly revert to the Commonwealth. I make those technical points about the legislation. I think that the most important thing is the enthusiastic support which it has received in the Senate and the recognition on both sides of the chamber and indeed, I think, in Australia generally of the importance of encouraging the purchase of Australian manufactured goods by Australians, and the importance of encouraging a pride in good quality Australian products, well designed Australian products, and if we can, of spreading something of the enthusiasm to which Senator Rae referred in connection with the America's Cup through to industry and the purchase of the products of Australian industry because they are regarded as good and a source of pride by all Australians. I thank the Senate for its support of the Bill. I commend the second reading to the Senate.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time, and passed through its remaining stages without amendment or debate.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Australian Capital Territory Tourist Commissioner-Northern Territory

PROCTEXT.PARA: Motion (by Senator Button) proposed:
That the Senate do now adjourn.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reid Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —Tonight I want to place on record my pleasure in the work that was done by the Australian Capital Territory Tourist Commissioner, Mr Don Hamence, during the three years in which he held that position. His term of office ended on 31 March 1984 when the Minister for Territories and Local Government (Mr Uren) failed to renew his term of office. Let it be clear that originally he was appointed for a two-year term and that term was extended by 12 months. There is no suggestion that the Minister terminated his employment, but I criticise the fact that his term was not renewed. I think Canberra has lost a great deal as a result of his not continuing in that office, because of the expertise that this man has and the experience he gained during the three years he was Tourist Commissioner.

SPEECH.PARA: A former Minister for the Capital Territory, Mr Ellicott, realised the potential for tourism in the Australian Capital Territory. He also realised that it was important for the Australian Capital Territory to diversify its economy and develop those areas where jobs could be most readily obtained. No one would ever imagine that the Australian Capital Territory would ever be other than principally a town where the Australian Public Service has the dominating role in employment, but I think that most people would agree that it is important to diversify as widely as possible the employment base to give the widest possible range of opportunities for jobs to young people who are growing up in the community.

Mr Ellicott saw the position of Tourist Commissioner as needing to be in part Public Service and in part not Public Service-at somewhat of a tangent to the Public Service-so that the person who held the job could have some freedom to move in a way that a public servant may not be able to move. The position also needed a person who had an understanding of how the private sector operated and had experience in that area. The person who was appointed was Mr Don Hamence. He had had a distinguished career. Previously he had been with Hertz Rent-a-Car in Melbourne. He had an understanding of both private sector operations and the tourist industry. In fact, the appointment was made subsequently by Mr Hodgman as Minister for the Capital Territory.

As I said, Mr Hamence has held the job for three years since then. In that time the tourist industry in the Australian Capital Territory has developed in a way that cannot be lightly ignored. The number of visitors to Canberra increased by 9.4 per cent in the first year that Mr Hamence was involved in promoting tourism . The number went up by 17.8 per cent in the second year and 24.6 per cent in the third year. That seems to me to be a totally outstanding achievement as a result of the work that he did during his three years in that position. It should not be overlooked that the 24.6 per cent increase in the number of tourists visiting the Australian Capital Territory in the third year represents an increase of 1,500 jobs in the tourist industry in Canberra during that time. That probably makes it the largest employer of labour outside the Public Service .

The tourist industry in the Capital Territory has been let down by the present Minister by his failure not only to reappoint Mr Hamence to his job but also to provide adequate budgetary allocations to the Tourist industry. In last year's Budget $500,000 was allocated to tourist promotion. That was identical to the amount allocated the previous year. There was no increase in the allocation, not even to take account of inflation. Last year the Commonwealth allocated $30,000 to supplement the moneys of the Canberra Visitor and Convention Bureau. That amount is identical to that allocated the previous year. That sum is matched dollar for dollar by the Canberra Visitor and Convention Bureau. Last year its commitment to tourism was such that it provided $50,000, which is in excess of the amount it was required to provide under the provisions of the Commonwealth grant.

During the time that Mr Hamence has been promoting tourism in the Capital Territory he has travelled throughout Australia and overseas in order to produce the results to which I have referred, namely, the percentage increases in the number of tourists visiting the Australian Capital Territory. He has made contacts and has supervised the establishment of offices in both Melbourne and Sydney for the purpose of representing Canberra and promoting the national capital as a tourist attraction. I regret most the loss of the experience he has gained over those three years. I think it is a great pity that the Minister for Territories and Local Government so little understands the need for promoting tourism in Canberra that, apart from not responding to his financial responsibility, he has allowed this man to leave Canberra.

Last year funds provided to the Australian Tourist Commission increased by 75 per cent. That gives some indication of the attitude to tourism of the Minister for Sport, Recreation and Tourism (Mr John Brown) and his understanding of the needs of the industry. Tourist commissions have been set up in most States of Australia but not yet in the Australian Capital Territory, in spite of the very strong recommendation of the Parliamentary Joint Committee on the Australian Capital Territory and the Commissioner for Tourism that a tourist commission be set up in the Capital Territory to ensure that its tourism development continues .

I have no doubt that Mr Hamence will get on well in his future endeavours. He has ability. He has already been offered a number of positions by such organisations as the South Melbourne Cricket Club. Hertz Rent-a-Car has been in contact with him about rejoining that organisation. The Australian Tourist Commission has spoken to him about his taking up a position as a consultant to it. At least the Australian Tourist Commission appreciates what he has to offer to the tourist industry, even though the local Minister does not. I understand that the Northern Territory Government has had consultations with him about his working as a consultant to it. A report in the Canberra Times reads:
The Minister for Territories and Local Government, Mr Uren, acting on advice from his department, decided to not renew Mr Hamence's term after its expiration today.
I wrote to the Minister suggesting that it was an error of judgment to proceed with this course of action. The Minister said in reply:
It is recognised that Mr Hamence has made a contribution to tourism in the ACT.

I regard that as the understatement of the year, when one considers the percentage increases in tourism to which I have already referred. At least the Minister for Sport, Recreation and Tourism appreciates Mr Hamence. Last Thursday night a testimonial dinner was held in Canberra, attended by 140 representatives of the tourist industry. Another 40 people sent their apologies. That indicates a fairly high degree of involvement on the part of Mr Hamence in the tourist industry, and in a sense it reflects the views of its representatives about his being taken away from them in this manner. Mr Brown sent the following telegram to Mr Hamence:

Sorry, prior commitments prevent me from being with you this evening. I could not let the occasion pass however without saying how impressed I have been with the enthusiasm you have displayed for the promotion of tourism in the ACT. My best wishes to both you and your wife for the future.

I hope it is of some consulation to Mr Hamence that at least that Minister appreciates his talents and what he did for the Australian Capital Territory. That this man is now living in Melbourne is a serious and grave loss to the Australian Capital Territory.

I would not wish my remarks in any way to reflect on the man who has been appointed to replace him. I refer to Mr David Dickson who has been managing the National Sports Centre at Bruce. He is an extremely talented person. I have no doubt that he will be able to do the job. No matter how well he does it, tourism in the Australian Capital Territory will be three years behind the position that it should have been had the job been done by the man who has already made the contacts and who has been successful in promoting tourism in the Capital Territory. It is simply my wish to place on record my sorrow that the Minister showed so little judgment in this matter by not ensuring that this man stayed in this community.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kilgariff Sen B.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —Friday, 23 March, is a date that will be remembered in the Northern Territory as the day that Cyclone Kathy lashed Borroloola, that very remote small town 50 miles south of the Gulf of Carpentaria. Some 500 people took shelter in the police station and in the community hall. Honourable senators will remember that just the other day I moved a motion in this place commending the police officer who did an extremely good job in looking after the people of Borroloola, as well as the many other people who provided assistance. Much comment has been made about whether aid has been provided to Borroloola and whether government authorities are co-operating in providing assistance. As a result of Cyclone Kathy lashing Borroloola one person lost his life on a lugger, and many other luggers in the Gulf of Carpentaria were washed ashore. Within hours of that lashing, the Royal Australian Air Force, in conjunction with the Northern Territory Government, rushed supplies to Borroloola. As was the case when Cyclone Tracy hit Darwin, the Royal Australian Navy also provided assistance.

SPEECH.PARA: I wish to reassure those who feel that perhaps arrangements to provide assistance have gone amiss that that is not the case. I shall read into the Hansard record a series of messages that have passed between the Federal Government and the Northern Territory Government. I often think that in these sophisticated times when things can be made to happen at the push of a button and in these times when we have modern methods of communication on occasions things can go amiss. Messages have been flying backwards and forwards suggesting that the Northern Territory is not participating in the provision of relief to the people of Borroloola. The first telex to which I refer is dated today. It was sent by the Acting Chief Minister of the Northern Territory to the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke). It states:
In response to your telex I thank you for your message of sympathy for those affected by Cyclone Kathy.
I know that the Commonwealth stands ready to assist the Northern Territory under the natural disaster relief arrangements. This assurance is welcomed.

From a question asked in the Senate today it appears that there is some misunderstanding regarding formal acceptance of your offer. In the past the Northern Territory Government has claimed reimbursement of expenditure on approved relief measures in accordance with the Commonwealth natural disaster relief scheme; total physical damage is estimated at less than $1 million--
That refers to Borroloola of course, not the luggers. It continued:
The extent of financial support required from the Commonwealth cannot be determined until Northern Territory expenditure exceeds its assessed financial capacity under the relief scheme.

The Northern Territory counter disaster plan sprung into operation immediately providing emergency relief, and where needed shelter and food. The Treasurer/ Minister for Lands visited Borroloola immediately after the cyclone.
Government officers are presently preparing an urgent submission on the need for assistance for the relief of financial hardship.
I hope that these arrangements will be acceptable to you, and are not construed as a lack of acceptance of the Commonwealth's offer.
Yours sincerely,
There was a Press release by the Treasurer, Mr Marshall Perron, on 1 April, which was yesterday, which stated:
Three officers from the Department of Community Development should complete a comprehensive review of the needs of the people of Borroloola by the end of this week.
The officers are interviewing every person in the community and the surrounding outstations to determine levels of government assistance needed in the wake of Cyclone Kathy.
The Treasurer, Mr Marshall Perron, said today that the Government would be in a position to deal with individual needs once the report was assessed.
Mr Perron, who inspected Borroloola the day after the cyclone struck, said government teams had meanwhile provided all assistance possible to the town.
Power had been restored quickly, sewerage systems pumped out and maintained, and provisions brought in from Darwin and Katherine.
He rejected claims by the Northern Land Council and the Opposition that Aboriginal people had somehow been neglected.
'Nobody is short of food, clothing and immediate shelter,' he said.
'A credit system has been established at the local store and emergency supplies are also available.
'Tents and tarpaulins were in short supply for a few days, but this was rectified once the flood situation eased in the Daly River area.

One can well imagine, with the very heavy monsoons at this time, in conjunction with Cyclone Kathy, that the whole country was absolutely under water. If people down here cannot appreciate such a situation I can only suggest that they go to the Top End of Australia in what we call a wet wet, such as is being experienced this year. The Press release continued:
'All available tents were then transferred to Borroloola.
Mr Perron said longer term problems regarding housing for Borroloola people were being addressed.
He said the Housing Commission and the Aboriginal Development Commission had been asked whether housing projects could be brought forward.
Decisions on this were expected shortly.
The Treasurer said that the Borroloola town plan which had been brought into action last week would not disadvantage any people in the area.
'I have previously made it clear that the town plan seeks to manage future development in a sensible manner, and that the rights of existing land users will not be at risk.'
A statement, reporting Mr Marshall Perron some four days later, on 27 March, after the cyclone, stated as follows:

The paper read as follows-
NATURAL DISASTER RELIEF

Commonwealth assistance for natural disaster relief is provided under the natural disaster relief arrangements. These long-standing arrangements provide for Commonwealth financial assistance to help the States and the Northern Territory meet the unpredictable and sometimes large costs of providing natural disaster relief. The arrangements recognise the States' primary responsibility for the administration, provision and funding of relief measures, in line with their constitutional responsibilities in this area.

The Commonwealth's role is confined to providing financial support when a State 's expenditure on approved relief measures in a financial year exceeds its assessed financial capacity. Natural disasters covered by the arrangements are of a weather-related kind-cyclones, floods, storms, bushfires and droughts.

Under the arrangements, the Commonwealth provides assistance on a $3 Commonwealth to $1 State basis for expenditure by each State on approved relief and restoration measures in cases of 'major' disasters where such expenditures exceed a State's assessed financial capacity as represented by an annual base amount of expenditure. A major disaster is, for this purpose, defined as a disaster of which a State's expenditure on approved measures exceeds one-tenth of that State's annual base amount. The existing base amounts, set in 1978-79, are:
$ million
New South Wales 10.0
Victoria 7.0
Queensland 4.0
South Australia 3.0
Western Australia 3.0
Tasmania 1.2
Northern Territory 0.25
The approved measures which attract Commonwealth assistance under the arrangements are as follows:
(i) grants for relief of personal hardship and distress (cyclones, floods, storms and bushfires);
(ii) grants for restoration of public assets and emergency protection and repair works by State, local and semi-government authorities (disasters as in (i ));
(iii) concessional loans to small businesses (cyclones and floods);
(iv) concessional loans to churches, sporting associations and other voluntary non-profit organisations (disasters as in (iii));
(v) concessional loans to primary producers for carry-on, restocking and restoration purposes (cyclones, floods, storms, bushfires and droughts);
(vi) freight subsidies for primary producers (disasters as in (v));
(vii) subsidies to primary producers for carriage of water to central dispersal points (drought); and
(viii) assistance to State, local and semi-government authorities for the disposal of helpless and unsaleable stock (floods, bushfires and droughts).

The Commonwealth also meets half of the cost of assistance provided by the States on approved measures for the immediate relief of personal hardship and distress where such expenditures do not qualify for $3 for $1 assistance under the conditions outlined above. Approved measures for the relief of personal hardship and distress comprise the provision of emergency food, clothing and accommodation, essential repairs to houses to make them habitable and secure, and the repair and replacement of essential items of furniture and personal effects. These measures are restricted to people left in needy circumstances as a result of a disaster. In practice, the cost of assistance provided for the immediate relief of personal hardship and distress under the $1 for $1 arrangements is minor compared with assistance provided under the $3 for $1 arrangements.

As a result of the inclusion of the above-mentioned measures in the arrangements, the States are able to assume that relief expenditure incurred in respect of these measures will be eligible for Commonwealth assistance following specified major disasters. If a State wishes to change the terms of previously approved measures (e.g. the size of concessional loans), it is required to seek Commonwealth agreement. It also remains open to a State to request Commonwealth agreement to a new measure which it may wish to implement for a particular disaster or indeed to implement, completely on its own initiative and without seeking Commonwealth approval, measures for which the State would itself accept full financial responsibility.

A provision of $8.5 million was made in the 1982-83 Budget for natural disaster relief. Commonwealth assistance to the States and the Northern Territory increased to $146.3 million by the end of 1982-83. This large unexpected increase resulted primarily from the worsening of the drought in all the mainland States and the bushfires in Victoria and South Australia in February 1983. In addition, several States, particularly Queensland, made claims in respect of storms, floods and cyclones.

The Budget estimate for 1983-84 of $110.4 million is to provide for outstanding commitments and continuing assistance to the States and the Northern Territory for natural disaster relief. Significant assistance will continue in respect of outstanding commitments for bushfire relief in Victoria and South Australia, for relief in areas still affected by drought, particularly in Queensland, and for re-establishment assistance in other areas which were, until recently, severely affected by drought. In addition, a large provision has been made for relief of the extensive flooding which occurred in New South Wales and Queensland between April and June 1983. As these floods occurred only recently, full assessments of flood damage have not yet been completed and it is possible that Commonwealth commitments for relief payments in respect of these floods will increase during 1983-84.

The following table shows payments to the States since 1979-80, including estimated payments in 1983-84. Reflecting the differing incidence of disasters, the amounts vary considerably from one State to another and from one year to another.
