TALK.START.PARA: —One particular aspect has been very disappointing to me. Indeed, many aspects of the project have been disappointing. However, I would like to speak very briefly on the defence aspects of the Alice Springs-Darwin railway line. Honourable senators will recall that the Government set up an inquiry into the feasibility of this project. Mr Hill from the New South Wales Rail Authority was appointed to head the inquiry. But he had a limited reference . In fact, it is rather amazing that the defence aspect of the feasibility and viability of the project was excluded from the terms of reference. One must surely feel that a railway line has a major part to play in the development, and through that the defence, of the north. In spite of that the Federal Government did not include defence in the terms of reference in the inquiry set up to look at the viability of the railway line. Very many aspects in regard to the viability of the line have not come to light. It is my intention from time to time to add to the store of information within the Senate in the hope that the desirability of and the necessity for such a line will be recognised and eventually the line will be constructed. I seek leave to have incorporated in Hansard a Northern Territory Government position paper entitled 'Alice Springs to Darwin Railway-Defence Aspects'.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
The document read as follows-
ALICE SPRINGS TO DARWIN RAILWAY-DEFENCE ASPECTS
Northern Territory Government Position Paper
Department of the Chief Minister,Darwin, N.T.
March, 1984
Logistics are an important dimension of military strategy, and transport is a key element of logistics.

In the major work to date on logistics in Western literature, The Sinews of War : Army Logistics 1775-1953 (Office of the Chief of Military History, U.S. Army, Washington D.C., 1966), the author, J. A. Huston, asks whether it is possible, on the basis of over 175 years of experience, to draw any principles of logistics having general applicability. In his conclusions he considers only one area of first and most enduring importance-the role of transport. Huston maintains that the most common limiting factor in U.S. Army logistics has been transport. He states:

''Wherever shortage of supplies or equipment have appeared at the battle fronts , from the Revolutionary War to the Korean War, more often than not it has been the result of shortage in transportation somewhere along the line. While transportation might be the most general limiting factor on logistics as a whole , the limitations of transportation itself might be determined by a small segment of the total transportation system-shipping, port facilities, roads, railroads, vehicles, or other facilities.''

Australia has a unique defence environment. Within that environment, geographic and other considerations place a premium on mobility and the means of achieving mobility in the interests of national defence.
The White Paper entitled 'Australian Defence', released in 1976, summarised the key features of the Australian defence environment.
''Factors such as geography, population size and distribution, infrastructure, industrial capacity and resources distribution combine to create enduring features in our physical environment.

Our country is an island continent, with an extensive maritime resource area. We have no land frontiers. Except in the Torres Strait area, any approach to our continent would involve a transit of the open ocean, by sea or air. Any confrontation or conflict would be, initially at least, maritime in character. The population is relatively small and is largely urban, coastal and concentrated in the south-east. Defence infrastructure or relevant civilian infrastructure are still limited in the north and west.
The physical environment of Australia suggests that the characteristics of our force structure should include:
a good capability for external intelligence;
a capacity for the regular surveillance and patrol of our ocean approaches and maritime resources zone;
naval and air strike components to deter potential adversaries;
readily transportable and mobile land forces, with adequate capability for reconnaissance, to meet hostile incursions at remote localities;
mobile air defence elements;
elements for the protection of shipping from attack or other interference in Australia's focal areas and port approaches;
a capability for sustained operations at long ranges from bases and in areas remote from sources of logistic support.'' Chapter 3, paras. 30-32).
The importance of transport facilities-and railway facilities in particular-in the Australian defence context is underscored by events in World War II.

Traffic on the Northern Australian line grew from 52,085 train km in 1939 to 1, 193,372 train km in 1944, with up to 147 trains per week operating in the latter part of the war. Traffic in 1943-44 was up 6,000 per cent on pre-war years.
(Source: Rails to the Top End-The Adelaide Darwin transcontinental railway ( Cromarty Press, Sydney, 1982).
The following extracts from that book are revealing:

'' . . . the NAR (North Australian Railway) was in such an appalling condition (in World War II) that it could not meet the demands made upon it. The Government in Canberra had been warned several years earlier about the shortcomings of the railway-its ancient locomotives, for example-and had done little to rectify the situation.

The shortcomings of the transport system were shown graphically in 1942, when the Japanese posed a distinct threat to the northern coast of Australia. The railway system to the Northern Territory simply could not cope; not only was there the gap between the lines (and the poor road substitute) between Alice Springs and Larrimah, but what railway locomotive and rolling stock there was was grossly inadequate . . .

This history, War Economy 1942-45, published by the Australian War Memorial, points out that the war situation made coastal shipping-previously so important in the supply of commodities to Darwin-basically dangerous. The railway, inadequate as it was, had to fill the gap . . .''
Defence arguments in support of the Alice Springs to Darwin railway do not rest on equipping Australia to fight ''yesterday's war'', but relate to Australia's continuing defence requirements.

The importance of civil infrastructure-and particularly of transport systems in the north, north-west and centre of the continent-for the defence of Australia, is referred to in the 1976 Defence White Paper:

''Civilian facilities in the south-eastern part of Australia are, with some exceptions, capable of satisfying defence requirements in foreseeable strategic circumstances. Transport systems are less developed particularly in the north, north-west and centre of the continent. There is no all-weather overland route to the north of the continent. Most sizable communities have airstrips capable of accepting RAAF transport aircraft. Most coastal communities can provide fuel and provisions to naval ships, but ports are limited in number.

In present and prospective strategic circumstances, increased attention will be paid to influencing developments in civil infrastructure that may be relevant. This comprehends roads, railways, ports, airfields, communications, water acquisition and storage, and power sources. A more organised system is needed for bringing defence interests to the notice of the relevant authorities, with the objective of bringing the location of facilities of this kind more clearly into line with the strategic requirements for the defence of Australia''. ( Chapter 7, paras 31-32).

Transport infrastructure in northern Australia is inadequate to meet Australia's defence requirements. Construction of the Alice Springs to Darwin railway will contribute towards rectifying this inadequacy in Australia's defence capabilities.
Support for the above viewpoints is provided by a range of authoritative opinion:

The distances involved in our physical environment demand that long-range mobility by land, sea and air should be available to the force from the Defence inventory, complemented by civil aircraft, merchant shipping and other transportation facilities as may be available. Within Australia, restraints could be imposed on mobility by the locations and limitations of existing ports, airfields, roads and railways.''
1976 Defence White Paper-Chapter 4, para. 95

''The operations of the Australian Defence Force in mobilisation are directly constrained by the capabilities of the supporting logistics infrastructure. Moreover, this constraint becomes tighter the longer the state of emergency or state of war lasts. These areas are currently a major weakness in the Australian defence posture. Because the environment of Australian military operations in the 1950's and 1960's was always far forward, in north-east or south-east Asia, there has been little concern for the development of indigenous logistics capabilities. Logistics support for Australian commitments from Korea to Vietnam was essentially provided by our allies. As a result, Australia's transport and communication systems, supply and maintenance depots, harbours and docking facilities, power supply systems, medical facilities, etc., are all quite deficient from the point of view of the defence of Australia. Assured logistics support is essential to Australia's self-reliance.''
J. O. Langtry: ''Mobilisation Requirements'', in Australian Defence Policy for the 1980's, edited by Robert O'Neill and D. M. Horner, Queensland U.P., 1982, pp . 189-190

''Australia has little suitable shipping for operations across the beaches of the north-west. Our only potential landing ship, HMAS Tobruk, which possesses a very small load capacity, cannot beach on such beaches. The ports of Darwin and Port Hedland are thus of the utmost importance and should be developed to expeditiously discharge and clear container and other military cargo. It would be essential that these ports have a co-ordinated air defence capability. We should, too, be determined to hold these ports from either land or seaward attack.
If these two port complexes are seen to be strategically important to our control of the north-west, then the road and rail networks must reflect that importance.''

P. J. Greville: ''Central Organisation for Movements in War''. Printed in Problems of Mobilisation in Defence of Australia Ed. Desmond Ball and J. O. Langtry, Phoenix Defence Publications, 1980, p. 92.

''Air and road transport are clearly very significant modes of defence of the Australian mainland. However, rail and sea have a contribution to make. Debate continues over who will pay for construction of the Alice Springs to Darwin rail link. It could be the single most revolutionary contribution to Australia's transport to the end of this century with great ramifications for changing our defence strategy. Completion of the railway would mean a rail link between our major capital cities and would herald the beginnings of the Darwin transport axis. Darwin would become the centre of Australia's trade wheel with Asia with spokes reaching to all Asian cities and trade routes and extending throughout the rest of mainland Australia. The rail link is the perfect example of expenditure on transport infrastructure which could create its own economic viability and at the same time have far-reaching usefulness for Australia's defence. With consultation between business and defence planners this type of development can be continued where benefits accrue to all sections of our community while contributing to national security.''
Address by Sir Peter Abeles to the Royal United Services Institute Conference held in Sydney, October 1983.

''Defence owned transport assets are readily available (to deal with military threats)-but they are limited and designed for specific military tasks. Military assets would be primarily employed to provide mobility in and near areas of operation.

The major portion of transport resources needed to carry only men and material from main bases to deployment areas will be provided almost entirely from our national civil assets. (Railways were the) only real effective way of moving large quantities of men and materials. They are susceptible to attack and they can be interdicted, but they have always shown ability to be reconstituted and running again in a short time'' . . .
''With the exception of a few highways, road surfaces were generally poor for military traffic, which mostly exceeded axle-loading regulations.
Also climatic conditions in northern Australia were such that serious interruption to road traffic could be expected.
Third, Australia's long distances would be highly expensive in terms of drivers , equipment and maintenance.''

Address given by Lt. Col. John R. Brien, Chief Transport Movement Officer, N.S. W., of the Royal Australian Corps of Transport, and commanding officer, 2 Transport and Movement Group, to a meeting of the International Cargo Handling Co-ordination Association in Sydney, September 1983. Reported in 'The Australian Financial Review', 21 September, 1983.

''Railways are extremely difficult to damage and very quick to repair; however, they are vulnerable over large rivers and, to a lesser extent, in tunnels. The further inland they are, the harder they are to destroy, the easier the terrain and the fewer vulnerable points occur in the system. The more complex the system , the more flexible it is.

The new railway line from Alice Springs to Darwin is of immense strategic importance, especially if it contains sufficient passing loops for high density traffic and turnouts for spurs to future military installations''.
P. J. Greville, ''National Defence and National Infrastructure'' in Australian Defence Policy for the 1980's Ed. by Robert O'Neill and D. M. Horner, University of Queensland Press, 1982, p. 259.

Whilst I acceded to the request on this occasion, I think it would be in the interests of everybody concerned if we knew what we were agreeing to have incorporated in Hansard. I make that as a passing comment.

I draw attention to the fact that while the two honourable senators were presenting their arguments, not one member of the Opposition parties was in the chamber to listen to their contributions. No matter how important those contributions were, the honourable senators concerned were not able to excite any response or interest from their own parties. In other words, it was left to the Government to listen and respond to their remarks. As the adjournment debate has now covered more than three-quarters of an hour, I shall undertake to refer the other relevant matters raised in this debate to the appropriate Ministers.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Kilgariff Sen B.F.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Communications, upon notice, on 11 October 1983:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) When will a decision be made on the operations of the Aussat satellite.

(2) Does the Minister for Communications accept the report of the Aussat Conference, held in Alice Springs on 16 July 1983, in particular the recommendation that control of the satellite be vested in Aussat and that the Aussat body continue as a relatively small, independent and effective organisation.

(3) What plans does the Government have for the allocation of the necessary financial and physical resources to ensure Australians in remote areas receive modern telephone, television and radio services as quickly as possible.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Communications has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) and (2) On 29 February 1984 the Minister for Communications introduced into the House of Representatives the Satellite Communications Bill 1984 and the Satellite Communications (Consequential Amendments) Bill 1984 which cover the ownership of the National Communications Satellite System and the way in which it may be operated.

(3) The Australian Broadcasting Corporation will be provided with the resources necessary to establish and provide the Homestead and Community Broadcasting Satellite Service-HACBSS-which will enable people in remote areas to receive one ABC television service and at least two radio services.

Funds and resources have been allocated to the Department of Communications to conduct tests of reception of television services by means of small low cost earth stations. When these tests are concluded, the Government will have the information on which technical standards for such earth stations will be determined.

There has been a long standing program for the extension of television and radio services to remote communities and this is continuing. The program includes consideration, in particular instances, of extension by means of satellite rather than terrestrial distribution systems where this is shown to be the most cost effective means to adopt.

As an addition to the on-going program, the Government allocated funds from the 1983-84 Budget to undertake further extensions to ABC (National) Services through the remote and underserved communities scheme which will extend radio to 12 nominated areas and television to a further 42 communities.

In addition, Telecom Australia has announced a program to bring telephone services to remote areas by 1990 through the terrestrial network using digital radio concentrator systems-DRCS-which are designed to extend the basic telephone service to more remote areas in the cheapest possible manner.

Telecom has also announced the Iterra Satellite Service, designed to provide a range of switched and leased, voice and data services for enterprises, such as mining, exploration and tourist developments where service is required ahead of normal program timing.
The technical and financial aspects of the provision of a telephone service to those few communities which will not be reached by DRCS by 1990 are still under consideration.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Attorney-General, upon notice, on 1 December 1983.

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Will the Attorney-General's Department examine all issues of the magazine Soldier of Fortune distributed in Australia since 1978 to see if any offence has been committed since the Crimes (Foreign Incursions asnd Recruitment) Act 1978 came into effect and advise the result of that examination (see answer to Question No. 253, Hansard, 1 November 1983, p. 1964).

(6) Will the Attorney-General clearly answer in the affirmative or negative part one of Question No. 253 about whether the magazine does or does not ' . . . specifically glorify the activities of mercenaries and proffessional killers,' in respect of issues of the magazine sold in Australia since 1978.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Jones Sen G.N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Health, upon notice, on 2 March 1984:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Can the Minister for Health advise whether any epidemiological studies have indicated that vasectomy may be clinically harmful, as thousands of Australians undergo this operation each year.
(2) Has any medical research shown that men who have been sterilised by vasectomy are likely to develop severe atherosclerosis as a direct result of that operation.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Health has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Statistics based on health insurance claims for which benefits have been paid show that around 20,000 Australian men undergo vasectomy each year. To date , there have been no studies published in Australia or overseas which show that vasectomy is clinically harmful.

(2) No. Although studies in monkeys have shown that vasectomy results in an increase in atherosclerosis, to date there has been no documentation of a link in the short term between vasectomy and atherosclerosis and/or heart disease in men. Studies of long term effects in man are in progress. However, it may be some years before any such link, if it exists, can be demonstrated.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Coleman Sen R.N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Resources and Energy, upon notice, on 8 March 1984:

QUESTION.PARA: Is the Government concerned by reports in the Press that Roxby Downs may not proceed because of the continuing slump in uranium demand and its projected continued slump for at least a decade.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: The report released recently by the International Atomic Energy Agency and Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development, 'Uranium-Resources, Production and Demand', indicates that existing and committed production facilities could continue to cover reactor requirements until the end of this decade. After that time some production may be required from new facilities. Whether the Olympic Dam project at Roxby Downs will be one of those new facilities will depend upon the outcome of the feasibility study now being conducted by the joint venturers. The Government has decided that if a commercial decision to proceed with the development of the Olympic Dam project were to be made by the joint venturers, the Government would permit the export of uranium produced from that mine, subject to the safeguards arrangements applied generally to uranium exports at the time of export.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs , upon notice, on 27 March 1984:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Can the Minister for Foreign Affairs confirm that the former Acting Director-General of the Australian Secret Intelligence Service, Mr John Ryan, has returned to the Department of Foreign Affairs as a Deputy Secretary, paid over $60,000 per annum.
(2) Can the Minister say why Mr Ryan is regarded as competent to fill such as senior position in view of Mr Justice Hope's criticism of Mr Ryan.
(3) Can the Minister also indicate in what way Mr Ryan has been penalised for his responsibility for the ASIS Sheraton raid.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Foreign Affairs has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1), (2) and (3) Before being appointed Acting Director-General of ASIS on 5 October 1981 Mr Ryan was a Deputy Secretary, Level 5, in the Department of Foreign Affairs. While he was Acting Director-General of ASIS he was, technically speaking, placed on the Department of Foreign Affairs list of unattached officers as a Level 5 officer. At the time of his resignation as Acting Director-General of ASIS there were no vacant Level 5 positions in the Department of Foreign Affairs. Mr Ryan accordingly remains on the Department of Foreign Affairs list of unattached officers. The salary of a Level 5 officer is $60,471.

As the Prime Minister announced in the House on 29 February 1984 the question of whether or not disciplinary action, and if so what disciplinary action, should be taken against officers who were the subject of findings in Mr Justice Hope's report on the Sheraton Hotel incident is being examined by Mr Hermes.
Pending the outcome of Mr Hermes's examination, Mr Ryan has been placed on special duties in the Department of Foreign Affairs under the direction of the Permanent Head of that Department.
